www.fisglobal.com  1 INTRODUCTION  
The FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  USER GUIDE teaches you to use the FAME system t o perf orm basic data 
management and manipulation. With this guide, you’ll learn how to enter the FAME sys tem an d how to 
issue commands and options to develop the reports, graphs, and analyses that you want. You will learn 
how to create databases and how to  store , document, retrieve, revise, and update data.  
FAME is an acronym for Forecasting, Analysis, and Mo deling  Environment. FAME is a fully integrated 
system, combining data management, reporting, graphics, analytics, system building, and SeamlessTM 
interfaces to other applications outside FAME. Starting FAME 10.0, the Modeling feature is no longer 
supported  by FA ME. 
MarketMap Analytic Platform (FAME) is now FIS Market Data Analyzer  
FIS Market Data Analyzer was formerly named MarketMap Analytic Platform (a lso known  as FAME). The 
following components of FIS Market Data Analyzer and related products are referen ced in this document 
by their former names:  
 FIS Market Data Analyzer (forme rly FAME database)  
 FIS Market Data Analyzer studio (formerly MarketMap Analy tic Core FAM E Studio)  
 FIS Market Data Analyzer data manager (formerly FAME Enterprise Data Manager (FEDM) ) 
 FIS Market Data Analyzer .NET toolkit (TimeIQ.NET) (formerly MarketMap Analytic .NET Toolkit 
(TimeIQ.NET))  
 FIS Market Data Analyzer web API (accessPo int) (for merly MarketMap Analytic Web 
(accessPoint))  
 FIS Market Data Analyzer server (formerly MarketMap Analytic Core FAME Server)  
Documentation Conventions  
We have tried to incorporate as many examples as possible in this u ser guide. We have designed the  
FAME ses sions to be real istic; we deliberately include mistakes that you might make so that we can 
expla in exactly what you sho uld and shouldn’t do, show what happens if you make a mistake, and show 
how easily you can recove r from an error.  
Most of the do cumentati on takes the for m of regular paragraphs and tables. We occasionally change type 
faces or indenta tion to emphasize certa in points.

www.fisglobal.com  2  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
When a complete, valid FAME statement appears in a paragraph, it is capitalized and pr inted in boldface. 
Parts of FAM E stateme nts are merely c apitalized; for example:  
The final report takes place after the END BLOCK  comman d, outside of the block ing structure. It 
shows that the DECIMAL and PREFIX options revert to their original settings.  
When we print a list of example F AME comma nds or options, it looks like this:  
DECIMAL 1  
INTERCEPT ON  
TITLE TEXT "This is a Title", COLOR R ED, FONT GOTHIC  
When we  print an example FAME session, the parts that the user types are printed next to an asterisk 
prompt, while the resulting FAME o utput or response appears  flush with the left margin:  
* DISPLAY SALES  
 
SALES 
 
2006     101.11  
2007     10 2.22 
2008     103.33  
2009     104.44  
 
* REPORT SALES, ASSETS  
 
 
          2006    2007    2008    2009

SALES   10 1.11  102 .22  103.33  104 .44 
ASSETS   88.80   89.20   93.40   95.60  
Command forms appear as part of the t ext and are usually pre sented in one of two ways:  
 Most often, a brief description of the command is given, for example: “The command form is quite 
simp le: NEW f ollowed by the n ame of the new scalar or series, an equals sign, and an 
expression.”  
 In other in stances, all or part of  a command is printed in bold, with the parts that must be replaced 
in lowercase letters, as in t his example: “Where you would o rdinarily  enter the file specification, 
you substitute FILE(string -expression) , where string -expression  contains the information  that 
the user specifies.”  
Description of This Guide  
 Chapter A SAMPLE FAME SESSION  (p. 4) provides an overview of the FAME system.  
 Chapter COMMANDS AND OPTIONS  (p. 16) tells you the difference between commands  and 
options and shows how to i ssue comm ands and options . 
 Chapter FAME C ONVENTIONS  (p. 27) shows you a number of convenient shortcuts within 
FAME, such as abbreviating commands and opt ions. 
 Chapter IMPORTA NT FAME FEATURES  (p. 34) demonstrates the F AME ONLINE HELP 
capabil ity, as well as several other timesaving conveniences.

www.fisglobal.com  3  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 Chapter INTRODUCTION TO DATABASES  (p. 40) tells you how to create, open, and close a 
database in FAME.  
 Chapter DATA AND  WILDCARDING  (p. 45) describes data  within FAME  and shows you how  to 
gain access to data i n a database.  
 Chapter FREQ UENCIES, DATES, AND CASES  (p. 61) tells you how to set time ranges, specify 
dates, and set case ranges . 
 Chapter DATA OBJECTS  (p. 79) describes FAME’s data handling ca pabilities in detail.  
 Chapter EXPRESSIONS  (p. 98) introduces the many function s, mathema tical operators , and 
logical operators used by FAME.  
 Chapter ENTER  AND CHANGE DATA  (p. 127) shows how data and values are created and 
stored in FAME.  
 Chapter MISSING DATA V ALUES (p. 144) tells how FAME handles missing data.  
 Chapter DATA ATTRIBUTES  (p. 148) explains how to document  data objects a nd how to retrieve 
information describing data objects.  
 Chapter DISPLAY AND REPORT D ATA (p. 165) briefly outlines FAME’s reporting c apabilities.  
 Chapter GRAPH DATA  (p. 172) gives an overview of  FAME’s graphing capabi lities. 
 Chapter TIME SCALE CONVERSION  (p. 178) explains the heart of the FAME sy stem: how time 
series can be converted from one frequency to another. FAME offers  many alternative techn iques 
for time scale conversion. Most users will never need to know the details of conversion, bu t they 
are described with sever al illustrations and man y examples.  
 Chapter FORMAT OUTPUT  (p. 200) explains how you can control the appearance of the output 
produced by FAME, from s imple lists to tables printed b y analyses.  
 Chapter MORE ABOUT DATABASES  (p. 222) explai ns what you need to know about using 
databases. It also introduces you to the extremely useful, t emporary database called WORK.  
 Chapter TEXT FILES  (p. 242) tells  you how to create, ope n, close, examine, rename, delete, and 
unsave text files.  
 Chapter INPUT FILES  (p. 250) tells you everything you need to know about sending stored 
commands to the  FAME system.  
 Chapter PROCEDURES  (p. 265) shows you how to create and use your own FAME commands.  
 Chapte r CHANNELING AND OUTPUT FILES  (p. 274) gives advanced users information about 
controlling FAME’s channels and output.  
 Chapter WORK WITH FIS MARKET DATA  ANALYZER STUDIO  (p. 284) tells you how to w ork 
with FAME's graphic al user interface FIS Market Data Analyzer studio .

www.fisglobal.com  4 A SAMPLE FAME SESSION  
FAME is an interactive, comm and-driven, express ion-oriented language. Using a personal computer or a 
workstation, you enter commands  that instruct FAME to operate i n various ways on data objects . FAME 
produces results immediately. For instance,  
UPDATE SALES  
DISPLAY CCI.CLOSE, CCI.VOL UME 
GRAPH CCI.CLOSE , MAVE(CCI.CLOSE,30)  
are comman ds. UPDATE, DISPLAY, and GRAPH are FAME command names; SALES, CCI.CLOSE, and 
CCI.VOLUM E are user -defined name s of user -created data objects.  
SALES, CCI.CLOSE, and CCI.VOLUME are in fact time series . In othe r words, they are s equences of 
values recorded at regular intervals, say, monthly. A time series is the basic data object in FAME — you 
can create it, give it a name, read in its data values, store it in a database for later retrieval, update it, 
display i t, and use it in re ports, graphs, and analyses.  
FAME databases  are special files managed and indexed by FAME. A database can contain tim e series 
with different  frequencies : secondly, minutely, hourly, business day, daily, true weekly, ten -day, biweekly, 
twice-monthly, monthl y, bimonthly, quarterly, fiscal -year quarterly, semi -annual, annual, fiscal -year 
annual, and user -defined periods -per-year and years -per-period. 
A database can also contain scalars  (single values that do not change with time) and case se ries (series 
of val ues indexed by 1, 2, 3, ... rat her than time). Moreover, special features of FAME make it easy for 
FAME databases to be organized in a cross -sectional  fashion: pricing and fundamental data across 
15,000 companies, for example.  
This chapt er provides an over view of the FAME software graph ical user interface,  data objects, 
databases, and some basic commands to manipulate th em. After reading it, y ou will be well prepared to 
learn the FAME fundamentals explained at greater length in this manua l. 
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  overview  
FIS Ma rket Data Analyzer studio  is a Windows -only software graphical user interface for FIS Ma rket 
Data Analyzer . Familiar UI conventions (such as windows, windows, me nus, to olbars, explorers, and 
help) en able you to use FIS Ma rket Data Analyzer . 
See WORK WITH FIS MARKET DATA  ANALYZER STUDIO  (p. 284) for more information about using 
FIS Market  Data Analyzer studio .

www.fisglobal.com  5  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  features  
Features in FIS Market Data Analyzer s tudio release include the following:  
 An integrated Text Editor for editing  FAME code (input and procedure files). You can click to 
execute the INPUT , COMPILE, or CLOAD  commands on your cod e. 
 An Input and Output window that prov ides command input controls a nd text output windows with 
recalling and editing o f previous commands.  
 Syntax highlighting to make code comfortable to read both in the editor and the in put control.  
 A Project Explorer to : 
• Collect together FAME code (input and  procedure files), databases,  and ancillary files such 
as documentation that are  part of the same work  
• View the related files together at a glance  
• Automatically open and close a group  of related items , such as databas es 
Project files are used in the Projec t Explorer to store the files  you specified. Context menus are 
provided to allow  you to:  
• Open local dat abase files  
• Connect to MCADBS and open channels on the connections  
• Build a proje ct which ties tog ether a bundle of  related code files to open in the edit or and 
databases to open  
 A Se ssion Explorer that provides information about the state of your session a t a glance, 
including FREQUENCY, DATE and CASE range, channels, connections, and  so on.  
The Sampl e Session  
The bes t way to get started is to dive right i nto a simple interactive FAME  session. We encourage you to 
sit down at your comp uter or workstation and  type along with us.  
Start FAME  
If you have FAME installed in Windows on a perso nal computer, you  can also start a  FAME session by 
selecting the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  icon from the FAME program group.  
For starting FAME on platfor ms other than Windows, see Starting and Ending a FAME Session  (p. 27). 
You can also issue the MS -DOS com mand to start a FAME se ssion: 
%FAME%\mastudio  
In case your FAME se ssion encounters errors when executing FAME statements, the Output  tab in the 
window d isplays the errors.

FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Create a Database  
Create a new FAM E data base named CORP . The database is in a file named CORP.DB . 
* CREATE CORP 
Create Two Time  Series  
Specify in FAME that all newly created time series should be monthly (that is, indexed by  time at a  
monthly frequency).  
* FREQUENCY MONTHLY  
Set a date rang e for data entry, display, and analysis. The “*” means “go as far as ther e is data.”  
* DATE J AN09 TO *  
Note You can cut, copy, and paste multiple lines of 4GL code from an application such a s Notepad 
into the FAME Input/Outp ut window. FAME executes all the  state ments in the Input/Output  
window. However, if the last statement of  the multi -line code  does not have a newline 
character, then you need to press the Enter key on the keyboard to execu te it succ essfully. 
Before attempt ing to execute the code in the e xample s given in this document, you will need to 
remove the “*” and the e xtra space after it for each s tatement.  
Create a time series named SALES and enter data.  
* SERIES SALES  
* UPDATE SALE S

SALES and is used automatically when  SALES is reported, graphed, and s o on. 
* DESCRIPTION(SALES) = "Sa les less returns"  
Create a time series named EXPENSES and enter data.  
* SERIES EXPENSES  
* UPDATE EXPENS ES

Create Two  Formulas  
Create two formulas, PRO FIT and PROFIT_AFTEROH, to calcu late p rofit and profit -after-overhead -
allocation. Store a description for  PROFIT. Formulas ar e dynamic ; any time the underlying values 
change, the values calculated by the formula change aut omatically  the next time the formu la is used.  
* FORMULA PROFIT = S ALES - EXPENSES  
* FORMULA PROFIT_AFTEROH = 92% * PROFIT - 2 
* DESCRIPTION  (PROFIT) = "Profit Contributi on" 
Make a Report  
The next two statements are examples of FAME options. The options are  being set  globally : they affect 
subsequent FAME operations until they a re set again.  
Set up a title for reports and graphs.

* TITLE "($000 )" 
Specify formattin g for nume ric values in reports. The default is DECIMAL 2 . 
* DECIMAL 1  
Produce a simple report of  the input  and calculated data. In  the REPORT command, an AS claus e is 
used to specify a row description. If no AS clause is given, the ser ies or formula descr iption is used if it 
exists. Otherwise, the name is used.  
Note the use of && at the end of a line  to allow continuation of a long c ommand onto a second line.  
* REPORT SALES, EXPENSES, PROFIT, &&  
         PROFIT_AFTEROH AS " ... after ov erhead"

Creat e Another Time Series  
Set the FREQ UENCY and DATE range appropriate  for creating a new series, INVENTORY . INVENTORY 
is weekly data collected  every Friday, and 2 9 time per iods are to be entered. Note the use of FAME’s 
built-in date arithmetic to set the DATE  range.  
* FREQUENCY WEEKLY(FRIDAY)  
* DATE 2JAN09 TO 2JAN09 + 28  
An equiv alent specification would be 2JAN09 TO 17JUL09  but using FAME’s dat e arithmetic elimin ates 
the n eed to know the calendar date of the 29th Friday in 2009.  
Create the series INVENTORY . 
* SERIES I NVENTORY 
In the UPDATE command note the use of “type -ahead”: FA ME prompts for the correct next date in 
sequence. Moreover, since t he date range set h as a speci fied ending period (as opposed to “*”), the 
update prompting stops automatically after 29 entries . Note also the use of NA (Not Available ) to indicate 
a missing  value: no inventory was taken on July 3.  
* UPDATE INVENTORY  
 
 
INVENTORY 
 
 2-Jan-09 >  42 
 9-Jan-09 >  41  
16-Jan-09 >  38  
23-Jan-09 >  36 for 3  
13-Feb-09 >  35, 34, 31  
 6-Mar-09 >  29 , 31, 30, 29 
 3-Apr-09 >  28, 27, 25, 25 
 1-May-09 >  26, 26, 27, 26 
29-May-09 >  28, 29, 31, 31  
26-Jun-09 >  32  
 3-Jul-09 >  NA  
10-Jul-09 >  33 
17-Jul-09 >  34 
 
* DESCRIPTION(INVENTORY) = "Units in Inventory"  
Set OBSERVED Attributes  
INVENTORY is an end-of-period  measurement; it records th e units on hand every Friday. It  is a stock or a 
level as opposed to a flow or a rate. This can be noted i n the database by s etting the  OBSERVED 
attribute of INVENTORY to END. Other choices for OBSERVED are BEGINNING (a be ginning -of-period 
stock), HIGH (hi ghest stock of the period), LOW (lowest  stock of the period), SUMMED (for flows), 
ANNUALIZED (for flows co nverted to an annua l rate), FORMULA (for transformation of other series. For 
time scale conversion and totaling purp oses, this  attribute is the same a s AVERAGED) , and AVERAGED 
(for s tocks t hat have been averaged over a time period, such as average assets o ver a quarter or we ekly 
avera ges of daily money supply figures).  
FAME uses the OBSERVED attribute in time scale conv ersions (a ggregation, distribution , and fiscal year 
shifting), rep ort tot aling, and positioning data points on graphs. If you do not explici tly set the OBSERVE D

attribut e for a time series, it takes on the current OBSERVED default, which is SUMMED (but thi s default 
can itself be changed). Thus the series SALES and EXPENS ES crea ted above have OBSERVED 
attributes of SUMMED, which is in fact the correct setting.  
* OBSERVED(I NVENTORY) = END  
Inspect the attributes of two time series by using the WHATS command.

Report Data at a Different Frequency  
Instruct FAME t o implicitly conver t all data  retrieved by subsequent commands to a quarterly frequency 
using a cubic spline  (smooth  curve) in terpolation appropriate for the OBSERVED attribute of th e serie s 
being converted.  
* FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
* CONVERT ON, TECHNIQUE CU BIC 
Set up a TITLE and REPORT  command to display SALES and INVENTORY over the first two quarters of 
2009. FAME’s bui lt-in time  scale conversion automa tically insures that quarterly v alues f or SALES are in 
fact three -month sums, and that end -of-quarter valu es for INVENTORY ar e interpol ated from the weeks 
before and after the quarter end. In the REPORT command, note the c ommand -specific setting of the 
DATE range. The word DATE is option al in t his context.  
* TITLE "Summary for 09 Q1 and Q2"  
* REPORT <09Q1, 09Q 2> SALES AS "Quarte rly Sales" , INVENTORY AS &&  
          "End-of-Quarter Inventory"  
 
 
       Summary for 09 Q1 and Q 2

Note  The next couple of pages develop a simple forecasting example in FAME. If you have no 
interest in for ecasting, feel free to s kip over the discussion and pick  up the  session again at the 
next Note. You won’t miss out on anything imp ortant to your unde rstanding of FAME. 
However, the graph you produce later in the session will look different from t he example  we 
print because it won ’t have forecast data.  
Forecast Two Tim e Series  
Now forecast both INVENTORY and SALES for the next quarter . First turn implic it frequen cy conversion 
OFF so that INVENTORY can be forecast weekly and SALES monthly.  
Then use the FORECA ST option to specify tha t the forecast horizon should ex tend th rough 09Q3. FAME 
will automatically begin forecasting from the last  actual data point in each se ries. Moreover, the setting 
INSERT ON in the FORECAST option directs FAME to store the forecast v alues directly in the se ries 
being forecasted (as oppose d to st oring them in a separate series or in a different database).  
Next, use the METHOD opti on to sele ct a forecasting method: Brown’s exponential smoothing, in this 
case. FAME implements e xponential  smoothing as a special case of the more elaborate ARIMA  (“Box -
Jenkins”) method of forecasting  and will choose a smoothing paramet er if you do not s upply one.  The 
choice is based on the fitting technique statisticians call maximum likelihood . 
Finally, mak e forecasts using the EX TRAPOLATE command. Note that the  FORECAS T and METHOD 
options are set globally: they affect all subsequent E XTRAPOLATE command s. They co uld have been 
set command -specific: EXTRAPOLATE <FORECAST TO 09Q3, INSERT ON; METHOD BR OWN> 
SALES , for instance.  
* CONVER T OFF 
* FORECAST TO 09Q3, INSERT  ON 
* METHOD BROWN  
* EXTRAPOLATE SALES

Note  Thos e of you who skipped the  forecasting discussion may resu me the F AME session here.  
Get Help  
Use FAME O NLINE  HELP to obtain informati on on the syntax o f FAME com mands, options, functions, C 
HLI functions, text editor commands and options, subroutin es, and ut ilities. The initial win dow supplies a 
list of categorie s that a re hyperlinked to groups of commands, options, functions, and other  FAME 
features org anized by topic.  
* HELP 
If you’re running FAME on the Windows platform, the FAME O NLINE  HELP can also be op ened by 
selecting FAME H elp from the FAME program group.  
General  FAME ONLINE  HELP topics are displayed in underlined text in the in itial Help window.  To select  a 
topic from the list of FAME  ONLINE  HELP, you move the cursor over one of the topics and click the mouse. 
Choosing one of the topics takes you to a mor e detail ed list of the selected category via a hypertext link.  
You can also  search for specif ic FAME co mmands, options, functions using the Search feature of FAME 
ONLINE  HELP. There is a Sea rch button  available at the top of  the FAME O NLINE  HELP window.

www.fisglobal.com  13  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
There is a lso an Alphabetical Search item available from the initial list of topics in the FAME  ONLINE  HELP 
window.  
Draw a Graph  
You can use FAME’s graphic facilities to draw a plot of histori cal and fo recast data. First, set up new title 
lines, overriding t he font and size defaults for the second title. Next, specify the left axis  label. Then, 
spec ify the ri ght axis label, changing its orientation to the data being plotted for the SALES series . Finally,  
suppress the legend.  
* TITLE #1 "Sales and Inventory Le vel" 
* TITLE #2 " -- Third Quarter Estimated --", FONT F3, SIZE MEDIUM  
* LABEL LEFT "Inventory " 
* LABEL RIGHT "Sales"  
* LABEL LINES RIGHT ORIENTATION DOWN  
* LEGEND OFF  
* DEVICE GRAPHIC POST  
* CHANNEL G RAPHICS inventoryreport. eps 
* OPEN <ACCESS CREATE; KIND GRAPHIC>  inventoryreport.eps  
* GRAPH INVENTORY  
The PLOT option controls gra ph formatting. By default, a ll series are plotted with connected line 
segments in FAME’s choice of color against th e left axi s. For your graph, use t he PLOT option to specify 
medium -thick, solid, vertical lines for INVENTORY and extra -thick, solid, dashed lines referencing the 
right axis for SALES.  
* GRAPH <09Q1 TO 09Q3> INVENTORY <PLOT VERTICAL, MEDIUM, SOLID>, &&  
          SALES <PLOT SOLID, XTHICK, DASHED, RIGHT>  
PLOT is set at th e argume nt-specific  level: that is, a separate PLOT option immediately foll ows each 
series na me. It can  also be set command -specific and globally. Argument -specific settings override 
command -specific settings, which in turn override global settings.  
The gr aph, sho wn on the next page, is produced on a laser printer. Options to spe cify the type of p rinter 
and paper size were included in the FAME “start -up” file (fame.inp ) that can be used to cu stomize 
FAME. These specifications  can be changed or overridden at  any tim e during a FAME session.  
Note that both weekly and monthly data are  included on the s ame graph,  and that INVENTORY is 
automatically positioned at the end of each week.

www.fisglobal.com  16 COMMANDS AND OPTIONS  
FAME is a state ment-driven system. You enter statements at the asterisk (*) prompt. FAME accepts two 
kinds of st atements: commands and o ptions. 
 After you enter a comman d, FAME performs an action. Usually, the system generates output 
such as a graph, report, or display of  some piece of information.  
 When you enter an option, you set a condition that influenc es the beh avior of subsequent FAME  
commands. Options affect the ex ecution of commands, but they do not perform actions and they 
do not genera te output of their  own.  
This chapter discusses both commands and options.  
Using Commands  
Comman ds are composed of comma nd names and, sometimes, command  argumen ts; for example:  
DISPLAY SALES, ASSETS  
REPORT SALES, EXPENSES, NET  
DISPLAY and REPORT  are comma nd names . SALES, ASSETS, EXPENSES, and NET are command 
arguments  naming objects (in thi s case, ti me series) stored in a d atabase. A few commands (CLEAR a nd 
EXIT,  for example) require no arguments.  
Commands may require keywords i n addition to argu ments; for  example:  
RENAME SALES AS NET_SALES  
FIT SALES BY ADVERTISING, EMPLOYEES  
RENAME and FIT are comman ds. SALES, NET_SALES, AD VERTISING, and EMPLOYEES are 
command arg uments. AS and BY are keywords  that make the commands easy to read.  Keywords also 
help you to k eep track of what’s going on: AS shows which is the old name and which is the new name,  
BY tells which series is the resp onse in the regression.  
 
Structu red Comm ands  
A few FAME commands, called structured commands, can incorpora te other commands and option s. The 
structured commands are IF, LOOP, TRY, GRAPH, and REPORT. These commands use a f orm such a s: 
IF some expression or  condition is true

www.fisglobal.com  17  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
   execute a sequence  of commands  
END IF 
or 
REPORT 
   sequence of reporting commands and  options 
END REPOR T 
These co mmands are fully discussed in other FAME guides.  
Expressions in Commands  
Comma nd arguments often name your data objects, such as time series; for example:  
UPDATE SALES  
DISPLAY EXPENSES  
The command arguments SALES and EXPENSES are time series that you have create d. When 
appropriate, you may also use calculation expressions  as command a rguments; for example:  
DISPLAY SALES - EXPENSES  
EXTRAPOLATE PROFITS /ASSETS 
The first command pr ints a list of data values calculated by subtracting EXPENSES from SALES. The 
second co mmand fore casts the ratio of PROFI TS to ASSETS.  
Other uses of calc ulation expressions in commands may be inappropriate, since the expression requires 
an action  that cann ot be performed; for example:  
WHATS SALES - EXPENSES            --Illegal 
This command cannot be executed because the WHA TS command requests information regardin g an 
existing data object. SALES - EXPENSES is an expression that u ses two other data  objects, rather than a 
real stored data object.  
Using Options  
You enter options to influence the  actions o f commands. Options cann ot produce their own output. The ir 
effec ts can be seen only through the changes they cause in the results o f commands.  
Option s are comp osed of option names, option modifiers, and option settings or option modifier settings . 
FAME sto res option settings for future use; for example:  
DECIMAL 1 
WIDTH 60 
TITLE TEXT "This is a Title", COLOR RED, FONT GOTHIC  
DECIMAL, W IDTH, and TITLE ar e options . The values 1 and 60 are option settings . The words TEXT, 
COLOR, and FONT are option mo difiers . The string “This is a Tit le” and the words RED and GOTHIC  are 
option modifier settings .

www.fisglobal.com  18  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
All options have default settings. That is, even before you sp ecify a se tting for a particular option, the 
system determines a setting for that option. For exa mple, the DECIMAL option specifies  the number of 
decimal places th at the s ystem displays on reports. If you type DISPLAY INTEREST_RATE  withou t first 
specifying  the DECIM AL option, FAME displays the data with two decimal places by default (4.25, for 
example ). If you want to change the numbe r of decimal places that are dis played, you can specify 
DECIMAL 4  before typing DISPLAY INTEREST_RATE  to display the number 4 .2541.  
Option Names  
FAME uses single words for most option names, for example, GLUE, GRID, IGNORE , LEGEND, 
METHOD, SEE, and TRANSFO RM. However, a few option names consist of two or more words. The 
second and subsequent words of these mult i-word options are  called subnames . Most multi -word names 
are necessitated by FAME’s extensive graphics options, wh ich provid e detailed control over virtually 
every aspect of a grap h. 
For e xample, not only is there a LEGEND option (to determine whether a g raph legend appear s on a 
graph), but there are also LEGEND AREA, LEGEND BACKGROUND, LEGEND CONTENTS, LEGEND 
FRAME, and LEGEND  LINES options to contro l various characteristics of the  legend.  Consider the 
following options:  
LEGEND APPEAR ON  
LEGEND BACKGROUND  COLOR BLUE, APPEA R ON 
LEGEND AREA JUSTIFY LEFT, LOCATION BELOW  
LEGEND CONTENTS SYMBOL OFF, LINE OFF, DESCRIPTION O N 
In the f irst line, the option na me is the single word, LEGEND. I n the ne xt three lines, the option names 
consist of two words each, LEGEND BACKGROUND, LEGEND  AREA, and  LEGEND CONTENTS. The 
option modifiers are COLOR and APPEAR for the LEGEND BACKGROUND o ption; JUS TIFY and 
LOCATION for th e LEGEND AREA option; and SYMBOL , LINE, and DESCRIPTION for the LEGEND 
CONTENTS option.  
Option Modifiers  
Option modifiers spe cify a par ticular feature that is to be controlled. Option modifiers determine the effect 
of an o ption; for  example:  
 The APPEAR mod ifier of the LEGEND option deter mines wh ether a legend appears on a graph.  
 The COLOR option modifier in the  previous LEGEND B ACKGROUND option controls the color 
that appears behind the legend in a graph. The APPEAR modifie r controls  whether or not the 
back ground is colored at all.  
 The JU STIFY op tion modifier controls the justification of the legend lines and th e LOCATION 
modifie r controls  the position of the legend on the graph.  
 The SYMBOL, LINE, and DESCRIPTION option modi fiers cont rol the elements that ap pear in the 
legend.  
The exact ef fects of  the option modifiers are determined by their option settings; for example: ON, BLUE,  
LEFT, and  BELOW.

www.fisglobal.com  19  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Option Settings  
Option settings spell out the effect an option or an option mod ifier has on the results of a comm and. All 
options use settings an d take o ne of the following forms:  
 option setting  
 option modifier setting  
 option modifier set ting, modi fier setting  
 option modifier setting, modifier setting, modifier setting  
Examples of th e first fo rm, the simplest form, a re shown below:  
DECIMAL 2  
PREFIX "$" 
SCORE "=" 
Some options take a string of text that you define. You shou ld enclose a strin g within d ouble quotes (" "); 
FAME always uses a string exactly as you enter it.  
The second throu gh last fo rm of option modifiers m ay have one or more modifiers an d settin gs; for 
example:  
LEGEND APPEAR ON  
JUSTIFY COLUMN HEADING CENTER, CO NTENTS RIGHT  
LEGEND CONTENTS  SYMBOL ON, LINE OFF, DESCRIPTION ON  
If the modifier setting is  a boolean or logical va lue such as ON or OFF, you may o mit the modifier setting. 
FAME automatically assumes a positive or ON setti ng. For example, t he first a nd third LEGEND options 
listed above could have been issued a shorter way:  
LEGEND APPEA R 
LEGEND C ONTENTS SYMBOL, LINE OFF , DESCRIPTION  
Some options offer  default s and omissible settings; these are explained in the discussions of  the 
individual op tions.  
Specifying the Scope of Options  
Options can be set at four different levels: global , block , command -specific , and argument -specific. The 
effective scope of an optio n depends on the level at which it is specified.  
Global Options  
The highest level of option set ting is the global level. To set an option at this level, you issue the option as 
a sta nd-alone s tatement, similar to a c omm and. The option affects all c ommands that use it unless you 
change the setting by one of the following m ethods: 
 You re -specify the o ption at the global level.  
 You explicitly override the option at a lower level. This is  a tempora ry method.

www.fisglobal.com  20  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 You reset the  option to its default using the  RESET c ommand.  
Examples of global options appear below:  
DECIMAL 3  
PREFIX " $" 
LEGEND CONTENTS  SYMBOL ON , LINE OFF, DESCRIPTION ON  
PLOT #3 COLOR RED, STYLE SOLID, DESCRIPTION "Fitted Values"  
Block Opti ons 
The second highest level of option se tting is t he block level. To set an option at this level, you issue the 
option as a stand -alone s tatement b etween a BLOCK  and END B LOC K command pair.  
Options that you set globally before a BLOCK  statement remain in effect unless they are overridden at 
the block leve l (or at a lower level). Options set at the block level are global within the block. Wh en you 
terminate the block with th e END BLOCK  statement, the block  level o ptions are canceled; they revert to 
the settings that they had befo re you began the b lock. The BLOCK  and END BLOCK  command pair 
allow you to reset options without exiting and re -entering FAME.  
Hint If you issue the BLOC K command immediately upon en tering t he FAME environment, you can 
create discrete FAME sessions within a  single FAME sessi on. Later in the session, you can 
restore all the options you have used to their original values by enterin g the END BLOCK  
command.  Then, issue another BLOCK  comma nd to be gin another “session -within -a-session”.  
Blocks may be  nested so that one or more blocks are completely contained inside another. When blocks  
are neste d, options set at the in nermost level take precedence, j ust as b lock level options take priority 
over global options.  
Hint Make it a habit to use BLOCK  as the first command and END BLOCK  as the last comma nd of 
every input file that you wr ite (unless the express purpose of the i nput file is to change option 
settings). This is a good practice, b ecause you never k now when o r how an input file might be 
used, and by blocking it off, you can keep it from “steppi ng on the toes” of other input fil es or of 
your interactive sessio ns.

Any option that can be set at th e global l evel can be set at the b lock level, and vice versa.

Comm and-spec ific Options  
Options issued at the command -specific level are set a t the third highes t level; t hey are more localized 
than options set at the global or block level. Options set at th e command -specific level affect th e 
command as a whole, including all argu ments to that command.  
To set an option at this level, you enclose the option inside angle brac kets, < and > , and place it d irectly 
after the command name. Options set at the command -specific level r emain in effect fo r that com mand 
only. After the command is carried out, all options revert to their block or globa l settings . To set multiple 
option s at the command -specific levels , separa te them with semicolons within the angle brackets.  Here 
are some examples of command -specific options:  
OPEN <ACCE SS READ> CORP  
GRAPH <LEG END APPEAR ON> SALES, ASSETS  
REPORT <DEC IMAL 0; LPREFIX "$"> SALES, ASSETS  
Argument -specific Options  
Options issued at the argument -specific level are set at the lowest or most localized l evel. Argu ment-
specific options ov erride all other levels of optio ns. Thes e options affect one argument only.  
To set an option at this level,  you enclose the o ption insi de angle brackets, < and > , and plac e it directly 
after the command argument. To set multiple options a t the argument -specific leve ls, separate them with 
semicolons within the angle brackets . Here are som e exampl es of argument -specific options:  
OPEN CORP <ACCESS READ>, CORPPLAN  
REPORT SALES <LPRE FIX "$">, PERCENT <DECIMAL 1; SUFFIX "%">  
GRAPH SALES <PLOT COLOR RED>, ASSETS <PLOT COLOR GREEN>

With this REPORT c ommand, you may notice the use of the double ampersand (&&) for lin e continuation; th is FAME co nvention will be discussed in the next chapter. Limitations on Options Some options can not be set at all four option leve ls. Complete information about r estricti ons on each individual option is provided with the option’s documen tation in the C OMM AND REFERE NCE. In general, however, some options cannot be specified at the global or block level s. For exa mple, the KIND option af fects the OPEN and CREATE comman ds; this option must be specified at the command - specific or argument -speci fic level. Some op tions cann ot be set at the command -specific or argument -specific levels. For example, the YEAR, O BSERVED, B ASIS, FORECAST, TECHNIQU E, and OFFSET options, among oth ers, can not be set at the argument -specific level since they affect the ent ire output of a co mmand. Setting Options by Rows and Columns You might think of some of FAME’s options as being arr ayed in ro ws and columns. Entering options by rows or by columns g reatly r educes the effort required of you. This is particularly true of som e of the graphics options. I magine a single graph with four lines plotted on it. For each line, you could specify t he followi ng:  The color of the lin e (red, green, blue, or black).  The styl e for drawing each line (dashed, solid, or dotted).

 The plotting sy mbol for data valu es (“+”, “ *”, “x”, or “o”).  
 The points where the plotting symbol will be used (all, first, ends, or none).

PLOT #2 COLOR GREEN

The process of entering options this way is  unnecessarily ted ious and c an be shortened significantly by 
taking advantage of the special nature of the PLOT opt ion modifi ers. Every PLOT option m odifier consists 
of two words, a nd both are necessary to uniquely identify the line and attribute to be aff ected. For 
example , the word s #1 and COLOR  are needed to ensure that only the first line is red. We can see that 
the dimensio n number, #1, correspond s to the row number of the line,  and tha t COLOR  corresponds to a 
column of color attributes. The intersecti on of the row and the column  of the table specifies that FAME 
use red for the first line.  
Options with two -word mod ifiers can  be entered one row at a  time or one column at a time. T he optio ns to 
enter the plotting options one row at a time appear below:

The options to enter the pl otting options one  column at  a time appear below:  
PLOT COLOR #1 RED, #2 GREEN, #3 BLUE, #4 BLACK  
PLOT STYLE #1 SOLI D, #2 DASH ED, #3 DOTTED, #4 SOLID  
PLOT SYMBOL #1 "*", #2 "+", #3 " x", #4 " o" 
PLOT POINTS #1 ENDS, #2 ENDS, #3 ENDS, #4 ENDS

Either method con forms to a conveni ent way of  thinking about a graph. Sometimes you think of a graph 
one row at a time, for example,  “the firs t line should be a solid  red line with asterisks at the ends.” O n 
other occasions, you think of a graph by columns, for example, “a ll lines should ha ve symbols  at the 
ends.” Of course, you can enter some options as rows and others as columns if y ou want.  
FAME provides you with a convenient method for entering o ptions, whichever way you think. Throughout 
the volumes of the user guide, the documentation identifies  those options that can be entered by rows 
and columns.  
Constructing Option References  
Sometimes you need to check the se tting of an option. Perhaps you just wan t to recall the current default 
setting, or you are preparing a rep ort and can’t reme mber the n umber of decimal places you set for 
display.  
At other times, you may be building a syst em that te sts the value of an opti on and develops a report or 
analysis bas ed on the value of the option. FAME enables you to determine the se tting of any optio n with 
an option reference.  
To construct a simple option reference, enter an at -sign (@)  and the option name; for example:  
* DISPLAY @PREFIX, @DECIMAL 
 
@PREFIX 
 
 
@DECIMAL  
0 
 
* PREFIX "***"  
* DISPLAY @PREFIX, @UNDERLINE  
 
@PREFIX 
 
*** 
 
 
@UNDERLINE  
 
FALSE 
In the example s above, note that FAME shows the initial null setting o f PREFIX  by printing a blank line. 
Note also that all boolean (or binary) s ettings are repres ented as T RUE or FALSE, regardless of whether 
they are actually set as YES or NO, or ON or OFF. Y ou can sel ect a different display format for boolean 
values by usi ng the I MAGE BOOLEAN option, described in the chapter  FORMAT OUTPUT  (p. 200). 
To find out the setting of an option  of the option modifier setting  form, specify @option.modifier ; for 
example : 
* LEGEND APPEAR OFF  
* DISPLAY @LEGEND.APPE AR 
 
 
@LEGEND.A PPEAR

www.fisglobal.com  26  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 
FALSE 
 
You cannot reference an option without its modifier or modifiers; for example:  
* DISPLAY @LEG END 
 
Error: Option reference s must be fully qualified; f or example, @LEGEND.APPEAR  
 
Options that use multiple words must include all of  the words in the option  reference. If an option can be 
set by rows and columns, you must provide both a row an d a column  in the reference; the order  of the 
row or column specif ication does n’t matter. For example:  
* PLOT #1 COLOR RED, STYLE SOLID, DESCRIPT ION "Personal Data" 
* TYPE @PLOT.#1.COLOR  
RED 
 
* DISPLAY @PLOT.STYLE.#1, @PLOT.DESCRIPTION.#1  
 
@PLOT.STYLE.#1  
 
SOLID 
 
 
@PLOT.DESCRIPTION.#1  
 
Personal  Data 
If you omit a row, a c olumn, or a modifier, the option reference fails; for example:  
 
* DISPLAY @PLOT  
 
Error: Optio n referenc es must be fully qualified; for example, @PLOT.#1.SYMBOL

www.fisglobal.com  27 FAME C ONVENTIONS  
This chapte r explains  how you enter the FAME syst em to begin a FAME session a nd how you e nd a 
FAME session. It also introduces some convenient rules that yo u should know about usin g FAME:  
 How to abbreviate commands and options.  
 How to insert blank spaces in commands and option s.

Starting and Ending a FAME Session  
How you start FAME depends on the computer you use an d the way your company has i nstalled FAME.  
UNIX  
To start  FAME on a U NIX system, type $FAME/fame  at the operating system prompt.  
system prompt> $FAME/fame

Windows  
To start FAME on a pers onal computer running Wi ndows, start a Windows session and locate the FAME 
program group. Open the FAME program  group and  use the mouse to select and  start the FIS Market

In both UNIX and Windows, the asterisk (*) is t he FAME prompt. The asterisk indicates  that you can enter 
FAME options a nd com mands. The prompt appears when FAME expects a response from you.  
Ending a FAME Session  
If you are  at the basic FAME command level or in a block, you type EXIT to end your FAME se ssion:  
* EXIT 
If you ar e insi de a structured command (IF, GRAPH, LOOP, REPORT, or TRY), you type  CANCEL  to 
stop the structured  command, and then enter the EXIT  command. You’ll know when you’re inside a 
struc tured command, b ecause FAME changes th e prompt so that it includes the n ame of  the innermost 
structured command, as in the following session:  
* LOOP FOR TICKER IN CO MPANY.LIST  
LOOP* IF TICKER&EPS[ 09] LT TICKER&EPS[ 08]  
IF* CANCEL  
  All pending structured commands cancele d 
 
* EXIT 
FAME then re turns you to your system prompt or  your current windowing session, depending on your 
operating system.  
Notice that the prompt c hanged fro m an asterisk to LOOP*  after the LOOP command was initiated, and 
from LOOP*  to IF* after the IF c ommand was initiated. The CANCEL command canceled both s tructu red 
commands and “threw away” the work we had begun. Had we used th e CATCH command, ins tead, and 
supplied a file name, FAME would have saved the structured commands in that file.  This is what wo uld 
have happened:  
IF* CATCH MYLOOP  
  Current structured  command placed in the file: MYLOOP.INP  
Interrupting FAME  
In some circums tances, you may need  to interr upt a FAME session while a command is executing. This 
capability might be useful,  for example, if  during the execution of a complicated calculation, a me ssage 
from the computer system operator is displayed to warn you that the  system will be goin g down in a 
minute or two. There are several ways to interrupt a FAME session without waiti ng for a command  to 
finish. These ways  depend on your operating system:  
 On com puters running under the UNIX operating system, move the cursor to the shell window 
where you’re running FAME, hold down the CONTROL key and type the letter C and enter a 
carriag e return. This s equence aborts executi on of the command and cleans up an y loos e ends 
before returning you to the FAME command level.  
 On personal computers running Mi crosoft Wi ndows, move the cursor to the window where you’re 
running FAME, hold down the CON TROL key and pre ss the BREAK key. This  sequence aborts 
execution of the comman d and cleans up any loose ends before returning you to the FAME 
command level.

Abbrevia ting Comma nds and Options  
Most command and option names can be truncated to four or more le tters. In addi tion, most words in 
option modifiers and arguments can also be abbreviate d to four characters . The spel ling of the truncated 
segment must exactly match the spelling of the name, modifi er, or setting u p to the point of trun cation. 
Any abbreviation that is l egal f or an option is also legal for the corresponding option reference. The 
following comman ds, option s, and option references are all legal:  
DISPLAY SALES  
DISPLA SALES  
DISPL SALES  
DISP SALES  
 
LEGEND BACKGROUND COLOR BLUE , APPEAR ON  
LEGE BACK COLO BLUE, A PPE ON 
 
TYPE @LEGEND.BACKGROUND.COLOR, @LEGEND.BACKGROUND.APPEAR  
TYPE @LE GE.BACK.COLO, @LEGE. BACK.APPE  
Because of misspellings, the following abbreviated commands, options, and option references are illegal : 
REPT SALES        —Illegal “REPT”  
RPT SALES       —Illegal “RPT”  
 
LEGND BACKGROUND COLO BLUE   —Illegal “LEGND”  
LEGE BACKGR ND COLOR BLUE   —Illegal “BACKG RND” 
 
TYPE @LEGE.BACKGROUND.COLR   —Illegal “COLR”  
TYPE @LGND.BACK.COLO    —Illegal “LGND” 
Many com mand names, option nam es and subnames, modifiers and set tings can be truncated to fewer 
than four characters, provided that the t runcation is unique.  We refer to this as minimum unique 
abbreviation . Thus, the KEEP and KIND opt ions c an be abbreviated to KE and KI, respectively. Also, the 
GLNAME and GLFORMULA commands c an be abbr eviated to GLN and GLF, respectively. However, the 
abbreviations K and GL  are amb iguous; they can not be used. Additiona lly, the DATA command cannot 
be truncate d without becoming indistinguishable from the DATE option.  
The foll owing options and op tion refer ences demonstrate legal, minimum unique abbreviations:  
LABEL LINES RIGHT ORIENTAT ION STACKED  
LAB L R O S 
TYPE @LAB.L.R. O 
In this example, no subname, mod ifier, or setting requires more than one letter to be unique.  
LEGEND BACK GROUND COLOR GREEN, APPEAR ON  
LEG B C G, A ON  
DISPLAY @LEG.B.CO, @LEG.B.A  
BACKGROUND is the only second word be ginning with the  letter B that can fol low LEGEND. Therefore, 
all of the modifi ers and settings can be reduced to single letters, except ON, which  must be spelled out  
because i t is a reserved word.  
LEGEND CHARACTERS SIZE MEDIUM, FONT GOTHIC, COLOR BLUE  
LEG CH S M, F GO, C BLU 
DISPLAY @LEG.CH.S,  @LEG.CH.F, @LEG.CH.C

www.fisglobal.com  30  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
LEGEND CONTE NTS SYMBOL OFF, LINE OFF, DESCRIPTION ON  
LEG CO S OFF, L OFF, D ON  
DISPLAY @LEG.CO.S, @LEG.CO .L, @LEG.C O.D 
In the two previous sets of examples, two settings require more than one lett er to distinguis h them from 
other sett ings of the same modifier.  
In all of the se examples, you can see that three letters are sufficient to disti nguish the first wor d of the 
option names from other, similar first words of commands and options.  
Some special  FAME words cann ot be abbreviated . These words include the following:  
 Predefined values, suc h as ALL, AUTO , and NONE . 
 Operator names such as THEN , AND , and INTERSECT . 
 Names of basic F AME data types, such as STRING , NUMERI C, and NAMELIST . 
 In general, any o f the reserved words identified later in this guide.  
Although minimum uni que abbreviations ar e useful f or interactive use, you probably should not use 
abbreviations of less than four o r five character s in files that you sh are with other users or that may 
remain in service for years. There are two good reasons not to use the sho rtest possible abbre viations:  
 The FAME statements that you write may be unintelligible to anyone other than you . 
 Minimum unique  abbreviations are not  guaranteed. As we continue to dev elop a nd enhance 
FAME, we will add new commands and options. Thus, some a bbreviations may no longer be 
unique. For example, DI and DIS were once legal abbreviations of DISPLAY, but whe n the 
DISABLE IN TERRUPT option was add ed, DISP became the shortest legal  abbre viation of 
DISPLAY.  
You may append extra characters to complete com mand names without p roblem. Fo r example, if you 
believe that additional letters improve readability, the follow ing commands are  identical:  
REPORT SAL ES, ASSETS 
REPORTED SALES, ASSETS  
Howeve r, be sure not to misspell a command name by extending it; for exam ple: 
TYPE @DECIMAL  
 
TYPING @DE CIMAL    —Illegal spelling of “TYPE”  
TYPING  is spelled correctly in English, but it is incorrect in FAME because the fi nal E has been omitted 
from the co mplete  command name.  
As with command names, words in option names, modifi ers, and settings ca n be exten ded by appending 
extra letters to the complete word. For example, the three follo wing commands pr oduce identical result s: 
GRAPH <LEGEND APPEAR ON> SALES,  ASSETS 
GRAPH <LEGENDS APPEAR ON> SALES, ASSETS  
GRAPH <LEGEND APPEARING> SALES, ASSETS  
The op tions LEGE ND and LEGENDS are both legal. Also, the modifier APPEARING is legal since the 
base APPEAR is spe lled correctly. Again,  the argument ON is not required.  
Howeve r, the following option is illegal, because it misspells the name o f the OBSERVED optio n:

www.fisglobal.com  31  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
OBSERVATIONS END     —Illegal spelling of “OBSERVED”  
Throughout this guide, we use a vari ety of command a nd option abbreviation s to familiarize you with 
abbrevia tions.  In general, we do not abbreviate the first word of any command or option to fewer than  four 
characters. We use abbreviations of four or more characters for first words, and ofte n use abbreviati ons 
of fewer than four  characters for subsequent words i f we t hink that you should easily recognize the 
command or option.  
Includ ing Spaces in Comman ds and Opt ions 
FAME requires you to place at least one space or tab between any pair of wor ds or numbers in  
commands and options . However, you can add extra spaces between words. In  the following comma nds, 
the a sterisk prompts are included to emphasize the legal command and option spacing:  
* DISPLAY SALES - EXPENSES  
* DISPLAY      SALES   -    EXPENSES  
*    DISP LAY  SALES  /  EXPENSES  
*    DISPLAY SALES/EXPENSES  
You cannot place a sp ace within a command  or option  word, or within the name of a data object. The 
following commands are illegal : 
* DIS  PLAY SALES  - EXPENSES   —Illegal “DIS” and “PLAY”  
* DISPLAY SALES /  EX  PENSES  —Illegal “EX” and “PENSES”  
You can insert or omit spaces bef ore and after punctu ation mark s. The following commands are legal:  
DISPLAY SALES<PREFIX "$">, EXPENSES < DECIMA L 1> 
DISPLAY   <    DECIMAL   1   >  SA LES,EXPENSES  
DISPLAY<      DECIMAL  1>SALES<PREFIX "$">,EXPENSES  
DISPLAY<DECIMAL 1>SALES,EXPENSES,SALES/EXPE NSES < SUFFIX   "%"  > 
FAME pr eserves spaces within the literal strings that you enclose within double quotes. Put another way,  
FAME treats literal s trings (text within quotes) like e xact q uotations in ordinary writing. Thus, the two 
following examples are  not equivalent:  
PLOT #1 DESCR IPTION "Sales:Year -to-Date" 
PLOT #1 DESCRIPTION "Sales:  Year - to - Date" 
Throug hout this guide,  we’ll try to use spac ing that makes commands and option s more  readable. For 
example, we will indent commands and options that ar e issued within a bl ock, so th at the block is clearly 
set apart from the remainder of the session.  
Continuing a  Command or Opti on on More Than One Li ne 
FAME does not care about the le ngth o f individual commands and options, but you should keep your 
FAME  sessions, input files,  and proce dures readable. For example, a command that’s too long to fit on a 
single line of  your FAME sessi on may be made more re adable by breaking it into several  piece s. 
You can break a line into several pieces by using the FAME line continuation marker:  a double 
ampersand (&&)  followed by a carriage  return. That is, if you enter part of a command and then type &&

www.fisglobal.com  32  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
and hit  a carriage return, FAME promp ts you for the rest of the statement on the next line. On the second 
(and followi ng lines), FAME does not print the ast erisk (*) that it uses to prompt f or a n ew command or 
option. On the new line, you can type more of the sta tement, using additi onal line continuations, if 
necessary; for example:  
* REPORT <LPREFIX "$"> SALES, EXPENSES,  PERCENT <LPREFI X ""; && 
  DECIMAL 1; SUFFIX "%">  
You could have typed t his RE PORT command on a single line if you were using a 132 -column monito r, 
but the command i s too wide  to appear on a single line on an 80 -column monitor . To produce a command 
that fi ts in this guide , we used && to contin ue the command line. If we were no t conc erned about 
readability, we could have kept typing and allowed the line to wrap around or to trun cate (depending on 
our display  set-up). 
However, the double ampersands cannot app ear just anywher e. The ampersands cann ot divide a word in 
a command or a n opti on. Nor can they be used to divide a string of text. (Strings are s equences of 
characte rs, enclos ed in double quotes, and are meant to be taken literally. They are permissible se ttings 
to certai n commands and options .) For example, the following comm ands a nd options are legal:  
DISPLAY <DECIMAL 0> SALES, EXPENSES, SALES - EXPENSES, &&  
   SALES/EXPENSES  
TITLE TEXT "Sample Text for a Title", COLOR RED, FONT &&  
   GOTHIC 
DISPLAY <DECI MAL 1> SALES <PR EFIX "$">, EXPENSES, S ALES / && 
   EXPENSES <DECIMAL 0; SUFFIX "%"> 
With the above commands and options, the ampersands do not se parate any word or s tring of t ext. 
The following statements are all illegal:  
DISPLAY SALES <PREFIX "$">, EXPENS ES, SALES / EXPE NSES <DECI &&  
   MAL 0; SUFFIX "%">   —Illegal split opti on: “DECI” and “MAL”  
 
DISPLAY SALES, EXPENSES, SALES - EXPENSES, SALES/EX  && 
   PENSES    —Illegal spli t object: “EX” and “PENSES”  
 
TITLE COLOR RED, FONT GOTHIC, TEXT "This is a &&  
   String Literal"   —Illegal split in a l iteral string  
In general, the same  rules  that guide the insertion of extra spaces into commands and options  also guide 
the inse rtion of t he line continuation ampersands. If either a space or a pair of ampersands interr upts a 
word in a  command or an option,  the command or option fails. If y ou ins ert spaces into a string, its 
meaning is changed; if you insert amp ersands into a strin g, FAME re jects the string.  
Note that string expressions can be substituted for strings in many places in F AME. (Strings and stri ng 
expressions are more fully desc ribed later in this guide.) Thus, the unacceptable TITLE option, shown 
above, could be issued  correctly  as: 
TITLE COLOR RED, FONT GOTHIC, TEXT "This is a " + &&  
   "String Literal"

Entering More Than One Command or Option on a Line  
You can enter more than one co mmand or option on a single line. FAME recognizes the semicolon (;)  as 
a statement term inator and  treats text following a semicolon as a new command or option; for example : 
TITLE COLOR RED, FONT GOTHIC; GRAPH SALES, EXPENSES  
TITLE TEXT "Sample Title", COLOR BLUE ; GRAPH SALES, &&  
   EXPENSES, SALES/EXPENSES  
The second example combines more th an one statement  per line and line con tinuation.  
Earlier, you saw how yo u coul d use the semicolon to enter multiple options at the command -specif ic or 
argument -speci fic levels  of a command; for example:  
GRAPH <TITLE TEXT "Title Example", COLOR RED; LEGEND CONTENTS &&  
   DESCRIPTION ON> SALES, EXPENSES, SALES/EXPENSES  
While mul tiple commands on a single line allow you to create a very compact expres sion, multiple 
comma nds and op tions can also make it difficult to read and understand exactly what is going on.  
Note  You can pa ste and execute multip le lines of 4GL code statements th at are  copied from an 
application such as Notepad into the FAME 4GL clien t. 
Using Uppercase a nd Lowerca se Letters  
You can freely substitute uppercase and lowercase letters in FAME c omm ands and options;  cases hav e 
no effect on commands or options. FAME only distinguishes between uppercase and  lowercase lette rs 
inside a literal st ring. Therefore, the following are  all equivalent:  
REPORT <DECIMAL 1> SALES, EXPENSES  
report <decimal 1> sa les, expenses  
Report <Decimal 1> Sales, Expenses  
RePoRt <DeCimaL 1> SaLeS, eXpEnSeS  
REpoRT <DEciMAl 1> SAleS, e xpenses 
FAME tre ats literal strings (t ext inside quotation marks) very m uch li ke quotations in ordinary writing; they 
are presumed to represent e xactly the material being quot ed. Therefore, the following TITLE option 
specifies the exact combination of uppe rcase letters, l owercase letters, and spaces that appear in the 
graph or  repor t title:  
TITLE TEXT "Sales:  Year -to-Date" 
Except for literal strin gs, FAME reports opt ion settin gs fully spelled out in uppercase letters. For example:  
* TYPE @PLOT.#1.COLOR  
BLACK 
Throughout th is user guide, in orde r to help distinguish narrative te xt fro m command and option 
examples, we use uppercase letters to indicate  commands and option s, except for literal strings.

FAME offers you a number of conveni ent ways to simp lify the entry of comm ands and options:  
 If you know what  you w ant to do, but can’t remember quite how to do it, check the FAME O NLINE 
HELP for the in formation you need.  
 If you expect to repeat the same command sequences many times, use inpu t files to reduc e your 
effort.  
 If you want to keep a record of the state ments you enter during a FAME session, try the auditing 
capability.  
 Route  your analytical out put and re ports to files for storage.  
 Issue operating system commands from inside FAME.  
This chapter discus ses each of these feat ures under its own heading. A disc ussion  of the SUTIL and 
UTIL libraries of supported and unsupported utili ty software appears at the end  of this chapter.  
Obtaining Online Help  
FAME offers an online help feature that g ives you informa tion about FAME capabi lities. When the FAME 
ONLINE  HELP is act ivated, the FAME O NLINE  HELP file opens in a browser window. The he lp includes 
complete  lists of the FAME commands, functions, and options, and full documentation for each.  
Openi ng the Help File  
To open the FAME HELP  file from within your FAME sessio n, you  can simply type HELP at the FAME 
prompt:  
* HELP 
For users running FAM E on a personal c omputer un der Windows, the HELP file can also be opened by 
selecting the FAME HELP icon fro m the FAME progr am group.  
Help by Topi c 
The initial HELP window displays  a bas ic listing for FAME commands and options, FAME functions, C HLI 
functions, FAME text ed itor comma nds and options, FAME subroutines, and FAME utilities. In the FAME 
HELP window, t he topics are di splayed as underlined text.

Navigating Help  
The general topics  are displayed in the initial FAME HELP window. To select a topic f rom the list of FAME  
HELP, you  move the cursor over one of the topics and click the mouse. Selecting one of the  topics takes 
you to a more detailed l ist of the selected category via a  hyper text link.  
The selected subgroup for each general topic appears in  a subsequent window . A subgro up can be

Storing Stateme nts in an Input File  
After using the FAME system for a w hile, you may find that you repeat some operations many times. You 
may al so discover that you  need to f ine tune a series of commands and options until they produce exactly 
the right ou tput. In both of  these cases, you will  want to use an input file.  
An inp ut file is a text file that holds a list of FAME commands and options, ex actly as you would e nter 
them in a FAME session. To use an input file, you issue the INPUT command plus the nam e of the text 
file that holds the list  of commands and options. If you g ive th e file name the INP extension, you can omit 
the extension when you specify the file nam e; for exa mple: 
INPUT SALES  
This INPUT command causes the commands and options stored in th e file named SAL ES.INP to be 
executed.  
The chapter  INPUT FILES  (p. 250) describes the use and  control o f input files.  
A Special Input File: The Start -up File  
FAME makes  a special input file called a start-up file  available t o you.  The start -up file, always named 
fame.inp , contains a sequence of c omm ands and options that FAME automatically executes every time 
you enter the system.  
Typically, fame.inp  store s common option settings that you alwa ys specify when you use FAME.  
Automatic start-up files are also described in the chapter called  INPUT FILES  (p. 250). 
Displaying an Input File  
You can use the EXH IBIT command to displa y any text file, such as an input file. You can use the 
EXHIBIT command, for example, to list an input file  and review the comm ands and o ptions that you’ve 
stored in it. In the following example, the EXHIBIT command di splays the conte nts of the file named 
SUM MARY.INP :

Storing a FAME Session in an Audit File  
One very convenient way to build an i nput file is wit h an audit file . Audit  files store every statement issue d 
during your FAME session. To create an audit file named TRIAL.TXT, you enter the following sequence 
of statements:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT; ACCESS APPEND> TRIAL  
CHANNEL AUDIT TRIAL  
If, at an y time during yo ur FAME session, you w ant to stop adding statements to t he aud it file, you can 
turn off auditing by giving the following option:  
CHANNEL AUDIT NONE  
Auditing is  discussed in the chapters  INPUT FILES  (p. 250) and CHANNELING AND OUTPUT FILES  
(p. 274). 
Storing Resu lts in an Output File  
In the same way that input files store commands for input, output fil es store the out put from commands. 
Output files allow you to create a pe rmanen t record of your reports and analyses.  
To store output in a file, y ou direct the output  of your c ommands to a text file. Then, at your convenience, 
you can make a copy of the tex t file at a prin ter. 
To direct your ou tput to a file, you create a text file to store the output, and you instruct FAME which 
output to channel t o it. The simplest w ay to do t his is to use the OUTPUT command; for example:  
OUTPUT <ACCESS APPEND> SALESREP  
This OUTPUT comman d creates a file calle d SALESREP.TXT and directs all out put to  it. (FAME uses 
TXT as the default extension on most operating syst ems.) If the file al ready exis ts, FAME appends the 
output to it.  
Later, if you want to direct output to your FA ME session again , type the following c omm and:

OUTPUT TERMINAL  
FAME recog nizes several classes of output and allows you to control each class sepa rately with the 
CHAN NEL option . Redirection of output is discussed in greater detail in this guide in the  CHANNELING 
AND OUTPUT FILES  (p. 274). The chapter  TEXT FILES  (p. 242) provides more information about 
creating and us ing text files.  
Adding Comments  
Becaus e input files and procedures (a pr ocedur e is similar to an input file) may be shared by many users 
or may b e used for several y ears, it i s advisable to document these files to make their purposes as clear 
as possible. You can do this by adding comments to commands and options.  
Comments alw ays be gin with two hyphens ( --). When FAME sees double hyphens, it ignores any 
remaining text on the same line. C omments may occu r anywhere in a line; for example:  
* EXHIBIT FOREGRAPH.I NP 
 
OPEN <ACCESS READ> CORPHIST -- Open the corporate history data  
                            -- base for reading  
 
--The following graph compares actual sales and expenses to  
--last year's forecasts of sales and expenses  
 
PLOT DRAW #1 SOLID, #2 DASHED, #3  SOLID, #4 DASHED  
PLOT COLOR #1 BLACK, #2 BLACK, #3 RED, #4 RED  
GRAPH SAL ES, SALES.FORE, EXPE NSES, EXPE NSES.FORE  
The OPEN command and the following line illustrate the use of comments at the end of a command line. 
The pair  of lines preceding the PLOT and G RAPH c ommands show complete comment lines. Note the 
incorporation of blan k lines in the input  file. The se lines are ignored by FAME.  
Adding comment lines requires a little extra effort , but becomes ti me well spent as you r eturn to an old 
input file, proced ure, o r FAME session and reinterpret it.  
Issuing Operating System Command s 
You can issue oper ating syst em commands inside the FAME system. There are two ways to do this, by 
using an ex clamation point (!) or by using the SY STEM command.  
Using an Exclamation  Point  
The simplest way to enter an operating system command is to type a n exclamation point and follow  it with 
the command . For example , if you can’t remember the name o f an i nput file, you can type the following 
command in FAME to get a part ial listing of your file direc tory: 
 On a personal computer running Windows system:  
 !DIR *.INP

www.fisglobal.com  38  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 On a  UNIX syste m: 
 !ls -l 
 
As soon as the operating system completes the system comman d, con trol returns to FAME.  
To modify an input file, you can type the fol lowing: 
 On a persona l computer  running Windows:  
 !NOTEPAD SALES.INP  
 On a UNIX system:  
 !vi sales.inp  
When you f inish using the system editor and exit  from it, you are returned to the FAME s ystem.  
Using the SYSTEM Command  
Another way to issue an operating s ystem command is to enter the SYSTEM command and follow it by 
the command in quotes; for example:  
SYSTEM "EDIT SALES.INP"  
The S YSTEM command increase s the amount that you must type by  sever al additional characters and 
the quotation marks. However, FAME eva luates the command s tring ente red with the SYSTEM command 
before it passes the command to the operating system.  This means that  you can supply a comp lex string 
expression as the argum ent, t hereby making it possible for you to use dynamic operating system 
comm ands in procedure s. 
For mor e information about the SYSTEM command, see the FAME S YSTEM  BUILDING  USER GUIDE
