FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Using the UTIL an d SUTIL Libraries  
In addition to the FAME features descr ibed i n the rest of this chapter, the FAME system offers you two 
special libraries of utiliti es:  UTIL and SUTIL. These libraries are outlined below:  
 The UTIL library consists of proce dures, or genera l purpose utilities, w hich have been written and 
stored for yo u to study and use. Procedures in the UTIL library are unsupported.  That is, you are 
free to chan ge the code for the procedures in the UTIL library and generate your own utilitie s. 
Two of the pr ocedures in the UTIL l ibrary are the OPTION procedure (w hich i mproves on an 
option reference by displaying all of an option’s set tings) and the STATU S procedur e (which 
displays the frequency, ranges, database information, and channeling inf ormation for you r current 
FAME session ). 
New procedures may be added to the UT IL library at any time.  
 The SUTIL library consists of procedures th at are written and s tored for you to use in advanced 
applications. Procedures in the SUTIL library are supporte d. You cannot ch ange the code for the 
procedures in the SUTIL library an d gene rate your own utilities.  
For information about the UTIL and SUTIL l ibraries on your sys tem, conta ct your system 
administrator.

www.fisglobal.com  40 INTRODUCTION TO DATABASES  
FAME stores data in spe cially formatted  FAME databases constr ucted to ensure rapid retrieval of  data.  
For all practical purposes, the size of a FAME database is limited  only by the amount of compute r disk 
storage available to you on one logical device. Databases expand dynamical ly as you add da ta. When 
you delete da ta from a database, the disk space  can b e reused by new data. The formatting of data is 
entirely internal t o FAME so that you c an store a nd retrieve data easily.  
This chapter describes:  
 How to create a database.  
 How to  open an existin g database.  
 How to con trol access to a database.  
 How to close a database.  
Many of the topics in this chapter are discussed in mor e detail in the chap ter MORE ABOUT 
DATABASES  (p. 222). 
Opening a Database  
Soon after you begin most FAME sessio ns, yo u use the OPEN command to open some existing 
databases. At its simp lest, the OPEN comma nd specifi es a name. FAME adds the extension DB to the 
name, then opens the file with that name as a databa se; for example:  
OPEN HOUSE 
OPEN CORP, DIV4  
The first co mmand opens the file HOUSE.DB. During your session, you’ll refer to it by  the name HOUSE. 
The second co mmand opens the databases CORP.DB and DIV4.DB. During your FAME session, you will  
use the names C ORP and DIV4, respecti vely, to refer to these databases.  
If you supply an extension with the name when you open a database, you m ust use both the nam e and 
the extension when you refer to the database. For example:  
OPEN HOUSE.DB  
opens the fi le HOUSE.DB. Dur ing your session, you’ ll call the database by the name H OUSE.D B. 
Another method of opening a database allows you to simplify the name you’ll use for the databa se. For 
example:  
OPEN OPEXOC83 AS A

www.fisglobal.com  41  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Since you did not provide an extension with t he name (OPEXOC8 3), FAME automatically  adds the 
extension DB to the name . FAME  opens the file OPEXOC83.DB, but assigns it the name A. You will re fer 
to this database  as A duri ng your FAME session.  
If a system file name do es not use the DB extension, you must supply the extension when you use the 
OPEN command. If you want, you can use an AS clause, as shown above, to supply the databa se name 
that you’ll use in FAME; for example:  
OPEN HOUSE.ABC AS HOUSE  
Closing a Database  
When you have fini shed using a database,  it’s a good idea to close it, esp eciall y if it has been opened for 
updating. Otherwise, you might lose tra ck of which database s you have  open and issue a command that 
deletes or otherwise alters data objects stored in  the database.  
There are two ways to c lose a database: EXIT and CLOSE.  
If you have completed your FAME session, you can use the EXIT command to e nd the session. EXIT  
closes al l open databases.  
If you plan to continue yo ur FAME session,  you can use the CLOSE  command. The CLOSE command 
takes the ke yword ALL, or one or more databases as its arguments. If you specif y ALL, FAME closes 
every datab ase and text file you have opened.  
You can use the @OPEN.DB system variable to ch eck what databas es you have open; for example : 
 
* CLOSE CORP, HOUSE  
 
Error: HOUSE is not an open channel  
 
* DISPLAY @OPEN.DB  
 
@OPEN.DB 
 
CORP, MYSALES 
 
 
* CLOSE ALL  
* DISPLAY @OPEN.DB  
 
@OPEN.DB  
Creating a Database  
You create  and open a FAME  database with the CRE ATE command. The name that you giv e the 
database must conform to these rules:  
 A database name must begin wi th a letter, a dolla r sign ($) , or a percent sign (%).

www.fisglobal.com  42  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 A database name may contain letters, numbers, dollar sig ns ($), percent signs (%), hatch signs  
(#), at-signs (@), underscores (_ ), and  dots (.).  
The following are valid database names: ECON, SALES, PLA N90, PLAN_FOR_92, %P ROF@85, 
BIG$YEAR.  
The database name must also conform to the limits imposed by your operati ng system. Some operating 
systems enfo rce an upper limit of eight charac ters f or the database name.  
The following CREATE commands are legal:  
CREATE HOUSE 
CREATE CORP  
CREATE SA LES, DIV4  
These three commands create and open four databases. FAME adds the exte nsion DB to thes e names 
and creates th e databases HOUSE.DB, CORP.DB, SAL ES.DB,  and DIV4.DB. During your FAME 
session, you’ll call them HOUSE, COR P, SALES, and DIV4.  
Most datab ase creations are as straight -forward as these examples. Suppose, though, that yo u don’t 
want you r databases to use the  DB extension. Instead, you want t hem to  use your initials: SBM. The first 
example then becomes:  
CREATE HOU SE.SBM 
This command creates th e database file HOUSE.SBM and assigns it the database label (or channel 
name ) HOU SE.SBM.  
If you want to use a shorte r name  for the database during your FAME session, use an AS clause to 
supply a name. For exam ple, to cr eate the database HOUSE.SBM and call it A1, use the command:  
CREATE HOUSE.SBM AS A1 
We will discu ss channels more thoro ughly in the  chapter  MORE ABOUT DATABASES  (p. 222). 
The WORK Data base 
So far, we have not mentioned the WORK database. FAME automatically creates and opens the WO RK 
database at the beg inning of every FAME session; FAME  also deletes it at the end of every session. If 
you don’t open a databas e before you begin u sing the s ystem, FAME stores all of your results in the 
WORK database. When you exit FAME, all of your work  is lost unless you sp ecifically save it during the 
session. 
The WORK database is especially useful when you need a quick answer to a question about FAME’s 
behavior and you don’t want to risk your data. You can get into FAME and start creat ing data objects  to 
test your ideas. W hen you finish your tests and exit  from FAME, FAME cleans up after you. If you take 
advantage of the WORK d atabase, your comput er account  won’t get cluttered with test databases, and 
your production databases won’t be littered with us eless data objects.  
The WORK database is always  open whe n you are in FAME. And, unless you use the SEARCH 
command to change the o rder that FAME uses when it se arches through databases for data objects, 
WORK is always searched first. For mor e information on  the WORK database and  the SEARCH 
command, see the chapt er MORE ABOUT DATABASES  (p. 222).

www.fisglobal.com  43  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Controlling Access to a Database  
Usually you can update, delete, and overwrite  data in an exis ting database. At othe r times, however, you 
may only wan t or b e permitted to read data in a database. An example of this kind of “read only” database  
might be a research database that your entire company regularly uses. FAME gives you the A CCESS 
option as a command -specific or argument -specific modifier to the OPEN c ommand to control the way 
you open databases.  
Any of five methods  of access  may be chosen for opening databases: UPDATE, READ, CREATE, 
OVERWRITE, or SHARED.  
Opening a Datab ase for Updating  
By default, FAME allows you to open a database so tha t you can both read it and wri te to it. All of the 
following commands are equivalent:  
OPEN CORP  
OPEN <ACCESS UP DATE> CORP  
OPEN CORP <ACCESS UPDATE>  
If you do not have permission to op en a d atabase with ACCESS UPDATE, FAME displays an error 
message.  
You sho uld also be aware of  operating  system security. Make sure that the ACCESS option specification 
does not conflic t with any opera ting system access cod es for a database. For example, if  a dat abase has 
been protected by the operating system so that you can re ad it but not write to it, ACC ESS UPDATE fails.  
Opening a Database for Reading  
The most freq uently used access method, apart f rom UP DATE, is READ. Once you open a database for 
reading, you can retrie ve its contents, but  you canno t make any changes; for example:  
* OPEN <ACCESS READ> CORP  
* UPDATE SALES  
 
Error: Cannot write to  read-only database ch annel CORP 
ACCESS READ allows seve ral us ers to use a database at the same time. If another user opens a 
database with ACCESS RE AD, then y ou and other users can also open it for reading only. By contrast, if 
one user op ens a database w ith ACCESS UPDATE, the n no other user can gain access to  it. 
Once you’ve opened a database, the access mode cannot be changed. Fo r example, if you op en a 
datab ase with ACCESS READ, but then realize that you must update it, you must close it  with the 
CLOSE command, and then reop en it with the proper access mode.  
Openi ng a Database for Sharing  
In addition to ACCESS READ, which allows many readers for a database, a single user can also open 
the databas e ACCESS SHARED. When one user opens a database ACCESS S HARED,  he or she can 
update data in the database while many other users c ontinue to read the data.

www.fisglobal.com  44  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
This access method is popular since it allows a system administrator or database mana ger to add new 
data to a database whil e other users are still using the databa se. Because special situations can arise 
with this access method, m ost FAME application s only all ow a few users to access a database SHARED. 
The FAME C OMMAND  REFERENCE  discusses the implications  of ACCESS SHARED more  thoroughly.  
Creating and Opening a New Database  
ACCESS CREATE caus es the OPE N command to function exactly like the CREATE command. The 
following commands are  equivalent:  
CREATE MYSALES  
OPEN <ACCE SS CREATE> MYSALES  
Creating a New Databa se, Even If It Already Exists  
If you want to create a new database, regardless of the existence of another file wit h the same name,  you 
can automatically  delete the old file by specifying  ACCES S OVERWRITE; for example:  
OPEN <ACCESS OVERWRITE> MYSALES  
ACCESS OV ERW RITE creates a ne w version of the file. On most operating systems, it also deletes the 
old version. The ACCE SS option cannot  be used with the CREA TE command, so, if you want to ove rwrite  
an old database, you must use OPEN with <ACCESS OVER>.

www.fisglobal.com  45 DATA AND  WILDCARDING  
FAME’s great powe r lies in its use of five major classes of data objects, the variety of data that  it handles, 
and the simple naming con ventions that the system uses.  
The five classes of data objects are listed below:  
 Scalars  
 Series  
 Formulas  
 Global Names  
 Global F ormulas  
The types of data that FAME handles are listed below:  
 Numeric and precision  
 Text st rings  
 Boolean da ta 
 Date data  
 Namelists  
This section describes three of t he fiv e classes of data objects: scalars, series, and formulas. The other  
two classes of data  objects, global names and global formulas, are beyond the scope of a FAME 
introductory gui de. Global names  and global formulas  are discussed in FAME C OMMAND  REFER ENCE  
under the GLNAME and GLFORMULA commands. This section discusses all the types of data an d 
introduc es the concept of wildcarding.  
Three Classes of Data Objects  
We use the term data object  to refer  to any kind of data s tored in a FAME database. There ar e five  
specific classes of FAME data objects: scalars , series , formulas , global names , and global formu las. 
Scalars , series , and formulas  are described below.  
Scalars  
A scalar stores a  single data val ue; for example, look at the following scalars and their  value s: 
INCHES_PER_METER   39.37

www.fisglobal.com  46  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
MONTHS_PER_YEAR   12 
TAX_RATE     48% 
In each of these example s, the dat a object holds a single value. The first two examples will never change 
their val ue; there will a lways be 39.37 inches in a meter, and 12 months in a yea r. The  last scalar, 
TAX_RATE, can be considered permanent; the tax rate d oes not usually chan ge for a p rofitable 
company, so a scalar is the natural way to store the data value.  
Series  
While scalars s tore single data value s, series store multiple data valu es. Us ually, series hold data that 
you’ve collected at regular intervals,  such as every day o r every in ning. Furthermore, series can be 
divided into two types: time series and case ser ies. 
Time Series  
Series indexed by dat e are called time series. (An index is simply the method by which we arrange the 
data and then refer to it. ) For example, a tim e series m ight contain data for January, February, March, 
and April of 2009. Here are some examples of time  series:  
Quarterly ASS ETS 
Monthly SALES  
Weekly (Friday) MONEY_STOCK 
Business Day DOW_JONES  
Daily TEMPERATURE  
These time series ho ld the following dat a: assets that you recorded every quarter, sales every month, 
money stock prices on Friday of every week, D ow-Jones indexes every  business day (Monday through 
Friday), a nd temperatures every day (Sunday through Saturday). We’ll describe  some aspects of tim e 
series m ore thoroughly in the chapter  FREQ UENCIES, DATES, AND CASES  (p. 61). 
Case Series  
Series indexed by case number are called case series.  (Again, the index  is simply t he method by which 
we arrange and refer to the data.) A case series might refer t o the first, sec ond, and third occurre nces of 
an event. The following ca se ser ies give you more examples to think about:  
POPULATION_BY_STATE  
SALES_BY_DIVISION  
RUNS_PER_INNING  
The data listed in the above case series covers at least two different ideas:  
 The first two examp les might be cross -sections of several time series. For exampl e, 
POPULATION_BY_STATE might store the results of the 1980 census. The population of ea ch 
state, individually, could be treated as a time series, but you are probably more intere sted in the 
current population than in  historical figures.  
 The last exam ple, R UNS_PER_INNING, is data collected over irregular intervals of time.  The 
second inning a lways foll ows the first, but is seldom of equal length. Even the number of innings 
in a gam e is not fixed. Record high water leve ls and acquisitions of new compani es are  other 
examples of this kind of case series; their values are separ ated in time, but by  varying i ntervals.

www.fisglobal.com  47  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
As you begin to use FAME, you’ll discover that it is sometimes easier t o use a case ser ies than a time 
series . 
Formulas  
While scalars and serie s stor e data values, formulas store mathematical relationships among seri es and 
scalars (and other form ulas); for example:  
PROFIT     Sales - Expenses  
INCOME_TAX    Tax_Rate * Profit  
CURRENT_RATIO    Current_Assets / Current _Liabs 
RETURN_ON_EQUITY   Net_Inc - PF_Div / AVE (Equity)  
In these examples, the three formulas named PROFIT , CURRENT_RATIO, and  RETURN_ON _EQUITY 
combine time series; the result is another time series. The second exampl e (INCOME_TAX) c ombines a 
scalar (TAX_ RATE) and a time series; the resul t is a  time series. The fourth example also illustrates the 
use of AVE, o ne of FAME’s many functions . 
FAME does not evaluate a formula until it actually uses it. That is, FAME stores a  formula as an 
expression that combine s data objects and constants; FAME  does not store the results of the expression 
as a series or a scalar.  
You can even create a formula th at combines data objects that you haven’t created yet. FAME doesn’t 
care since it  doesn’t attempt  to evaluate the formu la until you use it.  
Therefore, fo rmulas  are dynamic . As the values of the component data objects change, t he results of the 
formulas cha nge. 
Types of Data  
So far, all of the data objects we’ve used have stored numeric  values. However , other kinds of data can 
be stored as series and scalar s and can be combined by formulas. In fact, FAME recognizes six kinds of 
data: 
 Numeric data, such as 10 0, -99.3, and 1234.56.  
 Precision data, such as 1234567.89012 and 9.8765432123  
 Text strings, such as “Economics Division ,” “Figure 8.7,” and “Net wt. in l bs.” 
 Boolean values, such as TRUE or FALSE.  
 Dates, such as 2009, 09Q4, Ma y08, 25Apr08, and 09 :2. 
 Sets o f names, called namelists , such as {NY, LA, CHI}, {SALES, EXPENSES, PROFITS}, and  
{BUDGET, PROJEC TED, ACTUAL}.  
These si x types of data are discussed in m ore de tail below.  
Numeric and Precision Data  
FAME stores numeric data as either numeric or pr ecision va lues:

www.fisglobal.com  48  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 Numeric objects can hold values with up to seven significant places; for ex ample, 1,234,567  or 
1.234567.  
 Precisio n objects can hold values with up to fifteen significant places; for example, 
123,456,789,012,345, 222,333, 444.55, or 12.345678 901234. FA ME stores the global constant PI 
as the precision value 3.141592653589793.  
The nu mber of signific ant places for both nu meric and precision data depend on  the c omputer operating 
system that you use.  
FAME allows you to use a sho rthand notation to r epresent a ny numeric or precision constant. Several 
symbols are recognized as having specia l significance w hen they are appended to numbers:  
 When you append the le tter K to a number, it means that the number is expressed in thousands. 
Thus, 12K is equivale nt to 1200 0, and 65.536K is equivalent to 65536.  
 When you append a percent sign (%) to a nu mber, it means t hat the number is divi ded by 100.  
For example, 82.3% is equiva lent to 0.823, and . 05% is equ ivalent to 0.0005.  
 With numeric data, when you append the letter E and an integer  to a number, it  indicates 
multiplicat ion by 10 raised to the power spec ified.  For example, 1.7E6 is 1700000, and 1.7E -6 is 
0.0000017.  
With preci sion data, when you append the  letter D and an integer to a number, it indicates 
multiplication by 10 raised to  the power speci fied. For example, 2.3 D12 is 2,300,000,000,000, 
and 2.3D -12 is  0.0000000000023.  
 When you append the letters DG to a number, FAME treats the number as  an angle expressed in 
degrees. For example, 30DG is equivalent to 0.5236 radians.  
 Do not c ombine these spe cial symbols or use a decimal point after the letter D or E. FAME does 
not accept any of the following:  
    22.3KK —Illegal 
    12.3E-2% —Illegal 
    99.2D1K —Illegal 
    84.3%%% —Illegal 
    1.4E10.9  —Illegal 
    9.9D10.3  —Illegal 
    .3KDG  —Illegal 
Text Strings  
Usually, you enclose a text string within doubl e quot es when you enter it; for example, “This is a text 
string.”  
You may  find that you need to use dou ble quotes within a string. In order to do this, enter two double 
quotes wherever  the quotes appe ar in the string.   Consider the following examples:  
 
 He said it  was his “best” effo rt 
 She sa id “Hello”  
  “Good afternoon”  
Enter the above text as text strings in the followi ng way:  
"He said  it was his ""best"" e ffort" 
"She said ""Hello"""

www.fisglobal.com  49  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
"""Good afternoon"""  
While all of these examples of strings use double quotes, we’ll eventually int roduce a f ew cases where 
you do not have to enter the quotes because the context requires y ou to enter a st ring. 
Boolean Data  
Boolean val ues ar e also referred to as logical values. Boolean values can be either positive (TRUE, YES,  
or ON) or  negative (FALSE, NO, or OFF). Boolean values do not use quotation marks.  
Date Da ta 
You can store  a date (such as 4Apr0 8 or Dec09) as a series or a scala r. You  can also generate a date 
with a formula or expression. We’ll discu ss dates more thorou ghly in th e chapter  FREQ UENCIES, 
DATES, AND CASES  (p. 61). 
Namelists  
Namelists are special sets o f data object names. Whenever FAME expects a list of names separate d by 
commas, you can  enter a n amelist. FAME expands the namelist to act on the list of names stored in the 
name list; for exampl e, the outputs of the sequences of commands in both the follow ing examples are 
equivalent:  
Example 1  
REPORT SALES, EXPENSES, PROF ITS, TAXES, TOTAL_RE VENUE, INV ESTMENT 
GRAPH SALES, EXPENSES, PROFITS, TAXES, TOTAL_REVENUE, INVESTMENT  
UPDATE S ALES, EXPENSES, PROFITS, TAXES, TOTAL_ REVENUE, INVESTMENT  
or 
Example 2  
MYLIST = {SALES, EXPENSES, PROFITS, TAXES, TOTAL_REVENUE, &&  
   INVESTMENT } 
REPORT MYLIST  
GRAPH MYLIST  
UPDATE MYLIST  
After you identify the names in MYLIST  the first time, it becomes mu ch easier to wor k with the namelist 
than to enter the individual names a gain a nd again when you want to use them. (We’ll discuss the 
creation of namelists in the cha pter DATA OBJECTS  (p. 79). 
FAME req uires namelists to be of the scalar data class; you cann ot cre ate a series of namelists.  
Each name in a namelist must be a valid FAM E name. However, the names do not need to refer to 
existing data objects. A namelist may even be empty.  
Hint Certain command s can use namelists as  a convenient shorthand. For examp le, if you want to 
use DISPLAY, SUMMARIZE, or WHATS on twelve different d ata objects, the sim plest 
approach would be the following:  
o Store the data object names in a namelist scalar.

www.fisglobal.com  50  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
o Use the namelist i n your DISPLAY, SUMMAR IZE, and WHATS commands instead of  the 
individual names.  
FAME automatically replaces the namelist scalar wi th the list of names  and then performs the 
operation on the specified names.  
Commands that do not allow a list of names can sti ll be executed one nam e at a time inside a namelist 
loop; for example, consider the structured command LOOP FOR COMPANIES IN MY_L IST. This 
capability  is discus sed in the FAME S YSTEM  BUILDING  USER GUIDE. 
Namelist scalars are always expanded in a context whe re FAME allows a list of names. If you wish to 
avoid the  autom atic expansion of a namelist, preface its name with an exclamation point (!); for examp le: 
DISPLAY !MYLIST 
This com mand displays the name list {SALES, EXPENSES, PROFITS, TO T_REVE NUE}. However, the 
following command  
DISPLAY MYLIST  
is equivalent t o: 
DISPLAY SALES, EX PENSES, PR OFITS, TOT_REVENUE  
Naming Data Objects  
Using FAME, you can create an almost unlim ited variety of names for data objects . You must observe a 
few rules, an d you may not use a few names because they are reserved for use by FAME.  
Rules for Names  
The rules for data object names appear below:  
 Data object names may be from 1 to 64 characters long for version  3 databases and 242 
characters for version 4 databases ; for example, X is a valid name, and so is 
ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZABCD EFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWX YZABCDEFGH IJ. 
Note  See the latest edition of the FAME O NLINE  HELP for more information abou t version 3 and 
version 4 databases.  
 Data object names must begin with a  letter (A to Z), a dollar sign ($), or a percent sign (%); for 
example, ASERIES , $BSERIES , or %CSERIES . 
 Data object names may contain letters (A to Z), digits (0 to 9), dollar signs ( $), percent sign s (%), 
hatch signs (#) , at-signs (@), underscores (_), a nd dot s (.); for example, A333 , A$444 , A%555 , 
A#666,  A@777 , A_888 , and A.999. 
With these rule s in mind,  we recommend that you follow the naming conventions that we use in most of 
our e xample FAME sess ions. First, use the u nderscore character to improve the  reada bility of multi -word 
names; for example:  
HOUSING_STARTS  
PARTS_PER_H OUR 
NET_SALES

www.fisglobal.com  51  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
NEW_YORK_CITY 
Second, use the dot to separate parts of names that represent different entities or  categories; for  
example:  
SALES.NEW_YO RK 
SALES.CHICAGO  
EXPENSES.NEW_YORK  
EXPENSES.CHICAGO  
You will eventually discover a number of uses for the “ dot separator” if yo u use it c onsistently. The GLUE 
character, described next, is one popular way to use the se parator.  
Gluing Names Together  
The GLU E option allows you to specify the  chara cter that “glues” name fragments together to form a new 
name. After  you specify a chara cter as th e glue character, whenever FAME finds an ampersand (&)  in a 
name , it inserts the glue character to concatenate a new name; for example:  
GLUE "." 
DISPLAY NEW_ YORK&SALES  
These two statements produce the same result as the single statement DISPLAY NEW _YORK.SALES . 
If you follow consistent rules for naming your data objects , you can use the GLUE operator to save you 
time and effort of typing. Fo r example, suppose y our time s eries all have names of the form city.item . You 
can store the city names in one n amelist, the ite m names in another nam elist, and use the CROSSLIST 
funct ion to  generate all possible combinations of the names. The CROSSLIST fun ction creates names by 
taking one name from each namelist and concatenating them using the glue character. For example, the 
two following sequences o f statements are equivalent:  
GLUE "." 
SCALAR CITIES:NAMELIST = {NY, CHICAGO, DENVER, LA}  
SCALAR ITEMS:NAMEL IST = {SALES, EXPENS ES, PERCEN TAGE} 
DISPLAY CROSSLIST (CITIES, ITEMS)  
or 
DISPLAY NY.SALES, NY.EXPENSES, NY.PERC ENTAGE, &&  
CHICAGO.SALES, CHICAGO.EXPE NSES, CHICAGO.PERCENTAGE, &&  
DENVER.SALES, DENVER.EXPENSES, DENVER.PERCENTAGE, &&  
LA.SALES, LA.EXPENSES, LA .PERCENTAGE  
We’ll di scuss the SCALAR command and the CROSSLIST function later in this guide. But for now, you 
can see that both  sequences of statemen ts take four lines, but the first set of  statements is shorter and 
involves less repetition than the second  set of statements. The nameli sts CITIES and ITEMS can also be 
used with other commands to save considerable ti me.

Specifying a Database and a Data Object  
You may use a single name (s uch as SALES) to store  different data in different datab ases ( such as the 
CHICAGO database, the NY database, and the NATIONAL dat abase). In these cas es, you ca n identify 
both the data object and the database from which you want to retrieve the object.

www.fisglobal.com  57  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
To do this, specify the da tabase, an apostrophe (') , and the name of the dat a object; for example:  
DISPLAY CHICAGO'SALES, NY'SALES  
UPDATE CHICAGO'SALES, NATI ONAL'SALES  
GRAPH NY'SALES  
Without the database specification, the comman d DISP LAY SALES  simply retrieves the first data object 
named SALES that F AME  finds. FAME uses  the curre nt search order  to determine the sequence to use 
in searching through the open da tabases. By defa ult, databases are add ed to the search list in the order  
that they are opened, so that the most recently opened database is the l ast one in the searc h list. Fo r 
more information on the search list and how to change it, see the  chapter MORE ABOUT DATABASES  
(p. 222). 
Specifying Wildcards  
Namelists give you the abi lity to store lists of names i n a scalar. Wildcarding  allows you to call lists of 
names that meet criteria you specify.  
Wildcar ding in FAME works jus t like wildcards in many card game s. For  example, in some card games, 
the joker is wild and can represent a ny card that you cho ose to com plete your hand. In FAME, the caret 
(^) and the question mark ( ?) are wild and can represent, respectively , either a single ch aracter in  a data 
object name or any group of characters in a data object name.  
For the wil dcarding example s that follow, suppose  that you have a small database co ntaini ng these 
series:  
ATLANTA.EXP.06         CHICAGO.SALES.08       NEW_ YORK.SALES.09  
ATLANTA.EXP.07         CHICAGO.SALES.09       SALES.TOT     
ATLANTA.EXP.08         EXP.TOT                SALES.07      
ATLANTA.EXP.09         EXP.07                 SAL ES.07     
ATLANTA.SALES.06       EXP.08                 SALES.08       
ATLANTA.SALES.07       EXP.09                 SALES.09       
ATLANTA.SALES.08       EXP.00                 SAN_FR AN.EXP.06  
ATLANTA.SALES.09       NEW_Y ORK.EXP.07        SAN_FRAN.EXP.07  
CHICAGO.EXP.06         NEW_YORK.EXP.08        SAN_FRAN.EXP.08  
CHICAGO.EXP .07         NEW_YORK .EXP.09        SAN_FRAN.EXP.09  
CHICAGO.EXP.08         NEW_YORK.EXP.00        SAN_FRAN.SALES .06 
CHICAGO.EXP. 09         NEW_YORK.SA LES.06      SAN_FRAN.SALES.07  
CHICAGO.SALES.06       NEW_YORK.SALES.07      SAN_FRAN.SALES.08  
CHICAGO.SALES .07       NEW_YORK.S ALES.08      SAN_FRAN.SALES.09  
The caret (^) represents any one character in a wildcard spe cification. The command  
DISPLAY SALES. 0^ 
is equivalent to  
DISPLAY SALES .06, SALES.07, SALES.08  
The question mark (?) represents any group of cha racters in a wildcar d specific ation. The question mark 
may even represent no characters. The command  
DISPLAY ?S ALES.07

data objects appear in alphab etical order.

In the special case where yo u want to find every  occurrenc e of one particular name, preface the name 
with two question marks (??) . FAME wi ll the n match exactly that name. For example, if you want to find 
SALES i n every database, bu t not SALE S06 or XSALES, use the wildcard specification ??SALES.  
In addition to the general  wildcarding des cribed above, two spec ial options allow you to limit wil dcardi ng 
to one database or to specify the kinds of objects you want to r etrieve with the wil dcard.  
Limiting a Specification to One Database  
Since you may use a single name to store di fferent data obj ects in different data bases, the MATCH option 
allows wil dcardi ng to retrieve objects from as many or as few databases as you want . 
If you specify MAT CH FIRST, for each name that matches the wildcard specification, FAME retrieves only 
the fi rst occurrence. For example, if the se ries SALES.06 can be found in each  of six open databases, the 
following sequence  
MATCH FIRST  
DISPLAY SALES?  
displays only the f irst versi on of SALES.06 that it encounters. Of course, other matches to the wildcard 
speci fication are als o displayed.  
The defau lt option setting is MATCH AUTO . When FA ME is simply retrieving data, as for a DISPLAY, 
GRAPH, or REPORT co mma nd, it finds ever y occurren ce of each match to a wildcard specification. If, 
however, you attempt to create,  overwrite, or c hange a data object wi th a wildcard specification (for 
example  with a COPY command), then for each name that matches the wildcard  specification, only  the 
first occurrence is retrieved. Continuing with our earlier example, the sequence  
MATCH AUTO 
DISPLAY SA LES? 
COPY SALES? TO MY BASE 
displays all six of the SALES .06 se ries, but copies only the first of them to the database MYBASE. Oth er 
names matching th e SALES? w ildcard specification are handled similarly.

www.fisglobal.com  59  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The MATCH option is immaterial unles s you have more than one database open  and the same data 
object name app ears i n more than one of the open databases.  
Limiting a Specification to One Kind of Data Obj ect 
So far , we’ve talked about three classes of data objects: scalars, series, and formulas . Eight ITEM opt ions 
allow you to rest rict the data objects retrieved by  a wildcard specification.  
For example, if you do not want to include for mulas among the obje cts you’re  working with, you can use 
the ITEM CLASS option to exclude formulas during wildc arding:  
ITEM CLA SS FORMULA OFF  
Suppose  that after entering this ITEM CLA SS opt ion, you enter the command DISPLAY MY_?  and your 
database contains the objects MY_FORMU LA1, MY_FO RMULA2, MY_SCALAR1, MY_SCALAR2, 
MY_SERIES1, and MY_SERIES2. The command evaluates  to the followin g: 
DISPLAY MY_SCALAR_1 , MY_SCALAR_2, MY_SERIES_1, MY_SER IES_2 
The wildcarded DISPLAY command does not display either MY_FORMULA_1  or MY_FORMULA_2.  
To include f ormulas again during wildcarding, you enter the following command:  
ITEM CLASS FOR MULA ON 
To exclu de scalars (including namelists) during wildcarding, ent er thi s command:  
ITEM CLASS SCALAR OFF  
And, of course, to exclude series,  you issue the follo wing comma nd: 
ITEM CLASS SERIES OFF  
If you only want to work with series that result from a  wildcard specif ication, you issue the  following 
command:  
ITEM CLASS FOR MULA OFF, SCALAR OFF  
Or you could issue the following command, which also  results in limiting  your wild card specification to 
series only:  
ITEM CLASS OFF, SERIES ON  
This discussion cove rs only the ITEM  CLASS option. There a re other ITEM options that you may  want to 
use. We’ve discussed the INDEX and TYPE concepts, so you should understand how their  respectiv e 
ITEM options work. You’ll be able to use the remaining ITEM options after you’v e become familia r with 
the concepts:  
 The ITEM NAME option for names and the IT EM ALIAS option for aliases.  
 The ITEM BASIS option for the BUSINESS  and DAILY basis att ributes.  
 The ITEM FREQUENCY option for frequencies, such as ANNUAL and DAILY.  
 The ITEM INDE X option for DAT E and CASE series.

 The ITEM OBSERVED option for observed  attributes, such as HIGH, LOW, BEGINNING, and 
END.  
 The ITEM TYPE option for series and scala r types, s uch as NUMERIC, PRECISION, DATE, and 
STRING.  
Confirming Your Wildcard Specificati on 
The CONFIRM o ption uses the WILDCAR D setting to control any destructi ve eff ects of wildcarding on 
objects:  
 CONFIRM WILDCARD ON  instructs FAME to confirm object na mes that m atch a wildcard that 
you specify with a destructive command. This setting require s you to confirm  the action when you 
try to delete or overwrite an objec t with  a wildcard. We’ll demonstrate this protective feature 
below.  
 CONFI RM WILDCARD OFF  instructs FAME  not to confirm any object names that match a 
wildcard used in a destructive comm and. 
 CONFIRM WIL DCARD AUTO , the defaul t, tells FAME to use CONFIRM WILDC ARD OF F with 
procedures and user -defined functions, and CONFIRM WILDCARD ON everywhere else.  
In the fol lowing DELETE command, FAME requires you to confirm the object names that match t he 
wildcard spec ification because CONF IRM WILD AUTO  is in effect:  
* DELETE ATLANTA.? 
OK to DELETE MYBASE'ATLANTA.SALES?  (Yes, No, Continue, Quit, Help) > Y  
OK to DE LETE MYBAS E'ATLANTA.EXPENSES?  (Yes, No, Continue, Quit, Help) > Y  
OK to DELETE MYBASE'ATLA NTA.PERCENTAGE?  (Yes, No, Continue, Quit, Help) > Y  
Here is what the re sponse s mean:  
 Yes means that it is OK to delete the current object and to  continue prompting.  
 No means that it is not OK to delete the current object, but to continue prompting.  
 Contin ue means to dele te all remaining match es without further prompting. This  respo nse 
pertains only to the current wildcard specification; if several  wildcard specificat ions were included 
in a list following the DELETE command, prompting recommences with the n ext wildcard 
specification.  
Quit means  to stop prompting and not to dele te any  of the matches confirmed so far. This response 
pertains only to th e current wildcard s pecificati on; if several wildcard specifications were included in a list 
following the DELE TE command, prom pting recommences with  the next wildcard specification.

www.fisglobal.com  61 FREQ UENCIES, DATES, AND CASES  
Most of the data that you use in business  analysis is time se ries data.  A time series consists of data that 
you’ve recorded at a regular, recurring inte rval; for exampl e, daily stock price h ighs, monthly stock 
volumes, quart erly c orporate earnings, and annual GDP.  
Some of FAME’s most powerful cap abilities revolve ar ound the c oncepts of frequencies and dates. This 
chapter describes:  
 Frequencies and how to set them with th e FREQUENCY option.  
 Dates and their use with the DATE op tion. 
 The YEAR and CENTURY options and how they affect dates.  
 The CASE op tion and case number s, another  way of indexing data.  
Understanding Frequencies  
In FAME, time series are indexed  by date at a sp ecific frequency. FAME  handles seventeen  different 
kinds  of frequencies. Among the frequencies mentioned earlier are daily, month ly, quarterly, and a nnual. 
Most of the frequencies can be aggregated into three FAME -defined groups, intraday f requencies , day-
based frequencies , and  month-based frequencies : 
 
Intrada y Day-based  Month -based  
MILLISECONDLY  
SECONDLY  
MINUTELY  
HOURLY  DAILY  
BUSINESS 
WEEKLY  
TENDAY  
BIWEEKLY  
TWICEMONTHLY  MONTHLY  
BIMONTHLY  
QUARTERLY  
SEMIANNUAL  
ANNUAL  
Two other frequencies are user -defined  (rather than FAME -defined): 
PPY (periods -per-year)    YPP (yea rs-per-period)  
Most applications never use the PPY and YPP frequenc ies, but they are di scussed he re in brief. User -
defined frequencies are beyond the scope of this introductory g uide. See the FA ME O NLINE  HELP for mor e 
information about user -defined f requen cies. 
Some frequency keywords can refer to more than one actual fre quency. For example,  the keywo rd 
WEEKLY encompasses seven different frequencies. Seven frequencies are necessar y since WEEKLY 
data can be reported ev ery Monday, every Tuesday, every W ednesd ay, and so on. Because a given

www.fisglobal.com  62  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
weekday occurs either 52 times a yea r or 53 times in a y ear, the a ctual weekday becomes of vital 
importance.  
With FAME, you specify the exact weekl y periodicity th at interests you. The system frees you from 
complicated number  juggling to fit data into 52 or 53 periods per year. Similarly, bi monthly data (data 
reported ev ery two months) may be reported every January, March, May, July, September, and 
November, or ever y February, April, Jun e, August, October, and December.  
Some k inds of frequency consist of just one frequency; for example, there  is only one daily f requency.  
Frequencies that require exact identification can be specified by entering the fr equency keyword,  followed 
by an approp riate “sample” unit in parentheses . For example, weekly data reported every Thursday is 
WEEKLY(THURS); bimo nthly data that is r eported in  January, March, May, July, and so on is 
BIMONTH(JAN).  
The following table explai ns each of the r ecognized frequencies (listed in order from highest to l owest) . 
Table 2. FAME  Frequencies  
 
Frequency  Meaning 
MILLISECONDLY  The MILLISECONDLY frequency corresponds to data observed eve ry x 
millisecond s, where x is the numb er of milliseconds in each period.  X is an integer 
that evenly divides 1000. Thus, the permissible values f or x are 1, 2, 4, 5,  8, 10, 20 , 
25, 40, 50, 100, 125, 200, 250, 500, and 1000. If x is omitted, 1 is assumed. 
MILLISECONDLY(100 0) is a synonym for SE CON DLY.  
SECO NDLY  The SECONDLY frequency corresponds to data observed every s se conds, where s 
is the number o f seconds in each period. S is an integer from 1 to 900 and must 
divide evenly in to 86,400 (the n umber of seconds in a day). For example, 
SECONDLY(10) da ta is reported every 10 seconds. If the sample unit is omitted 
from the f requency specificati on, FAME  assumes SEC(1).  
MINUTELY  The MINUTELY frequency corres ponds to data ob served every m minutes , where m 
is the number of minutes  in ea ch period. M is an integer from 1 to 720 and must 
divide evenly int o 1440 (t he num ber o f minutes in a day). For example, 
MINUTELY(10) data is reported every 10 minutes. If the sa mple unit is omi tted from 
the frequenc y specification, FAME  assumes MIN( 1). 
HOURLY  The HOURLY frequency corresponds to data observed every h hours, w here h is 
the number of hours in each period. H is one of the values 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, and 12. If  
the sample unit is om itted from the frequency specifica tion, FAME  assumes 
HOUR(1).  
DAILY  The DAILY freq uency corresponds to  data obse rved once each calendar day, 365 
or 366 days per year. The DAILY frequency does n ot use a sample unit in 
parentheses. U tility companies of ten track data such a s power generation on a daily 
basis.  
BUSINESS The BUSINESS frequency corresponds to data observed once each business or 
trading day, Monday through Fr iday. There are about 260 business day s per year. 
The BUSINESS frequency  does not use a sample unit in parentheses. Dow -Jones 
reports the Dow -Jones Industrial Index each busin ess day.

www.fisglobal.com  63  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Frequency  Meaning 
WEEKLY  The WEEKLY frequency corresponds to dat a reported every  seventh day. Because 
a weekly period may end on any of seven days (Monday through Sunday), FAME  
uses seven weekly frequencies. T o pin down the exact  weekly fr equency, you 
supply an ending day in parentheses following the WEEKLY freque ncy; for example, 
WEE K(FRIDAY). The ending day cannot be omitted. Much of the  data published by 
the federal government (money aggregates, for example)  is weekly.  
TENDAY  The TENDAY frequency corresponds to the ten -day periods widely use d in the 
automot ive industry to report  car sales. The TENDAY frequency d oes no t use a 
sample unit in parentheses. Each month’s days are divided i nto three groups by the 
TENDAY  frequency. The first TENDAY group includes the first through the tenth 
days of t he month, the se cond TENDAY group incl udes the eleventh through the 
twen tieth days, the third group includes the remaining days of the month (eig ht to 
eleven days, d epending o n the month).  
BIWEEKLY  The BIWEEKLY frequency corresp onds to data rep orted every second wee k. 
Because each biweekly period co nsists  of fourteen days, FAME  uses fourteen 
BIWEEKLY frequencies. Each we ekday repeats twice inside a b iweekly period, so 
the ending period name cannot be a day name without creating a mbiguity. To 
resolve the ambiguity, FAME names the ending biweekdays ASU NDAY t hrough 
ASATU RDAY, and BSUNDAY through BSAT URDAY. Thus, you can uniq uely 
specify a biwee kly freque ncy as BIWEEKLY(BTUESDAY), for example. The ending 
biweekday cannot be omitted.  
 
Since it is unli kely that you know whether last Tu esday was an ATUESDAY or a 
BTUESDAY, FAME  has a BIWK function that tells you the biweekday fo r any 
calendar day. BIWK takes three arguments, the year, the month, and the day, all 
expre ssed as integers  in that order, separa ted by commas, and enclosed in 
parenthes es. If you type DISPLAY BIWK(09,10,8) , FAME  informs you that the 
biweekday correspondin g to Octob er 8, 2009 , is ATHURSDAY.  
TWICEMONTHLY  The TWICEM ONTHLY frequency  corresponds to observ ations made twice each 
month. The TWICEM ONTHLY frequency does not use a sample unit in 
parentheses. The mon th is divided into t wo interva ls. The first interval comprises the 
first 15 days of the month; the second inter val comprises th e remainder of the mon th 
(13 to 16 days, depending on th e mont h). 
MONTHLY  The MONTHLY frequency corres ponds to observation s made onc e a month. The 
MONTHLY frequency does not use a sample unit in parentheses. The m onths are 
true m onths of varying lengt hs (28 to 31 days); they are not e qual d ivisions of a 
year. The unequal divisions become important for anal yses, graphics, and time 
scale  conversions.  
BIMONTHLY  The BIMONTHLY frequency corr esponds to data observed every second month. 
There are two BIMONTHLY fre quenci es. The first BIMONTHLY frequency 
corresponds to periods ending in even-numbered months  (February , April, ..., 
December). The second BIMONTHLY frequency corresponds to periods en ding in 
odd-numb ered months (January, March, ..., November).  
 
To identif y the bimonthly frequency that interests you, follow the frequency name 
with an ending month in parenth eses; for example, BIMONTH(JUNE) or 
BIMON(NOV). Notice that BIMONTH(MAR) and BIMO NTH(MAY), for ex ample, 
identify the sa me frequency as BIMON(JAN). If you  omit the ending month, FAME 
assumes BIMONTH(DEC).

FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Frequency  Meaning 
QUARTERLY  The QUARTERLY  frequency corresponds to data recorded every three months. 
There are three QUART ERLY frequencies . Ending months separa ted by three 
months identify the s ame fr equency. Thus, the QUARTERLY(DECEMBER) 
specification is equivalent to QUA(MAR), QUA(JUN E), and QU A(SEP). If you omit 
the ending month from the frequency specification, FAME  assum es 
QUARTER(DEC).  Corporations often re port financial data on a quarterly  basis . 
SEMIANNUAL  The SEMIANNUAL frequency  corresponds to data  reported every six months. 
Because each semiannual period consists of six months, FAME  uses six 
SEMIANNUAL  frequencies. Ending m onths separated by six months iden tify the 
same frequency; thus, SEMIANNUAL(JAN) is equivalent to SEMIANN(J UL). If you 
omit the  ending mo nth from the frequency specification, FAME  assumes 
SEMI(DEC).  
ANNUAL  The ANNUAL frequency cor responds to data reported every tw elfth month. Because 
a year has twelve possible ending months, FAME  uses twelve ANNUAL 
freque ncies. To identify the frequency that interests you, enclose the ending month 
name in paren theses following  the frequency; for ex ample, ANN(APR). If you omit 
the s ample ending month from the frequency specification, FAME  assumes 
ANNUAL( DEC ). 
PPY The PPY frequency, or the periods -per-year frequency,  divides years into in tervals 
of equal length. You speci fy onl y the number of periods in a year. The number of 
periods can be any  integer value you d esire, up to 500. For example, PPY(7) 
divides the year into seven equal periods; PPY(100) d ivides the year into one 
hundred inter vals. 
 
Never use the PPY frequency  to represent one of the day -based or month -based 
periodicities recognize d by FAME. PPY(4) is  not equiv alent to QUARTERLY, and 
PPY(12) is not equivalent to MONTHLY.  
YPP The YPP frequency, or t he yea rs-per-period frequency, corresponds to data 
reported at intervals that are multiples o f twelve m onths, so that they are user -
specified month -based frequencies. To specify the YP P frequency that  interests 
you, enter the number of twelve -month multipl es, a sample ending year, and a 
sample ending month. For example, the fre quency of U.S. presi dential el ections is 
YPP(4,08,NOV) . The limit to the interval length is 30 years.  
Defining  a Frequency  
The FREQUENCY option serv es the following functions:  
 Interp rets d ates (discussed next). For example, 09:1 translates to January 2009  when you’ve set 
a monthly fre quency, or to the first quarter of 2009 when you’ve set a quarterly frequency.  
 Determines the fre quency of the time ser ies you create and determines the date o f date scalars 
you create. For example, you are prompted to enter n ew data at a weekly frequency or at a 
monthly frequency, depending on your setting of the FREQUENCY option.  
 Determines the freq uency of the time seri es created during automatic time -scale c onversion. For 
example, you can convert weekly and semi -annual time  series to quarterly  or monthl y series, 
depending on your setting of the FREQUENCY option.  
 Determines the frequ ency of values u sed in implicit loops.  For example, a report may appear with 
monthly columns or with annual columns, depending on your setting of  the FREQUENCY optio n.

Althoug h you may specify the FREQUENCY option globally, you can override it locally in m ost 
commands. Ho wever, it’s important to note that the FREQUENCY option does n ot limit your retrieval or 
manipulation of data already stored in d atabases.  
The FREQUE NCY option  takes the form FREQUENCY freq -spec , where freq-spec  is one of FAME’s 
seventeen  frequencies, qual ified with an example ending period (or a sample unit, i n the case of intraday 
and PPY frequencies) in parentheses if necessary:  
 The intraday frequen cies, MILL ISECONDLY,  SECONDLY, MINUTELY, and HOURLY, do not 
require sample units. If the sa mple unit is omi tted, it defaults to 1 . 
 The DAILY, BUSINESS, TENDAY, TWI CEMONT HLY, and MONTHLY frequencies do not use 
example ending periods.  
 The example ending peri od may not  be omitted from weekly and biweekly frequency 
specifications; for example, WEEKL Y(FRI) and BIWEE K(BTUES).  
 The example ending period may be omitted from month -based frequencies, such as 
BIMONTHLY, QUARTERLY, SEMIANNUAL, and AN NUA L. If you omit th e example ending 
period from a month -based frequency specification, FAME uses the December default.  
The fre quencies and example e nding periods can be truncated to their minimum unique abbreviation; in 
many cases, the abbreviation may co nsist of one letter.  The follo wing are all legal  frequency

Understanding Dates  
Now th at you know the different frequencies of data available to you in F AME , you need to lea rn how to 
specify dates for the different frequencies. Dates perform several important func tions in FAME:  
 Dates set ranges for ti me series analyses; for example DATE 2009 or DATE JAN 09 TO DEC09 . 
 Dates serve as indexes to identify partic ular values; for exa mple SALES [2009] or 
EXPENSES[JAN07]. (The square brackets around the date indicate subscrip ting, a concept 
discussed later in thi s guide.)  
 Dates become arguments t o some  settings and options; for example FORECAST TO MAR 12. 
FAME interpre ts dates in conjunct ion with f requencies. There are many ways you can combine date and 
frequency specifications . The following examples all illustrat e an equivalent specification of a  twelv e 
month range, from July 2008 to June 2009:  
FREQUENCY MONTHLY  
DATE JUL08 TO JUN09  
This example se ts the FREQUENCY option globally. JUL08 and JUN09 are examples of the date data 
type used to set the date range. The da te JUN09 is an example of imprecis e spec ification since it is 
ambiguous without a frequency specification; JUN09 could pertain to any mon th-based frequency 
(monthly, bimonthly, quarterly, semiannually, or annually).  
FREQUENCY MONTHLY  
DATE 08:7 TO 09:6

This example also sets the FREQUENCY o ption globally. 08:7 and 09:6 are examples of the date data 
type used to set the date range. The date 08:7 is an example of imprecise specification since it is 
ambiguous without a freq uency specificat ion; 08:7 could pertai n to any of several day -based or m onth-
based frequencies.  
DATE 08M7 TO 09M6  
This example incorporates an un ambiguous monthly da te specifi cation into each date so that you are not 
required to enter a FREQUENCY specifica tion. 09M6 is an  example of the date data type used to set the 
date rang e. The  date 09M6 incorporates a frequency specification (since M represen ts month) and 
unambi guously sp ecifies June 2009, the sixth month of 2009.  
Remember that date specifications are  data objects mu ch like series or scal ars. Like other data objects, 
they canno t be abbreviated or extended. For example, SEP09 is not equivalent to S09, nor is it eq uivalent 
to SEPTEM09.  
Ambiguous Date Forms  
You ca n always specify  a date in a day -based , month-based, PPY, or YPP frequen cy usi ng the form 
yy:pp , where yy represents the year and pp represents t he period. Dates of this form are always 
ambiguous and are interpreted with reference to the FREQUENCY option; for example the date 09:4 
represents t he following:  
January 4, 2009 at F REQUEN CY DAILY  
The fourth Thursday of 2009 at FREQUENCY WEEK(THU)  
April 2 009 at FREQUENCY MON TH 
August 2009 at FREQUENCY BIMONTHLY  
The fourth quarter of 2009 at FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
The year can be eit her two or four digits ; for example, 09:4 or 2009:4. The  perio d can have any number of 
leading zeroes; for example, 09:4, 2009:04 , 09:004, or 2009:00 04. All of  these date specifications are 
equivalent.  
Intraday dates are specified using the  form daily-date:hh:mm:ss . Daily -date can be either ddmmmyy  (for 
example , 23AP R09) or yy:pp  (for example, 09:113). Hh is the hour on a 24 -hour cl ock, mm is the minut e, 
and ss is the second. For example, at a SECONDLY frequency, 3:30:00 PM on April 26, 2009 , is 
specified a s 26APR 09:15:30:00  or 09:116:15:30:00 . The ss may be lef t off for minutely and hourly dates, 
and the mm may be left off for hourl y dates. The time 4: 42:13 PM o n May 5, 2009, at an HOURLY(2) 
frequency is 5MAY 09:16 (intraday intervals are lab eled by the begi nning time of the inte rval; the two -
hourly interval that  includes 4:42 PM began at 4 PM).  
Each of FAME’s basic day -based and mont h-based frequencies has its ow n ambiguous date form:  
 For the day -based frequencies (DAILY, BUSINESS, WEEKLY, TE NDAY, TWICEMONTH LY, and 
BIWEEKLY), you  can use the form ddmmmyy , where dd is the number of the day, mmm  is the 
first three -letter month name, and  yy is the two -digit year numb er; for example, the date 
10NOV09 corresponds to the following:  
The day November 10, 2009, at FRE QUENCY DAILY and FREQU ENC Y BUS  
The week ending November 10, 20 09, at FREQUENCY WEEK(TUE)  
The period ending November 10, 2009, at FREQUENCY TENDAY

 For month -based frequencies (MONTHLY, BIMONTHLY, QUARTERLY, SEMIANNUAL, 
ANNUAL, and YPP), you can use the ambi guous form mmmyy , wher e mmm is the three -letter 
month na me, an d yy is the two -digit year number. For example, the date MAY09 corr esponds to 
the follo wing:  
The month ending in May of 2009 at FREQUENCY MONTH  
The quarter ending in May of 2009 at FREQUENCY QUA RTER(FEB)  
The semiannu al half-year ending in May of 2009  at FR EQUENCY SEMI(NOV)  
The year ending in May of 2009 at FREQUENCY ANNUA L(MAY) 
 For PPY (peri ods-per-year) frequencies, the ambiguous date form is nnPDyy , where nn is the 
period number , PD is literal (not substituted), and  yy is the two -digit year. Thus, 4 PD09 i s the 
fourth period of 2009, whether the periodicity is PPY(4), PPY (7), or PPY(250). 4P D09 does n ot 
correspond to any calendar date.  
All of these cases are ambiguous because they  do not incorpor ate the frequency. In each case, FAME 
knows that the fre quency  is either day -based or month -based, and also knows a sample ending  period for 
the date . 
For your  convenience, special, less ambiguous forms of date specification have been devel oped for the 
five principal month -base d frequencies. These forms retain some a mbiguity because the ending month of 
the year may be changed with t he YEAR option, whic h is discu ssed later in this section:  
 The form yyMnn  identifies a MONTHLY date. In this cas e, yy is the two -digit year, M is lite ral, and 
nn is the number of the m onth. For example, 09M5 is the fifth month of 2009 at the monthly 
frequen cy. (Remember, only one monthl y frequency exists).  
 The form yyBn  identifies a BIMONTHLY date. In this case, yy is the two -digit year, B is literal, a nd 
n is the number of the bimonthl y peri od. Thus, 08B2 is the second bimonthly period in 2008. 
However, 08B 2 is ambiguous becau se the fre quency could be FREQ BIM(JAN) or FREQ 
BIM(FEB).  
 The form yyQn  identifies a QUARTE RLY date. In thi s case, yy is the two -digit year, Q is literal, 
and n is the n umber of the quarter. Thus, 06Q3 is the third quarter of 2006. Howe ver, 06Q3 is 
ambiguo us because  the frequency could be FREQ QUART(JAN), FREQ QUA(FEB), or FREQ 
QUA(MAR).  
 The for m yySn  identifie s a SEMIANNUAL date. I n this case, yy is the two -digit y ear, S is literal, 
and n is the number of the semiannual period. Thus, 07 S1 is the first half  of 2007. However, 07S1 
is ambiguous because the frequency could be any month from FREQ SEM IANN(JAN) throug h 
FREQ SEMI(JUN).  
 The form yyA1  or yyA identifies an ANN UAL da te. Here, yy is the two -digit year, A is literal, and 
the period nu mber 1 is not necess ary after the annual date specification, for obvious reasons. 
Thus, 06A and 06A1 are both 2 006 without ambi guity. 
When you specif y an ambiguous date that can be in terpre ted at the current frequency, FAME immediately 
interprets it and tr anslates it into an unambiguou s date. That is, any date ceases to be ambiguous as 
soon as FAME uses it.

Thus, 06A and 06A1 are both 2 006 without ambi guity. 
When you specif y an ambiguous date that can be in terpre ted at the current frequency, FAME immediately 
interprets it and tr anslates it into an unambiguou s date. That is, any date ceases to be ambiguous as 
soon as FAME uses it. This me ans that even th ough you specified an ambiguous date range, FAME does

Unambig uous Date Forms  
Date s at any f requency can be specified unambiguously by prefixing the appropriate ambiguous fo rm with 
the freq uency:  
 For intraday fr equencies, use the form frequency( ddmmmy y:hh:mm:ss ). For example, 11 A.M., 
June 5, 2009, can be unambiguous ly specified as HOUR LY(5JUN09: 11) or as 
MINUTELY(5)(5JUN09:11:00).  
 For day -based frequencies, use the form freq uency(ddmmmyy). For example, 2NOV07 ca n be 
unambiguously specified as DA ILY(2N OV07), BUS(2NOV07), or WEEK(2NOV07).  
 For month -based frequencies, u se the form frequenc y(mmmyy ). For example, MAY07 can be 
unambiguously specified as MON(MAY07), QUA(MAY07) or SE MIANN(MAY07).  
 For the YPP frequency, u se the form YPP(years -per-period)( mmmyy ); for example, 
YPP(4)(MAY07).  
 For the PPY frequency, use the form PPY(periods -per-year) (nnPDyy ); for example, 
PPY(250)(4PD07) — well, it’s as clear as it can be.  
Of course, you c an use the form yy:pp to replace any o f the forms: ddmmmyy , mmmyy , and nnPDyy . 
FAME allows one other convenience in date specification. Suppose t hat you want to set a range th at 
spans two entire years. You can use ordinary numbers instead of dates, for exa mple:  
DATE 05 TO  06 
If you specify FREQUE NCY MONTH , FAME  treats this as 05M1 to 06M12. If you specify FREQ QUA , the 
range corresponds to 05Q1 to 06Q4. If you specify  FREQ DAIL Y, the range extends from the first day of 
2005  through the last day of 2006 . FAM E treats referen ces of the form 05 and 06 as numbers, not dates, 
but con verts them to year references when it requires a date reference . 
Using th e DATE Option  
The DA TE option takes as its settings one or more user -specified date spans or ranges. FAME inter prets 
the spans with respect to the FR EQU ENCY option. You can set spans that i dentify the following:  
 A single period; for example, DATE 2008.  
 A simple range that inc ludes ever y intervening period; for example, DATE 2001  TO 2008 .

 A range that regularly skip s intervening ob servations; for exampl e, DATE 19 89 TO 2008  STEP 4 . 
 A ran ge tha t is non -contiguous; for example, DATE 1979 TO 19 91, 19 99, 2007 TO 2009. 
 A range that i ncludes sp ans or periods taken out of order; for example, DATE 1964 to 1994 
STEP 2, 1955 TO  1959 . 
 A range t hat is open -ended at t he beginning (for example, DATE * to 198 9), the end (for 
example, DATE 1986 TO * ), or both (for example, DATE * TO * ). 
FAME use s date ran ges exactly as they are specified for the DISPLAY and REPORT commands. 
However, f or graphics and for analysis, FAME sor ts the date ranges chronologically  and d eletes duplicate 
dates.  
Date ranges may be set at every level of op tion specification: global, bl ock, command -specific, and 
argument -specific. The following is an example of a on e-period range:

Defining a Fiscal Year  
Can anything more be said about dates? Well, y es. As it happens, m any corpor ations have business 
years that do not end with the calendar year. Even the U.S. government uses a fiscal year that beg ins in 
October and ends in Septemb er. 
When you summarize data into annual aggregates, it becomes important for the data to be p roperly 
aligned with the fiscal year. If your fiscal year runs from July to June, you proba bly don’t want t o analyze 
data on a Ja nuary to December basis. FAME hand les th is problem with fiscal year frequencies (for 
example, ANNUAL(JUNE)) . The YEAR option de termines h ow fiscal frequency dates are named. 
Whenever you set a fiscal year frequency, yo u should also sp ecify the correspondin g YEAR option.  
The YEAR option has  two m odifiers, END and LABEL:  
 END takes a calendar month name as its arg ument. END identifie s the mont h of the calendar 
year in which the fiscal year ends.  
 LABEL takes FIRST, LAST, or  AUTO as its arg ument. LABEL specifies  the calendar year that 
should be used t o label the fiscal year. The arguments FIRST, LAST, and AUTO may no t be 
abbreviated.  
If you speci fy FIRST, then FAME uses the calendar year of the first month of the fiscal year to 
label the fis cal year.  
If you speci fy LAST, then FAME uses the calend ar yea r of the last month of the fiscal year to 
label the fiscal year.  
If you specify AUTO, t hen FAME s elects a FIRST or LAST setting, depending on your setting of 
the END modifier. Fo r fiscal years e nding in the months Ja nuary to May, FAME uses the calend ar 
year of the first month to label the fiscal year. For fiscal years end ing in June to Decem ber, FAME 
uses the calendar year of the last month to label the fiscal year.  
The default is  YEAR END DECEMB ER, LABEL AUTO . The mo difiers END and LABEL are optional . 
Supp ose your fiscal year ends in June, and that fiscal year 2008 ended in June, 2009. You s pecify the  
following:  
YEAR END JUNE, LABEL FIRST  
or 
YEAR JUNE, FIRST

Hint When you wo rk with fiscal y ears and w ith month -based frequencies that require ending

in your date formats.  
Defining the  Current Century  
FAME uses one other option, t he CENTURY option, in the interpretation  of dates. Most users never need 
to modify the default setting, CEN TURY AUTO.  
The CENTURY  option determines how two -digit year dates are interpreted by specifying the fir st year of 
the c urrent hundred -year period. The new default is AUTO whic h means that t he working century starts 
50 years before the current year.  
FAME in terprets two -digit yea r dates accordingly:  
 The years 26 to 99 correspond to 1926 to 1999.  
 The years 00 to 25 are interp reted as 2000 to 2025.  
To refe rence a year outside the c urrent century , you specify four digits; for example, 1918 or 2030. To 
change the  CENTURY opt ion, speci fy the four -digit year that you want to begin the century; for example:  
CENTURY 1 951 
This option makes the current century 1951  to 2050. In this case, th e years 51 to 99 correspond to 1951 
to 1999 and the years 00 to 50 correspond to 2000 to 2050 . 
Understanding Case Indexes  
So far, this chapter has  focused on dates and freq uencies. Howev er, you can think of much business 
data as categorical rather than time-based. For exampl e, a company may keep data on market size in the

www.fisglobal.com  76

different regions where it does business. Concei vably, these series could be s tored as time series, but in 
many cases,  historical and forecast data may be unneeded or unavailable.  
Time series requi re both a frequency and a date to identify a particular data value or range of dates. Case 
series, on the o ther hand, are indexed by a si ngle sequential method. Th erefore, a cas e series requires 
only the single option, CASE, to exactly identify  a particula r case num ber or a span of cases.  
The CASE option is very similar to the DATE option. It se ts a working cas e range that covers a single 
observation, a span of sequ ential observa tions, or a mixture of spans. For purposes of the DISPLAY and 
REPOR T commands, FAME uses the exact sequence of case numbers that you specify. However, for 
graphics and fo r analysis, FAME  sorts the case numbers into a scending order and deletes  duplicate cas e 
numbers.  
To identify one particular case, specify the CASE option , followed b y a single  index number; for example:  
* CASE 16  
* TYPE POPULATION  
2363208.00  
This CASE opti on makes the six teenth case the working range for any case series you an alyze.  
To get a simple span of cases, use the form CASE beginning TO ending , whe re the keyword T O is 
required; for example:  
* CASE 1 TO 5  
* DECIMAL 0  
* REPORT POPULAT ION 
 
 
                  1       2        3        4         5  
            -------  ------  -------  -------  --------  
POPULATION  3890061  400481  2717866  2285513  23668 652 
This option makes the first five cases (or  categories) the working c ase range.  
As with the DATE option, it’s easy for you to combine ranges:  
* CASE 2  TO 3, 1, 10  TO 12, 14  
* REPORT POPULATION  
 
 
                 2        3        1       10      11      12       14  
            ------  -------  -------  -------  ------  ------  ------- 
POPULATION  400481  2717866  3890061  5464265  965011  943935  549017 9 
Use the STEP keyword with a case  range to skip o ver cases and display categori es at regular intervals:  
* CASE 5 TO 25 STEP 5 
* REPORT POPULATION  
 
                   5       10       15       20       25 
            --------   -------  -------  -------  ------- 
POPULATION  23668652  546426 5  2913387  4216 446  4917444

You may no t use the asterisk in the middle of a group of case spans. The foll owing case r anges are

* TYPE @CASE  
1 TO 5, 7, 10

www.fisglobal.com  79 DATA OBJECTS  
FAME has five kinds of data objects: scalars , series , formulas , global  names , and globa l formulas . Each 
kind of data object is created with a u nique, unambig uous command:  
SCALAR, SERIES, FORMULA, GLNAME, or GLFORMULA. The GL NAM E and GLF ORMULA com mands 
are beyond the scope of a FAME introductory manual. They are discussed in F AME’s C OMMAND  
REFERENCE . This chapter introduc es and demonstrates the fo llowing comman ds and concepts:  
 How to create a scalar with the SCALAR command.  
 How to create a time ser ies or a case series with the SERIES command.  
 How to use existing scalars and ser ies to create ne w scalars and series with the NEW  command. 
In particular , it is often simpler to create a scalar with NEW than with the SCALAR command.  
 How to create  formulas with the FORMULA command.  
 How to copy any data object with the COPY command.  
This chapter also ex plains how to overwrite data w ith the OVERWRITE option a nd how to stor e 
temporary objects in the WORK database.  
Creating Scalars  
Data obj ects that st ore a sing le value are scalars ; you create them with the SCALAR command.  
A scalar can be an y one of the six  FAME data types: NUMERIC, PRE CISION, STRING, BOOLEAN, 
DATE, or NAMELI ST. Once you’ve created a scalar, you cannot change the data type o f the scalar  
except by  deleting it and then creating it again.  
Here is the form of the SCALAR command:  
SCALAR scalar -names:data -type = expression  
You can abbreviate the SCALAR  command name,  but you must fully specify the data types as 
NUMERIC, PRECISION, S TRING, BOOLE AN, NAMELI ST, or DATE. You can omit the equals sign and 
the expression, as well as the colo n and the data t ype: 
 If you omit the equals si gn and expression, the sca lar is given a  missing data code as its value. 
You can use the SET command, descr ibed in the chapter  ENTER  AND CHANGE DATA  (p. 127), 
to assign values to these  scalars.  
 If you omit  the colon and the data type, FAME looks at the setting of the OBJECT option 
(describe d later) to deter mine what type of scalar to create. The default setting of the OBJECT 
option caus es FAME to creat e a NUMERIC scalar.

www.fisglobal.com  80  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Each scalar dat a type is described s eparately below.  
Numeric and Precision Scalars  
The following commands create valid numeric scalars. The  commands in each pair produce the same 
result:  
SCALAR ALPHA  
SCALAR ALPHA: NUMERI C 
These commands  create a numeric scalar named ALPH A and assign it the m issing data code.  
SCALAR BETA = 1.2  
SCAL BETA:NUMERIC = 1.2  
These commands create a nu meric scalar call ed BETA and assign it the value 1.2.  
SCALAR ALPHA, BETA, THETA = 1.8  
SCAL ALPHA, BETA, THETA:NUME RIC = 1.8  
These commands create num eric scalars named AL PHA, BETA, and THET A and assign the value 1.8 to 
each one. Note that the colon and num eric data type ( :NUMERIC ) are optional. More complicated 
expressions can appear on the right side of the equals si gn. We show more complicated exampl es in the 
next chapte r under the discuss ion of expressions.  
To create a precision scalar, use the following  forms: 
SCALAR AL PHA_PR: PRECISION  
SCAL ALPHA_PR, BETA_PR:PRECISION = 13579246  
The first command c reates a precisi on scalar and assigns it a missing data value. The secon d command 
creates t wo precision scalars and assigns them both the same value.  
String S calars 
The follow ing commands create four string scalars:  
SCALAR MYTEXT:STRING  
This command create s the string sca lar MYTEXT and assigns it a missing  value. 
SCALAR ONE:ST RING = "Evaluation of the first scenario"  
This command creates the string scalar ONE a nd assigns it the  string Evaluation of the first scenario . 
SCALAR A, B:STRING = "Division One"  
This command create s the string scalars A and B; each is assigned the value  Division One . 
As the following example illustrates, the quotation marks around the st ring of text are required:  
* SCALAR ONE:STRING = Evaluation of the first scenario  
Error: Invalid s yntax at end of statement or argument

If you omit t he quotes around a st ring, FAME treats t he string as an expression and attempts to evaluate 
it. As you will  see in the next chapter, it is possible to create an expression that can be evaluated as a 
string . 
Unless you use  the OBJECT option (described later  in this chapter) to change the default data type, you 
cannot omit the colon and STRING data type from the SCALAR command, e ven if you put quotes around 
the string on the right side:  
* SCALAR TWO = "Divisi on Two" 
Error: C annot set variable TWO of type NUME RIC to expression of type STRING  
Unless the OBJECT option setting has been changed, FAME requires the full expression SCALAR  
scalar -name:STRING = string -expression  to create a string scalar and assign a va lue to it.  
Boole an Scalars  
The following example s create boolean  scalars:  
* SCALAR ANSWER:BOOLEAN  
* SCALAR ON_OFF:BOOLEAN = ON  
* SCALAR YN, TF:BOOLEAN = YES 
* DISPLAY ANSWER, ON_OFF, YN, TF  
 
ANSWER 
 
ND 
 
 
ON_OFF 
 
TRUE 
 
 
YN 
 
TRUE 
 
 
TF 
 
TRUE 
These thr ee SCALAR commands create four scal ars: the first with a  missing data code,  the second with 
the value ON, and the third and fourth with the va lue YES. 
Boolean variables only store two kinds of results, positive and negative, even though the ir values can be  
set as YES, TRUE, and ON, (or thei r opposites NO, FALSE , and OFF respectiv ely). The DISPLAY 
command illustrates that when you retrieve boolea n values, they ar e expressed as either TRUE or 
FALSE, regardless of the form used to set them.  
Nam elist Scalars  
The following examples create namelis t scalars:
