SCALAR CIT IES:NAMELIST  
SCALAR TOWNS, CITIES, STATES: NAMELIST  
These two SCALAR commands create n amelist scalars, but do not assign values to them.  
SCALAR CITIES:NAMELIST = {TAMPA, DENVER, TEMPE,  KLAMATH}  
This c ommand creates the namelist CITIES and assigns four name s to it. Note that,  to a certain extent, it 
is redundant to say “namelist scalar,” sin ce name lists can never be series.  
Warning  Later in this section, you  will learn how to delete and how to overwrite  existing data objects. 
Remember th at whenever you are w orking in a context  where FAME  allows a list of names, 
you should preface a namelist n ame with an excla mation point (!) if you want an operation to 
affect the namelist itself and not i ts contents.   In particular, note that the SCALAR command is 
not the recommende d way to create n amelists. If the exclamation point is omitted, you may 
accidentally create nameli sts that you do not want. For example, if X is the namelist {A, B, C}, 
then the command SCA LAR X:NAMELIST = {A, B, C, D}  creates A, B, and C as namelists, 
each equal to {A, B,  C, D}. The NEW command, discussed later in this chapter, is far safer 
than the S CALAR command fo r creating namelists.  
Date Scalars  
To create a date scal ar, you must provid e a frequency in addition to the date. You can supply the 
frequency  in parentheses f ollowing the data type DATE; or you can omit the frequency and allow FAME 
to dete rmine it from th e current value of the FREQUENCY op tion. When you supply  a date with the 
SCALAR command that is different from the current setting of the FREQ UEN CY o ption, the n you must 
specify an unambiguous date on the right side of the equals sign. If t he frequency of the SCALAR 
command matches the curr ent setting of the FR EQUENCY option, the n the date specified on the right 
side of the equals sign can be am biguous . The foll owing FAME session makes these points clear:  
* SCALAR FYEAR:DATE = 08  
* SCALAR ST ART:DATE = JUN08  
 
Error: JUN08 is not a date at ANN UAL frequency  
 
* SCALAR START:DATE(MONTH ) = JUN08  
 
Error: JUN08 is not a date at ANNUAL frequency  
 
* SCALAR  START:DATE(MONTH ) = 08M6 
The first SCALAR command, creating the date scalar FYEAR, works because 08 is a legal da te at the 
default, annual frequency . 
There are two thing s wrong with the se cond SCALAR command. First, the SCALAR command attempts 
to assign a  monthly date to a scalar of annual frequency.  
Second, the monthly date cannot be interpreted at t he current worki ng frequency, which is ANNUAL.  
The third SCALAR command makes the same erro r: although we are creating a monthly scalar, the 
monthly date on t he right of the e quals sign is interpreted at an annual frequency.  
In the last command, the date s pecification on the right side of the equals sign i s made unambiguous so  
that FAME does not  use the current frequency to interpret it.

www.fisglobal.com  83  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
In the following exampl e, we g lobally se t the FREQUENCY option to quarterly, and use an ambiguous 
date form appropriate f or quarterly dat a to create the scalar BEGIN. Becau se we do not specify a sample 
ending mon th with the frequency, FAME uses the default end month of December:  
* FREQUENCY QUAR TER 
* SCALAR BEGIN:DATE = 09:3  
Some date specifications, such as WEEKLY and BIWEE KLY, do not allo w default end periods. In these 
cases you must provide t he sample ending pe riod yourself. The following example illustrates an awkward 
case in volving biweekly data: 
* TYPE BIWK (09, 11, 24)  
 
BTUESDAY  
 
* SCALAR BW_ONE:DATE (BIWEEKLY (BTUES))  = BIWEEK(24NOV0 9) 
* SCALAR <FREQUENCY BIWEEK (BTUE S)> BW_TWO:DATE = 24N OV09 
The BIWK funct ion tells the biweekday for November 24, 2009. The first SCALAR com mand uses the 
complete standard form to create the scalar. The second command sets the FREQUENCY o ption at the 
command-specific level to create the s calar. 
Different Type s of Scalars  
You ca nnot create different types of scalars in the same command, nor can  you assign diffe rent values to 
scalars that you create in a single SCALAR command. For example, t he following SCA LAR commands 
are illegal:  
SCALAR IN TRO:DATE, VAL:NUMERIC    —Illegal 
SCALAR X = 1.7, Y = 1.4142       —Illegal 
The best way to fix these two in valid commands is  to turn them into four valid commands:  
SCALAR INTRO:DATE  
SCALAR VAL:NUMERIC  
SCALAR X = 1.7  
SCALAR Y = 1.4142  
Hint After you become comfortable with the different types of FAME data and scalars, you will often 
find it easier to create scal ars with the NEW command. We will describe the NEW command 
later in this chapter.  
Creating Series  
Data objects tha t take on regularly -measured sequen ces of related values  are series; you cr eate them 
with the SERIES command.  
A series can be any of five FAME  data types: NUME RIC, PRECISION, STRING, BOOLEAN, or DATE. 
Once you’ve created a series, you canno t change the dat a type of the series except by dele ting it and 
then crea ting it again.  
Here  is the form of the SERIES command:

www.fisglobal.com  84  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
SERIES series -name:data -type IN DEXED B Y index -type = val1, val2, ..., valn  
You can abbreviate the SERIES command name, but you mu st spell out the  data type as NUMERIC, 
PRECISION, S TRING, BOOLEAN, or DA TE. You can omit th e equals sign and the values. You can also 
omit the INDEXED BY inde x-type clause, as  well as the colon and the data type:  
 If you omit the equal sign and values, FAME  fills the serie s with missing data values.  
You can  use the SET and UPDA TE commands, which are described in the chapter  ENTER  AND 
CHANGE DATA  (p. 127), to assign values to the ser ies. It is usual ly easier and better to use the 
UPDATE c omm and to add da ta values to a series th an to list out the values on the SERIES 
command line.  
 If you omit t he INDEXED B Y index -type phrase, FAME assumes that you want to create a time 
series, that is,  a series indexe d by date. The keyword INDEXED is also o ptional, so you can 
simply specify BY in dex-type.  
 If you omit the colon and the data type, FAME looks at th e setting of  the OBJECT option 
(described later) to determine what type of series to create. The default sett ing of the OBJECT 
option causes FAME to create a NUMERIC  series.  
We will show ex amples of how to create time series first, and then we will show ex amples of ca se series.  
Time Series  
Whenever you plan to create a time series , it is crucial t hat you remember  to specify the frequency.  
Typically, th is is done by se tting the frequency at t he global level with the FREQUENCY option. If you do 
not specify a frequency, t he default frequency is ANNUAL.  
Numeric and Precision Time Series  
The following e xample shows how  to create a numeric time series of quar terly frequency:  
* FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
* SERIES CORP_SALES:NUMERIC INDEXED BY DATE  
The following commands a re all equiv alent to the SERIES command used above. Note how many 
defaults FAME invokes when you enter the co mmand with the simple form SERIES series -name: 
SERIES CO RP_SALES:NUMERIC BY DATE  
SERIES CORP_SALES:NUMERIC  
SERIES CORP_SALES INDEXED BY DATE  
SERIES CORP_SALES BY DATE 
SERIES CORP_SALES  
To create a series of precision values, you must specif y the PRECISION  data type, unless you use the 
OBJECT opt ion (described l ater in this chapter) to  change the default data type. Remember, precision 
data is like num eric data, e xcept that it can hold up to fifteen significant digits, rather than just seven. 
Create a precisi on time series with any of the following  SERIES statemen ts: 
SERIES CORP_SALES:PR ECISION INDEXED BY DATE  
SERIES CORP_SALES:PRECISION BY DATE  
SERIES CORP_SALES:P RECISION

Case Series  
You generate case series the same way that you crea te time series. Case series, however, require you to 
specify the INDEXED  BY CASE  phrase or, simply BY CASE , with the SERIES command.

SERIES A BY CASE

Transforming Data Objects  
The NEW comm and all ows you to create new scalars  and series  based on already existing scalars and 
serie s. The NEW comma nd uses mathematical or logical combinations of e xisting data objects; these 
combinations  are more fully described in the next chapter  EXPRESSIONS  (p. 98). The NEW com mand 
also uses v alues that you define for scalars.  
Here is the for m of the NEW command:  
NEW new -object = e xpression  
The name of the command itself, NEW, is optional and may be omitted. This allows you to efficiently 
generate new objects by naming the objec t and its “trans formation.”  
The NEW command provides you with a si mple means for creating a scalar. Althou gh the SCALAR 
command has the advantage of being very expli cit, the  NEW command is much briefer. The NEW 
command has the added advantage of automatica lly creating a d ocumentation attribute for the new data 
object fro m the expression used to create it.  
If you want to create a numeric scalar , the following commands are equi valent: 
SCALAR FUDGE_FACTOR = .87  
NEW FUDGE_FACTOR = .87  
FUDGE_FACTOR = .87  
If you want to create a  precision scalar , the following commands are equi valent: 
SCALAR PRE_VAL:PRECISION = 12345 678 
NEW PRE_VAL = 12345678D0  
PRE_VAL = 12345678D0  
If you wa nt to cr eate a string scalar , the following commands are equivalent:  
SCALAR T1:STRING = " Fidelity National Information Services " 
NEW T1 = " Fidelity National  Information Services " 
T1 = " Fidelity National Information Services " 
If you want to create a boolean scalar , the following commands are equivalent:  
SCALAR ANSWER:BO OLEAN = YES  
NEW ANSWER = YES  
ANSWER = YES  
If you want to create a namelist scalar , the following commands are equivalent:  
SCALAR CITIES:NAMELIST = {WHAT_CHEER, WALLA _WALLA, OOLITIC} 
NEW CITIES = {WHAT_CHEER, WALLA_WALLA, OOLITIC}  
CITIES = {WHAT_CHEER, WALL A_WALLA, OOLITIC } 
If you want to create a date scalar , the followi ng commands are equivalent. Remember, th e entry on the 
right side must be a date, and if it is ambi guous, F AME interprets the date at the current frequency:

www.fisglobal.com  91  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
SCALAR START:DATE(MONTHLY) = 09M6  
NEW START = 09M 6 
START = 09M6  
The expressions on the right side o f the equals sign in all of the above tr ansformations can be complex; 
the examples were kept simple  for eas e of presentation. The expressions can contain any of FAME’s 
operators or functions  used in an appr opriate context. The expressions can even be condi tional. 
Expressions are described in the  next chapter.  
For creating series, the NEW command uses ma thematic al or logical combinations of existing series. For 
example, the following are equiv alent; each grou p of commands creates a new time series:  
NEW PROFI TS = SALES - EXPENSES  
PROFITS = SALES - EXPENSES  
 
NEW EPS_RATIO = EARNINGS / SHARES  
EPS_RATIO = EAR NINGS / SHARES 
In all of these examples, the series SALES, EXPENSES, EARNINGS, and SHARES m ust already exis t 
and contain data that the NEW command can transf orm into the series PROFITS or EPS_RATIO ; for 
example:

Comparison of the Commands  
There are important differences between the  SERIES and SCAL AR commands on the one hand and the 
NEW command on  the other: 
 The SERIES and SCALAR comman ds create data objects. You must explicitly enter the value s 
for th e data objects.  
 The NEW command creates series and scalars that contain data values . The NEW comman d 
calculates values for the new objects from the v alues of the existing objects.  
The follo wing SERIES and SCALAR commands create a series and a scala r filled  with a missing value 
code:  
SERIES SALES  
SCALAR TAX_RATE  
The following SERIES and S CALAR commands c reate a series and a scalar that contain data valu es that 
you’ve explicitly entered:  
SERIES SALES = 10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60, 70, 80  
SCALAR TAX_RATE = 44% 
The following NEW commands create two series and two scalars that contain transformed  
data; the data is  based on the existing data for the series SALES a nd the scalar 
TAX_RATE:  
NEW X_SALES = SA LES 
NEW ZZ_SALES = SALES * 110%  
NEW X_TAX_RATE = TAX_RATE  
NEW ZZ_TA X_RATE = TAX_RATE / .96  
Or, even more simply:  
X_SALES = SALES  
ZZ_SALES = SALES * 11 0% 
X_TAX_RATE = TAX_RATE 
ZZ_TAX_RATE = TAX_RATE / .96  
The NEW comm and is not equivalent to the SERIES comm and, nor is the NEW command equivalent to 
the SCALAR comman d. Each has its own purpose and can only be used for its own specific application. 
For crea ting series, the  NEW command offers the advantage of being able to  create a series that is the 
result of a  series expression, whereas the SERIES command can only sup ply a li st of scalar expressions 
as the new values.

www.fisglobal.com  93  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Overwriting Data Objects  
The OVERWRITE option takes a b oolean setting as its argument; it is set as eithe r OVERWRITE ON  or 
OVERWRITE OFF . If you specify the option without a setting, FAME assumes OVER ON . 
The OVE RWRITE option enables you to automatically overwrite a pre -existing data object. Th e default, 
OVERW RITE OFF , protects existing data objects from bein g overwritten.  
While the default OVER OF F is in effect, you must use the DELETE command to remove a  data ob ject 
before you can re -use its name for another data object.  
You can specify OVERWR ITE ON  at any le vel of option specification. To protect your data,  you should 
not set OVERWRITE ON  at the global level. It is always safer to use OVERWRITE ON  at the  command -
specific level, or at least at the block level. (The SET command, discussed in the  upcoming chapte r 
ENTER  AND CHANGE DATA  (p. 127), changes values without reference to th e OVERWRIT E option.) 
Only the NEW command allows you to preface a new data object name with  a minus sign ( -) as a 
shorthand method of specifying OVER ON . For example, each of the com mands in the following sets is 
equivalent:  
NEW <OVERWRITE ON> PROFITS = SALES - EXPENSES 
NEW -PROFITS = SALES - EXPENSES  
-PROFITS = SALES – EXPENSES  
 
NEW <OVER ON> EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
NEW -EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
-EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
As you begin t o use the OVERWRITE option, you’ll discover a number of different places where it  can 
save you ti me. However, if you intend merely to store new values i n an existing scalar or series, it is mo re 
efficient to use the SET command.  
Data Objects in t he WORK Da tabase 
In addition to the minus sign, the NEW command gives you the forward slash  (/) to indicate  the WORK 
database.  Only the NEW command allows you to preface a n ew data ob ject name with a forward slash as 
a shorthand method of specifying that the data should be stored  in the temporary WORK database.  
For example, each of t he commands in the following sets is equ ivalent:  
NEW <STORE WORK> PROFITS = SALES - EXPENSES  
NEW WORK'PR OFITS = SALES - EXPENSES  
/PROFITS = SALES – EXPENSES  
 
NEW <OVER ON; STORE WORK> E PS = EARNINGS / SHARES 
NEW <OVER ON> WORK'EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
NEW -/EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
-/EPS = EARNING S / SHARES  
We’ll discuss the STORE option (shown above ) later in  this guide in the chapter  MORE ABOUT 
DATABASES  (p. 222).

www.fisglobal.com  94  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Remember that you lose  all of the objects in the WORK database  when you sign off the FAME system. 
You must explicitl y save obj ects from the WORK database in a permanent database to be able to gain 
access to the data again.  
Formulas  
Data objects that store relationships between series and scalars are called formulas ; you create them 
with the FORMULA command.  
FAME does no t store da ta with a formula, nor does FAME store any data type, such as numeric, 
precision,  string, boolean , date, or namelist. FAME stores the expression itself.  
Data does not exist for the formula unt il FAME uses the formula in a context where it will be  evaluated . At 
that time, FAME checks the formula to see that all the data required for its  evaluation is a vailable and that 
the data is of the appropriate type.  
The TURN FORMULA PROTECTION option enabl es you to determine whether to allow FAME to create 
or modify fo rmulas or global formulas in a version 3 database. This is applicable if you are using FAME 
10.x features in FAME 9.x.  
The FORMULA command has this form : 
FORMULA formula -name = expression  
Cons ider the following sample FAME session:  
* FORMULA PROF IT = SALES  - EXPENSES 
* DISPLAY !PROFIT  
 
PROFIT 
 
SALES – EXPENSES  
 
 
* DISPLAY PROFIT  
 
 
Error: SALES not fou nd 
 
 
* FREQUENCY MONTHLY  
* DATE JAN09 TO *  
* SERIES SAL ES = 124, 108, 127, 132, 145, 156  
* SERIES EXPENSES = 102, 94, 108, 112, 116, 123  
* DISPLAY PR OFIT 
 
PROFIT 
 
Jan 09     22.00  
Feb 09     14.00  
Mar 09     19.00  
Apr 09     20.00  
May 09     29.00 
Jun 09     33.00

If you want to see the definition of a formula , preface the formula name with an excla mation point (!) when 
you use the DISPLAY command.  The DISPLAY c ommand is the on ly command where preceding a 
formula name with an excla mation point has any effect.  
We can defi ne the formula PROFIT before we define the series SALE S and EXPE NSES. 
FAME does not check for any of the data objects until it needs them for the  DISPLAY command , which 
requires values for PROFIT. To continue the ses sion, we’ll delete the time series EXPEN SES and replace 
it with a formula of the same name.  
* DELETE EXP ENSES 
* FORMULA EXPENSES = FIXED + VARIABLE  
* SERIES FIXED = 75 FOR 3, 80 FOR 3  
* SERIES VARIABLE  = 29, 18, 23, 32, 35, 38  
* DISPLAY !EXPENSES  
 
EXPENSES  
 
FIXED + VARIABLE

Feb 09     15.00  
Mar 09     29 .00 
Apr 09     20.00 
May 09     30.00  
Jun 09     38.00  
We used the formula EXPENSES in the evaluation of th e formula PROFIT, and the resultant values for 
PROFIT c hanged accordingly.  
We can change the se ries VARIABLE into a string scalar to see how FAME han dles this “mis-typed” 
formula:  
* SCALAR <OVERWRITE ON> VARIABLE:STRING = "Variable Costs"  
* DISPLAY EXPENSE S 
 
 
Error: Expression contains + operator applied to ty pes NUMERIC and  
STRING 
This demonstratio n should prove to you that FAME defines formulas indep endently o f the data type and 
the data. FAME doesn’t attempt to evaluate the formula until it actually need s the values, and then it uses 
the most recent values a vailable.  
Copying Data Objects  
You can u se the COPY command in two different ways:  
 To copy a d ata object  to a new name in the same database.

www.fisglobal.com  96  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 To copy a data object from one database to a nother. The data  object can keep the old name or 
use a new name when it  is copied to a new database.  
In either case, FAME does not delete the old data object when it  copies th e object. The command uses 
the form:  
COPY oldname AS newname TO database  
In this form, oldname  is the original name of the data object, newname  is the n ew name assigned to the 
copy of the data  object, and database  is the name of the database wher e the new data object is stored. 
Use the following rules with the COPY command:  
 If you specify newname , you are required to use  the AS keyword.  
 If you specify database , you are required to use the TO keyword.  
 You can repe at the spe cification oldname AS newname  and separate the specifications by 
commas.  
 You can omit the TO data base specification. When you omit it, FAME stores the n ew data object 
in the database specified  by the STORE option. (The STORE option is fully descr ibed in th e 
chapter MORE ABOUT DATABASES  (p. 222). In general, the database set to store n ew objects 
is usually the first database  opened for updating in the current session. However, this can b e 
changed with the STORE option.)  
To clarify these concepts, the two following ex amples copy a se ries and give it a new name:  
COPY SALES AS NEWSALES  
This command copies the series named SALES to the first database opened for updating in the curre nt 
session . The new series is named NEWSALES.  
COPY SALES AS SALES1, MYSALES  
This command co pies two series named SALES and MYSALES to the first database opened fo r updating 
in the current session. The n ew copy of SALES is renamed as SALES1. The new copy of  MYSALES 
keeps the name MYSALES.  
If you want to be completely sure where you are storing th e copied data ob jects, you can use the STORE 
option (described in the c hapter MORE ABOUT DATABASES  (p. 222)) before you give the COPY 
command, or you can use the TO database  form of th e COPY command; for example:  
COPY SALES TO SALESBASE  
This command copie s the series named SALES to the SALESBAS E database. The series keeps the 
name SALES in the SAL ESBASE dat abase. 
What if several different databases have data objects with the same names?  You can be cert ain to get 
the right one if you use a database name wit h the name of the data object to be copi ed. For example, to 
uniquely identify the series SALES  from the MYBASE database, you refer to it as MYBASE'SALES. The 
apostrophe (')  ) is the character we use when calli ng a data object by its “full” name. Think of the 
apos trophe as being akin to the apostrophe used to turn a noun into a possessive (for example, the 
miller’s tal e). Then, the COPY command becomes the following:  
COPY MYBASE'SALES TO S_BASE

www.fisglobal.com  97  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
This command uses  the database identifier to copy the series name SALES  from the MYBASE database

Date ranges and case rang es affect series that you copy. If you w ant to be sure to copy all of a series, set

you can set the range at the command -specific level. The following example illustrates the use of a 
command -specific date range:  
COPY <DATE 2007 TO *> MYBASE'SAL ES AS M_SA LES TO T_BASE

handy, particularly when  you work with t ime series that contain many years of history.  
The curr ent frequency does not affect the COPY c ommand. COPY always copies a series at its original 
frequency. W e’ll describe how to copy a series at a different frequency in the chapter  TIME SCALE

www.fisglobal.com  98 EXPRESSIONS  
Expressions allow you to manipulate numeric data, pre cision dat a, string data, namelists, dates, and even 
boolean values. Most sophisticated use rs take advantag e of FAME’s ability to process complex 
expressions. Thi s chapter explains the following concept s: 
 What an expression is and what “expression orientat ion” means . 
 All of the expression operators (**, *, /, +, -, DIV, MOD, INTERSECT, UNION, EX CEPT, 
SUBSET, NO T, AND, OR, EQL, NEL, GT, GE, LT, LE, EQ, and NE).  
 Glob al constants, such as BLANK and QUOTE.  
 The order of precedence for evaluating expressions and executing the expression operators.  
 How to use conditional expressions for “if... then...” logic in express ions. 
 How to subscript a series for a single date or ca se. 
 Implicit looping that FAME automatic ally performs in expressions involving series.  
 What a function i s and how to use one, as well as a quick example of a user -defined function.  
A list of functions appears at the end of this chapter.  
Understanding Expre ssions 
We have occasionally referred to FAME’s “expression orientation.” By expression orienta tion we me an 
that you can use an expression wherever a data value is appropriate. Of course , the result of the 
expression must be appropriate for the context: you  can only offer a numeric expression if FAME expects 
a number, a namelist expression if FAME e xpects a n amelist, and so on.  
FAME’s expression orientation can save you many intermediate steps in your an alyses. For example, if 
FAME lacked expression orientat ion, you would have to enter the followi ng commands:  
PROFIT = SALES - EXPENSES  
GRAPH PROFIT  
Because FAME  has expression orientation, you can skip a step and enter the following command:  
GRAPH SALES - EXPENSES 
If FAME lacked expression orientation, in order  to fit Y as a third order polynomial of  X, you would have to 
enter the following:  
X2 = X**2

www.fisglobal.com  99  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
X3 = X**3  
FIT Y BY X, X2, X3  
Because FAME has expression orientation, you can enter the foll owing:  
FIT Y BY X, X**2, X**3  
FAME does not limit its expression orientation to its handling of numeric and precision data. You can also 
use express ions involving strings, namelists, dates, or boolean values where they are approp riate; for 
examp le: 
SCALAR A:STRING = "Division One Sales:  "  
SCALAR B: STRING = "Division Two Sales:  "  
SCALAR X:STRING = "Actual Values"  
SCALAR Y:STRING = "Fitted V alues" 
PLOT #1 DESCRIPTION A + X  
PLOT #2 DESCRIPTION A + Y  
PLOT #3 DESCRIPTION B + X  
PLOT #4 DESCRIPTION B + Y 
GRAPH ONE_SALES, ONE_SALES.FITT, TWO_SALES, TWO_SAL ES.FITT 
In this example, we use string a rithmetic to create the descriptions that appear on a graph. Mor e 
complicated examples, involving a much greater economy of effort, can be constr ucted for assign ing 
descriptions to series from a loop.  
Using Expressio n Operators  
Expressions incorporate oper ators and operands:  
 Operators include the familiar num erical or mathematical operators, ( such as +, -, *, and / ), logical 
operations (such as OR, AND , and NOT ), and some special FAME operators designed to handle 
dates, strings, namelists, and boolean value s. 
 Operands are the numbers, dates, strings, namelists , and bool ean values that operators 
manipulate.  
FAME uses the following operators: **, *, / , +, -, DIV, MOD , INTERSECT, UNION, EXCEPT, SUBSET, 
NOT, AND, OR, EQL, NEL, GT, GE, LT, LE, EQ, and NE. The ope rators are defined below according to 
the type of data  that resu lts from each operation. Numeric  and precision  results are discussed first, then 
date results, string results, namelist  results, and boolean  results.  
Numeric and Precision Operators  
Operations  producing numeric and precision results include the f ollowing. In the following list, the data 
type of the operands must be numeric or precision . If all of the operands are numeric, the result of the 
expression is n umeric. If any operand is precision, the  result of the operation is precision.  
 + for addition;  for examp le, the expression 100 + 1.01 results in 101.01.   
 - for subtrac tion; for example, the expression 22.2 - 11.0 results in 11.2.   
 * for multiplication; for example, the expressio n 3.1 * 2.2 results in 6.82.  
 / for division; for example, the expression 495 / 11 results in 45.

www.fisglobal.com  100

 ** for exponentiation; for example, the ex pression 2**3 results in 8.0, and the expression 81**0.25 
result s in 3.0.  
 The FORCE NUMERIC opti on is an argument -specific modifier to specify whether  the numbe rs 
appearing as literals should be forced as NUMERIC or remain as PRECISION throu ghout the 
evalua tion of expressions.  
For example,  
DISPLAY <FORCE NUMERI C OFF; DECIMAL 15> 1000.987654321,  5.12 3456789 ,    
(1000.987654321 + 5.123456789)  
DISPLAY <F ORCE NUMER IC ON; DECIMAL 15> 1000.987654321, 5.123456789 ,     
(1000.987654321 + 5.12345678 9) 
Other operati ons that produce numeric or precision results are sign inversion and identity. These 
operations  use the symbols - and + as described below:  
 Unary min us (-) is the negative prefix before a constant; for example, -PI or -99. 
 Unary plus (+) is the positive prefix before a constant; for example, + 100 or +0.1. 
Two other operators that produce numeric and precision results are DIV and M OD. Both operate  
exclusively on numeric and precision data:  
 DIV performs division with truncation of the remain der. DIV s aves the integral part and discards 
the rest; for example, the statement 18 DIV 4  results in 4 an d the statement 10.825 DIV 2.5  also 
results in 4.  
 MOD performs division and saves only the remaind er, or mod ulus; for example, the statement 18 
MOD 4  results in 2, and the statement 10.825 MOD 2.5  results in 0.825.  
One other operation produces a numeric result : date differencing. When you subtract t wo dates of the 
same frequency, the result equals the number of periods separating them; for example, at a monthly 
frequency, 09:3 - 08:2 results  in 13, but at a  quarterly frequency 09:3 - 08:2 results in 5. At a dai ly 
frequency 6MAY 09 - 2MAY 09 results in 4. 
Date Operators  
You can produce date results by addi ng or subt racting a date and an integer.  FAME perfo rms the date 
operation at the current fr equency; for example, at a monthly frequency, the stat ement 09:4 + 3 evaluates 
to 09:7, but at a quarterly frequency, the statement 09:4 + 3 evaluates to 10:3.  
You can use date operators to simplify range setting. Fo r example, if today is Friday, May 6, 19 88, and 
you want to set a range beginning twelve Frida ys ago (th e range will include thirteen dates), you can 
enter the following:  
FREQUENCY WEEK (FRI) 
DATE 2MAY0 8 - 12 TO 2MAY08  
The THISDAY function can make this spe cification even simpler:  
DATE THISDAY(WE EK(FRI)) - 12 TO THISDAY(W(F))  
The THISDAY function re turns toda y’s date at a specified frequency.

Namelist Operators  
Four op erators act on p airs of namelists to produce namelist results:  
 The plus  sign (+) is the simplest namelist opera tor.  It concatenates two namelists without 
removing duplicate entries. For example, {A, B, C}  + {C, D } evaluates to {A, B, C, C, D}.  
 The UNION operator crea tes a new namelist by taking two namelis ts, deleting any entries in the 
second list that dupli cate an en try in the first list, and then appending the remaining entries in the 
second lis t to the first l ist. For example, {A, B, C} UNION  {C, D}  evaluates to { A, B, C, D}.  
 The INTERSECT operator crea tes a new namelist by taking the first namelist and de leting any  
elements that do not appear in the second namelist. For example, {A, B, C} INTER SECT {C, D}  
evaluates to {C}.  
 The EXCEPT operator performs a function c omplementary to the INTERSECT operator. The 
EXCEPT operator creates a new namelist by taking t he first n amelist and deleting any elements 
that appear in the second namelist. {A, B, C} E XCEPT {C, D}  evaluates to {A, B}.  
The following session shows how these  operators work. When we use the TYPE an d DISPLAY 
commands, we must prefix the namelist with t he exclama tion point (!) in order to keep FAME from 
automatically expanding the namelists t hat result from these operations. Note also that the order of the 
namel ists in the expression is important; tha t is, FIRST INTERSECT SECOND is not equivalent to 
SECO ND INTERSE CT FIRST: 
* FIRST = {A, B, C, A}  
* SECOND = {B, D, B, E}

Boolean Opera tors 
There  are twelve operators that produce a boolean result: GT, GE, LT, LE, EQ, NE, EQL,  NEL, SUBSET, 
NOT, AND, and OR. These operators always require that the  two operands be of the same data type, 
except for NOT, which is the unary (or negation) opera tor. 
With Numeric, Precision, Date, or String Data  
You can use the GT, GE, LT, LE, EQ, and NE operators to compare pairs of numeric, precision, date, or 
string da ta objects. These operators are describe d below:  
 GT for greater than ; for example, the express ion 7 GT 5  and the expression 6MAY 08 GT 
1MAY 07 are both true.  
 GE for greater than or equal to; for example,  the expression 6.5 GE 6.5  and the expression 
6MAY 08 GE  1MAY08 are both true.

 LT for less than ; for example, the expression 11 LT 101  and the express ion 1MAY 07 LT 6MAY08 
are both true.  
 LE for less than or equal to ; for example, the expressi on 101 LE 101  and the expression 1MAY 87 
LT 5MAY 97 are both true.  
 EQ for  equal; for example, the expression 55 EQ 55  is true while the expression 5MAY 08 EQ 
6MAY 07 is false.  
 NE for not equal ; for example, the expression 1000 NE -1 and the expression 5MAY 08 NE 
6MAY 07 are bot h true. 
The results are obvious for comparisons of numb ers or dates, for example:  
* TYPE 2**3 G T 3**2 
FALSE 
 
* FREQUENCY MONTHLY  
* TYPE 08:1 LT 07:4  
FALSE 
 
* TYPE 08:1 GT 07:4  
TRUE 
 
* TYPE 08:1 EQ 07:4  
FALSE 
The results for strings aren’t q uite as easy to interpret. With strings, FAME translates each character  into 
its machine representation, then c ompares each string, one character at a time, until it  finds a d ifference. 
If FAME does not find a difference, then the strings are equal. If FAM E finds a differ ence, then it 
considers the string with the higher valu ed character to be greater than the othe r string. FAME does not 
consider the length of the str ings unles s they are otherwise identical, in which case the longer string is 
greater.  
In AS CII representati on, FAME ranks the numbers and letters so that the numb ers 0 through 9 are less 
than the upperc ase letters, which are less than the lowercase letters . The symb ols are scattered 
throughout the list.  
NE and EQ comparisons of strings are quite  common; the oth er comparisons are seldom used. The 
following examples show why the other operators aren’t used : 
* TYPE "Z" GT "ALUMINUM"  
TRUE 
 
* TYPE "Tuesday" LT " Thursday"  
FALSE 
 
* TYPE "a" GT "Z"  
TRUE 
 
* TYPE "A" GE "9"  
TRUE

With Namelist Data  
For name lists, FAME make s a special set of operators available to you. These op erators can be divided 
into two classes:  those that sort the namelists and purge the duplicate s (EQL, NE L, and SUBSET), and 
those that do not sort the lists (EQ and NE):  
 The EQL operato r sorts the name lists and deletes any duplicate entries before making t he 
comparison. EQL tests for equality of  the two resultant lists. For example, the expression {A, B, 
A} EQL {A, B, B}  is true. Think of EQL as meaning equal as a list  or equivalent . 
 The EQ operator doe s not sort the namelists before making the comparison. EQ tests for equality 
of the two lists e xactly as you present them. For example, the expressio n {A, B, C , D} EQ {D, C, 
A, B}  is false.  
 The NEL operator sorts the namelists and deletes a ny duplicate ent ries before making the 
comparison. NEL tests for inequa lity of the two resultant lists. For exa mple, the expression {A, B, 
C} NEL {C, B, B}  is true. Think of N EL as meaning not equal as a list  or not equivalent . 
 The NE operator does not sor t the namelists before making the comparison. NE tests for 
inequality o f the two lists exactly as you present t hem. For example, the expression {A, B, C, D} 
NE {A, A , B, B}  is true. 
 The SUBSET operator sorts the namelists and deletes any duplicate entries before making th e 
comparison. SUBSET tests whether the first namelist i s a subset of the second. For example, t he 
expression {A, B, C, C} SUBSET {A, B, C, D}  is true . 
The foll owing examples illustrate each of these operators:  
 
* SCALAR LIST_ONE:NAMELIST = {A, B, C, D}  
* SCALAR LIST_TWO:NAMELIST = {A, C, B, D, B, B, C}

FALSE

TRUE 
 
* TYPE LIST_ONE NE LIST_TWO  
TRUE 
 
* TYPE LIST_ONE NEL LIST_TWO  
FALSE 
 
* TYPE LIST_ONE SUBSET LIST_TWO  
TRUE 
 
* TYPE LIST_T WO SUBSET LIST_O NE 
TRUE 
 
* TYPE LIST_TWO SUBSET {A, B, C, D, E}  
TRUE 
 
* TYPE {A, B, C, D, E} SUBSET LIST_TWO  
FALSE

With Boolea n Data  
For boolean data, FAME makes the following set of operato rs available to you:  
 The EQ operator checks to see if boolean values are equal; f or example TRUE EQ FALSE  is 
false.  
 The NE operator checks to see if boo lean values are unequal; for example TRUE NE FALSE  is 
true. 
 The NOT operator is a unary operat or; it neg ates whatever follows. For example, NOT YES EQ  
NO is true.  
 The OR operator is the  logical or. Its  result is true if either of the boolean values being t ested is 
true; for example, YES OR NO  is true, NO OR NO  is false.  
 The AND o perator is the logical and. Its result is true only if both values being tested a re true; for 
example, YES AND YES  is true, NO AND NO  is false.  
We’ll de monstrate the boolean operators below:

FALSE 
You can also use the EQ and NE operators with boo lean data object s to produce boolean results.  
Operations with boolean r esults are very useful in system buildin g in FAME. You can use boolean results 
to facilitate t he conditi onal execution of expressions.

Operator Precedence  
Because you can specify several operators in a s ingle expression, FAME has established rules of 
preced ence to de termine the sequence of evaluation for the operators.  
For example, what is the re sult of the foll owing expression?

www.fisglobal.com  109  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
17 DIV 2**4 - 1 
Depending on the sequ ence of operations, the expression’s res ult could be 4095, 512, 2, 1, or 0.  
FAME uses three ru les of pre cedence. They are applied in the order given below.  
Look for Parentheses  
FAME per forms operations  enclosed in parentheses first. If you nest the parenth eses, FAME performs the 
innermost operat ion first; for example:  
5*((3-2)/(7-5)) 
In this expres sion, FAME  performs the operations 3-2 and 7-5 first, then FAME calculates the ratio. As th e 
last step, FAM E multiplies the ratio by 5. The result is 2.5.  
Use the  Level of Precedence  
If an expression co ntains operators without parentheses, FAME performs th e operatio ns according to the 
precedence level. FAME divides the operators into seven level s of precedence:  
Table 10. Level of precedence  
Precedence Level  Operator  
1 & 
2 ** 
3 *, /, DIV, MOD, INTERSECT  
4 +, -, UNION, EXCEPT  
5 GT, GE, LT,  LE, EQ, NE, EQL, NEL, SUBSET  
6 NOT  
7 AND  
8 OR 
FAME performs operations so th at operators at the top of the list are used before operators at the bo ttom 
of the list; for example, operators  with a precedence of 1 are performed before operators  with a 
precedence of 2:  
5*4-2**4 
In this expression, FAME performs the exponentiation firs t, then the mult iplication, and, finally, the 
subtraction. The result i s 4.

www.fisglobal.com  110  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Work from Left to Right  
If an expre ssion contains operators without parentheses and at th e same lev el of precedence, FAME 
executes the operators of the same level in order, from le ft to right; for  example:  
7-3*2+4 
In this expression, FAME performs the  multiplication first (using the level o f precedence), followed by the 
subtraction, and then t he additio n (working from left to right). The result is 5.  
The exception to this rule is th e operator **, w hich is evaluated from right to left; for example:  
3**2**2 
The result is 81 since 2**2 evaluate s to 4 and 3**4 evaluates to 81.  
Using Conditional Exp ressions  
FAME identifies conditional expressions by the IF, THEN, and ELSE conditional oper ators and one or  
more logical tests within the expression. Conditional expressions use the following form:  
command IF boolean -expression THEN simple -expression ELSE simple-expression 
or 
   command IF boolean -expression THEN simple -expression &&  
      ELSE IF boolean -expression THEN simple -expression &&  
      ELSE simple -expression 
This expression is not an IF comma nd; it is an expression that you substitute wherever F AME expect s an 
expression. (We discuss the IF command in the FAME S YSTEM  BUILDING  USER GUIDE) In this form,  
command  is a FAME command, such as NEW, REPORT, or GRA PH. 
You can include any number of ELSE I F boolean -expression THEN simple -expression  segments i n the 
cond itional expression.  
By simple -expression , we mean any expression that is not cond itional. In fact , you can use a conditional 
expression enclosed in pare ntheses as a simple -expression . 
When FAM E evaluates the conditional expression, it tests each boolean -expression in order until it 
encounters the first true result. At the first true boolean -expression , FAME executes the simple -
expression  associated with t he THEN statement. If FAME does not enco unter a true boolean -expression , 
FAME executes the simple-expres sion associated with the ELSE statement.  
For example, the following command uses a conditional ex pression to create a series:  
NEW TAX = IF EARNINGS LE 0  THEN 0 ELSE 48% * EARNINGS  
In this case , if EARNINGS is zero or negative, no taxes are due; o therwise, TAX is 48% of EARNINGS. 
We can add a few more tests to the same example:  
NEW TAX = IF EARNINGS LE  0 THEN 0 &&  
          ELSE IF EARNINGS LE 20K THEN 25%  * EARNINGS &&

www.fisglobal.com  111  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
          ELSE IF EARNING S LT 50K THEN 35% * EARNINGS &&  
          ELSE 48% * E ARNINGS 
In this example, if EARNINGS is less than or equal to zero, then TAX is 0. If EARNI NGS is less than  or 
equal to $20,000 (but greater than zero), then TAX is 25% of earnings. If EARNINGS is less than $50,000 
(but greater than $20,000), then TAX is 3 5% of EARN INGS. Otherwise, (if EARNINGS is greater than or 
equal to $50,000) TAX is 48% of EARNINGS.  
If you  are making a bar graph to show profits, you may want t o draw black bars for profits and red ba rs for 
losses. To separate the time series for profits  and losse s, you could use the following commands:  
NEW POSITIVE = IF PROFITS GE 0 THEN PROF ITS ELSE ND  
NEW NEGATIVE = IF PROFITS LT 0 THEN PROFITS ELSE ND  
GRAPH POSITIVE <PLOT BLACK, DRAW BAR, STACK ON> , && 
   NEGATIVE <PLOT RED, DRAW BAR, STACK ON>  
These conditiona l expressions create a series with positive values when PROFITS are greater than zero 
and a serie s with negative values when PROFITS are less than zero.  Note that the ND value assigned 
conditi onally to POSITIVE and NEGATIVE is a missing data code . We’ll di scuss missing data later in this 
guide.  
Another approach, that does not require y ou to generate a dditional data objects in your database, 
appears below.  In this example, the GRAPH command acce pts conditional expressions that correspond 
to the POS ITIVE and NEGATIVE objects created in the last example. We’ve underlined the conditional 
expressions for em phasis:  
GRAPH IF PROFITS GE 0 THEN PROFITS ELSE ND  <PLOT BLACK, &&  
   DRAW BAR, STACK ON>, IF PROFITS LT 0 THEN PROFITS ELSE ND  && 
   <PLOT RED, DRAW  BAR, STAC K ON> 
You can use conditional expressions for a number of applications, including  setting case or  date ranges. 
To determine the number of missing values  in a series, enter a sequence of statem ents such as the 
following:  
* CASE 1 TO 10  
* DISPLAY M YSERIES 
 
 
MYSERIES

    2     200.00  
    3         NA  
    4     400.00  
    5         NC  
    6     500.00  
    7         ND  
    8         NA  
    9     800.00 
   10         ND  
 
* SCALAR MI SSING_COUNT  
* SET MISSING_COUNT = SUM (IF MISSING (MYS ERIES) THE N 1 ELSE 0) 
* TYPE MISSING_COUNT  
5.00 
We’ll discuss the SUM and MISSING functions  later in this s ection.

Subscripting Series  
A subscript is a date or a case number enclosed in brackets ([ ]) t hat follows the series name. You can 
subscript time se ries and c ase series in either of two ways to identify individual values:  
 You can subscript  a series with a  date or case number to identify one specific observati on. 
 You can subscript an object with a relative  subscript. The subscript T is used for time se ries and 
the subscript  N is used for case series.  
We will demonstrate several subscripts in  the following c ommands. Note that when we use a date 
subscript, it mus t be unambiguous or it must be a date at  the current frequency.  
* TYPE INNING[3]  
4.00 
* TYPE S ALES[08:1]  
 
 
Error: Series SALES indexed by QUARTERLY given index expression of type ANNUAL  
 
 
* TYPE SALES[ 08Q1] 
34.53 
* TYPE <FREQ QUARTER> SALES [08:3]  
40.80 
In the first command, INNING is a case ser ies. In the second command, SALES[08:1] fails because it is 
an ambiguous date interpreted at the default annual frequency. However, the last two examples work 
because they offer unambiguous dates.  
The relative subscr ipts, T for time series and N for case s eries, can be used to lead or lag data, or as 
control parameters  in implicit loops; for example:  
* FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
* DATE 08Q1 TO 08Q4  
* REPORT SALES, SALES[ T-1] 
 
 
             08:1   08:2   08:3   08:4  
            -----  -----  -----  ----- 
SALES       34.53  38.66  40.80  42.45  
SALES[T-1]  33.29  34.53  38.66  40 .80 
In this case, SALES[T -1] is simply SALES (or SALES[T]) lagged by one period. FAME uses the in dex T to 
represent the current period; therefore, T -1 means one period ago; T+3 means three per iods in the future. 
Similarly, FAME uses the index N to represen t the current case number; therefore, N -1 means the 
previous case; N+3 means thre e cases later.  
In keeping with FAME’s expression orientation, you can u se a date -valued expression of the corre ct 
frequency to subscript a time series, and a numeric  or precis ion expression to subscript a case series. T 
or N can be used in such expressions  to designate th e time period or case number in the result series. 
For example, the following sequence copies t he values for the 12 months of 2010 of the series 
MONT HLY_SERIES  into the first 12 cases of the series CASE_SERIES:  
CASE 1 to 12  
NEW CASE_SERIES = MONTHLY_SERIES [ DEC09 + N]

Using Implicit Looping  
Any time FAME perfo rms an operation on one or more series, it executes an implicit loop using the 
relative subscr ipts T or N. For example, when you issue the command DISPLAY SALES - EXPENSES  
for the eight  quarters of 200 8 and 2009, FAME performs the operations one quarter at  a time, from 
beginning to end, as thoug h it were in a loop. That is, FAME calculates and disp lays the f ollowing: 
SALES[08Q1] - EXPENSES[08Q1]  
SALES[08Q2] - EXPENSES[08Q2]  
SALES[08Q3] - EXPENSES[08Q3]  
SALES[08Q4] - EXPENSES[08Q4]  
SALES[09Q1] - EXPENSES[09Q 1] 
SALES[09Q2] - EXPENSES[09Q2]  
SALES[09 Q3] - EXPENSES[09Q3]  
SALES[09Q4] - EXPENSES[09Q4]  
This sequence of operations is equivalent to (but far more efficient than) the following valid FAME LOOP 
comman d: 
LOOP FOR MYDATE = 08Q1 TO 09Q4  
   DISPLAY SALES[MYDA TE] - EXPENSES[MYDATE]  
END LOOP  
In this command sequence, MYDATE is called the index of the lo op. The da tes 08Q1 and 09Q4 specify 
the beginning and ending values for the loop.  
In most p rogramming langu ages, loops use integers as the beginning and ending va lues. However, 
FAME offers the special c apability to loop through dates. In FAME, the operatio n is perfo rmed as a loop, 
without requiring that a loop be explicitly defined; therefore, i t is called an implicit loop . 
Because of implicit looping, the two foll owing commands produce different results : 
SET SALESPLAN = SALES[T -1] * 1.10  
SET SALES = SALES[ T-1] * 1.1 0 
We’ll discuss the SET command more completely later in this guide. For now, all  you need to kno w is that 
the SET command changes the data values store d in scalars and series without changing  anything else.  
The first SET command makes each value  in the se ries named SALESPLAN 10% larger than the 
previous period’s value of the series na med SALES. The s econd SET command establishes a 10% 
growth rate for SAL ES based on the value of the period imme diately before the first period of the current 
date ra nge. 
The f ollowing FAME session should make the difference between these statements clear:  
* FREQUENCY QUAR TER 
* DATE 08Q1 TO 08Q4  
* SERIES REVENUE = 200, 225, 23 0, 240 
* SERIES REVENUE_PLAN  
* DATE 08Q2  TO 09Q1 
* SET REVENUE_PLAN = REVENUE[T -1] * 1.10  
* SET REVENUE = REVENUE[T-1] * 1.10  
* DATE 08Q1 TO 09Q1  
* REPORT REVENUE, REVENUE_PLAN  
 
                08:1    08:2    08:3    08:4    09:1

www.fisglobal.com  114  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
              ------  ------  ------  ------  ------ 
REVENUE       200.00  220.00  242.00  266.20  292.82  
REVENUE_PLAN      ND  220.00  247.50  253.00  264.00  
 
The values for the series REVENUE are equal to the  first value of REVENUE successively multiplied by 
110%. Note that the lagged series automatically “pierces” th e beginning of the date range to get the data 
value it  needs to start the series of values.  
The values for the series REVENUE_PLAN are equal to t he lagged values  of the initial REVENUE series 
multiplied by 110%. Agai n, the lagged series automatically “pier ces” the beginning of the date range to 
get the data v alue it ne eds to start the series of values.  
The implicit looping capability becomes especi ally valuable wh en you want to “grow” a series at a 
particular rate. To  “grow” a series, set the initial value,  specify an appropriate closed range, and define an 
expression t hat uses the same name for the series on both sides of the equal sign.  
Introducti on to Functions  
Functions are closely related to operators and are freq uently used in expressions. FAME offers a wide 
variety of functions that fill many different n eeds. Some  functions perform arithmetic operations, some 
functions perform string manipulat ions, some funct ions convert data types, and so on.  
A function uses a name which  you cannot abbreviate. Most functions take one or mor e argument s that 
are enclosed in parentheses following the function name.  
One simple functi on, SQRT, determ ines the square root of an expression. It’s demonstrate d below:  
DISPLAY SQRT(A**2 + B**2)  
In this example, SQRT is the function name. The expression A**2 + B** 2 is the argument.  
You can use functions to generate new series and scalars; for example:  
NEW PCT_CHG_SALES = PCT(SALES)  
This NEW command creates a seri es based on the observation -to-observati on changes associated with 
the time series SALES.  
Note  You can a lways obtain information about functions by using the FAME O NLINE  HELP to display  
lists of functi ons organized by topic.  
On the following pages, we pres ent an alphabetical table of FAME functi ons. The table names the 
function, provides a brief de scription of its purpose, tells the kind of inputs it uses, and tells the kind of 
value tha t it returns.  
This table is meant only as a guide to functions; it is n ot a complete list, nor does it offer co mplete 
information about the functions. For details on  the argum ents and uses of each function, consult the 
FAME ONLINE  HELP. 
Every function argu ment, except tho se that are special values defined for the function, ca n be replaced by 
an expression. In the l ist, if the data type of a function argument is unrest ricted (fo r example if it just says 
date, as opposed to date scalar ), then you can use eith er a scalar or a  series expression.

User -defined Functions  
You can write user -defined  functions to suit your needs. To create your own function, follow the same 
steps as for writing a procedure:  
First, use an editor to create a text file containing t he functio n’s source code. The file M YFUNC.PRO 
contains the source code for the function MY _SUM: 
* EXHIBIT MYFUNC.PRO  
 
 
FUNCTION MY_SUM  
ARGUMENT FIRST_VALUE, SECO ND_VALUE 
LOCAL SCALAR TOTAL_VALUE = FIRS T_VALUE + SECOND_VALUE  
RETURN TOTAL_VALUE  
END FUNCTION

www.fisglobal.com  126  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The MY_SU M function accepts two argu ments and returns a scalar value.  
Second, compile the source file with the COMPILE command:  
* COMPILE MYFUNC  
 
Procedure sourc e file is: D$1:[0000TKB.BASICS2]MYFUNC.P RO; 
 
Function MY_SUM  
 
Errors: 0  
Warnings: 0  
 
Total of 0 Errors a nd 0 Warnings 
 
Procedure co de file is: D$1:[0000TKB.BASICS2]MYFUNC.PC;  
Once you h ave compiled a file, you can skip the second step. You don’t need to co mpile it again unless 
you change the sou rce code or you switch to a new release of FAME. FAME calls the files “procedure” 
files bec ause both functions and procedures may appear in them.  
Third, load the compiled file with the LOAD command:  
* LOAD MYFUNC  
Note Alternatively, you can use the CLOAD c ommand to compile the specified source code and 
load t he resulti ng compiled code. The CLOAD  command can be used instead of the COMPILE 
and LOAD c ommands.  
Fourth, use your function just as you would use one of FAME’s own functions:  
* DISPLAY MY_SUM (1.1, 3. 2) 
 
MY_SUM (1.1, 3.2)

keywords used to restric t the class of an argument.  
For more information about user -defined fun ctions, consult the FAME C OMMAND  REFEREN CE. The process 
of creating user -defined commands, or procedures , is very similar. Procedur es are described briefly in the 
chapter  PROCEDURES  (p. 265) and in considerable detail in the  SYSTEM  BUILDING  USER GUIDE

www.fisglobal.com  127 ENTER  AND CHANGE DATA  
In just  about e very application, t here comes a time when you must add new data values to  an existing 
data object or you must change previous values. FAME gives you a number of ways to perform these 
tasks:  
 The UPDATE command allows you to enter one or mo re values for a se ries, or prompts yo u for 
values for one or more series. By using the REVI EW option, along with a number of special 
updating expressions, you can view  and change the values in the series.  
 The SET command changes one or more of the values o f a series  or scal ar with a single 
command.  
 The MODIFY command changes formulas.  
 The RENAME  command changes a data object’s name.  
 The DELETE command removes data objec ts from a database. If you use a wildcar d 
specification or a namelist with the DELETE com mand, you can conf irm the deletion of  individual 
data objects.  
This chapter discusses these  commands and ends with a special discussion of how you can change the 
frequ ency or index type of a series.  
Updating  Series  
You can use the UPDATE command to enter o ne or more  values into existing serie s. You cannot use the 
UPDATE command to create new ser ies. There are several different ways to use the UPDATE command:  
 You can spe cify the updated value or values for a s eries with the UPDATE command or allow the 
UPDATE  command t o prompt  you for the update d value or values.  
 You can update several series of th e same index and frequency at the same time. Again, you can 
specify the upda ted value or values with the UPDATE comm and or allow the UPDATE command 
to prompt you for  the updat ed value s. 
 Using the REVIEW  option, you can view the current values of series, an d then keep the values or 
change them as necessary.  
 Using the special keywor ds available with the UPDATE command pro mpts, you can move 
through the data, and offer so me express ions to change and manipula te data.  
You must open the database with write access (ACCESS SHARED  or ACCESS UPDATE ) before you 
can change data values in the da tabase. 
The UPDATE command uses the form  UPDATE series = value -list for one or more serie s. The = value-
list phrase is optiona l, as described below.

www.fisglobal.com  128  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Updating a Single Series  
After you set a date range or a case range, you can update a series of values on t he same line as the 
UPDATE command. Exam ples of updating a numeric series, a string serie s and a da te serie s follow:  
UPDATE NU M_SERIES = 10, 20, 30, 40, 50  
UPDATE STRING_SERIES = " First", "Second", "Third", "Fourth", &&  
    "Fifth" 
UPDATE <FREQUENCY MONTH LY> DATE_SERIES = MAY06, JUN06, JAN07, F EB07, DEC09  
In the second example, we had to put quotes (")  around the individual stri ngs so that FAME knew we 
were entering five separate s trings. Without quotes, the system would try to interpret First as a data ob ject 
name.  
In the last example, we speci fied the frequency at the command -specific level before ent ering mo nthly 
dates for the  series.  
If you enter the UPDATE command without a lis t of values for a series, FAME prompts you to enter 
values over the current date range or case range. We show the up dating of another numeric series, string 
series, and date s eries: 
* SERIES NUM_SERIES2  
* SERIES STRING_SERIES2:STRING  
* SERIES DATE_SERIES2: DATE(MONTHLY) BY CASE  
* DATE 2005 TO 2009  
* CASE 1 TO 5  
* UPDATE NUM_SERIES2

2009 > 57K  
 
* DATE 2005 TO *  
* UPDATE STRING_S ERIES2 
 
STRING_SERIES2  
 
2005 > One Thing and Another  
2006 > "Still more" for 2  
2007 > "Save", "Help"  
2009 > Save  
 
* UPDATE DATE_SERIES2  
 
DATE_SERIES2  
 
    1 > JUN06 
    2 > JUN07  
    3 > JUL08, AUG 08 
    5 > SEP09  
Several important things happen in this sa mple FAM E session:

www.fisglobal.com  129

 With all  three sets of updating prompts, we entered more than one numeric value, string, or date 
for one of the prompts. When you do this,  FAME keeps track of the number of value s that you 
enter and offers the next correct date  prompt or  case pr ompt. You can alway s enter any number 
of values for each series on a sing le line. 
 FAME uses the current date range or case range for the prompting se quence. The UPDATE 
command requires the current range to be closed on the left, but it ma y be open on the r ight; for 
example, DATE 04 TO 10, or DATE 97 TO * , or CASE 17 TO * . The r ange DATE * TO 11 is not 
permitted because it is open on the left. However, if you want to enter data last -to-first, you can 
use a backwards date range with the UPDA TE command ; for ex ample DATE 03 TO * STEP -1. 
The UPDATE command stops prompting you for va lues when it reaches the end of the range. 
The command does not affect value s outside the working range.  
 If you ente r a single string for each prompt, you do not hav e to put q uotes ar ound each string. 
Use a comma to delimit multiple strings entered on a li ne; that is , when you enter values for 
several periods at one time. Use quot ation marks around a string to 1) preser ve leading or trailing 
blanks, 2) incorporate a c omma in th e string , 3) use a repetiti on statement such as FOR 5 , or 4) 
begin a string with a keyword meaningful to UPDATE, such as SAVE . Note that SAVE  caused 
FAME  to save the series without prompting for a value for 2010 . 
Updating Multiple Series  
In addit ion to upd ating a single series, you can use the UPDATE command to update several series at  
one time.  
When you update more than one series at a time, you may supply va lues with the command if all series 
are of the same type. In this case, all the series wi ll be give n the sa me set of values. M uch more common 
is the use of the FAME prompting seque nce. All the series must be of the same index (either DATE or 
CASE) and upda ted over the same range. Time series mus t have the same frequency (daily, monthly, or 
annual, for e xample).  As shown below, th e series can be of different types (numeric, precision , string,

Keyw ords and Phrases for Entering Data  
The UPDATE com mand gives  you a n umber of special ke ywords and phrases that you can use while 
entering val ues at the updating prompt. We describe the most commonly used keywords and phrases 
below:  
 The value FOR n  and the value FOR *  phrases specify a value and the number  of times that 
FAM E repeats the value . For example, if you respond 100 FOR 10 to an update prompt, FAME 
fills the next ten data values with 100. If you want to fill a series to the end of the working range 
with a single value, you specify an asterisk (*) f or the num ber. For  example, you can s pecify 
“None” for *  in response to an updating prompt to fill a string series with None . 
 The SAME  keyword leaves a data value unch anged. 
 The SAVE  keyword ends the current  UPDATE prompting sequence and stores the values that 
you’v e entere d so far. You’ll fi nd the SAVE  keyword helpful for ending and saving resp onses 
before you reach the end of a prompting sequence. When you are updatin g multiple series, you 
can only enter th e SAVE  keyword as the first value in response to a prompt.  
 The QUIT  keyword ends the c urrent UPDATE prompting sequence and discards the valu es that 
you’ve entered in the current sequence. Use the QUIT  keyword when yo u’ve made a mistake and

www.fisglobal.com  132  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
want to start th e prompting sequence again. When you are updating  multiple series, you can only 
enter the QUIT  keyword as the first value in response to a p rompt. 
 The DOWN  n phrase moves you n periods through a series toward the end  of the range to allow 
you to enter more  values. For example, if you enter DOWN 5  at the 2003 promp t, FAME moves 
you down five  periods to prompt you for the 2008 data. When you are  updating multiple series, 
you can only enter the DOWN n  phrase as the first  value in response to a prompt.  
 The UP n  phrase moves you n periods through a series towa rd the beg inning o f the range to 
allow you to enter more values. For example, if you enter UP 6 at the 2009 prompt, FAME moves 
you up five periods to prompt you for th e 2003 data. When you are updating multi ple series, you 
can only enter the UP n  phrase as  the first  value i n response to a pro mpt. 
 The HELP  keyword displays all of the available up dating keywords and phrases. When you are 
updating multiple series, you can only enter the HELP  keyword as the first  value in response to a 
prompt.

Phrases for Man ipulating Data 
In addition to the upd ating keywords and phrases listed above, the UPDATE co mmand accepts five 
phrases that allow you to manipulate the values in a seri es: 
 ADD numeric -value  adds a numeric val ue to the value cu rrently stored in t he series. If you specify 
FOR n  as part of the phrase,  FAME repeats the addition for a total of n observations.  
For example, if yo u enter ADD 10 FOR 4 , FAME adds 10 to th e current data value and the next 
three values. I f the valu es start  out as 1, 2, 3, an d 4, they become 11, 12, 13, and 14.  
 INCR numeric -value  adds a numeric value to the value of the previous observation (e ither N -1 or 
T-1) in the series to determine the current ob servatio n’s data value. You  can use FOR n  as part 
of the phrase to specify the nu mber of times that FAME repeats the incrementing process.  
For example, if yo u enter INCR 10 FOR 4 , FAME adds 10 to t he previous observation’s value, 
and then adds 10  to the re sult, an d so on. If the pre vious observation’s value is 100, the current 
observat ion’s value becomes 110, and the next three values are 120, 130, and 140, re gardless of 
their former values.  
 MULT n umeric -value multi plies the current o bservation’s value by numeric -value  to determine the 
new value. If you specify FOR n as part of the phrase, FAME performs the mult iplication for a 
total of n observations .

www.fisglobal.com  134  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
For example, if you enter MULT 10 FOR 3 , FAME m ultiplies the curr ent observation’s v alue and 
the next two values by 10; if the values star t out as 11, 12, and 13, they become 110, 120, and 
130. 
 GROW numer ic-value  specifies that numeric -value  is a simple  growth fa ctor. FA ME multiplies the 
value of the previous observation (T -1 or N -1) by the g rowth factor to determine a growth 
increment. Once the growth increment is c alculated, GROW behaves like INCR. The g rowth 
increment is added to the value of the prev ious obser vation ( T-1 or N-1) to dete rmine the current 
observation’s value. If you specify FOR n as part of the phrase, FAME adds the growth increment 
through a total of n observations.  
For example, if the p revious observation’s value is 10 and you specify  GROW  .5 FOR 3, the next 
three values  are 15, 20, and 25, regardless of their former values . 
 CGROW numeric -value  specifies that numeric -value  is a compound growth factor. FAME adds 
numeric -value  to 1 to de termine th e compou nd growth rate, the n multiplies the value of the 
previous observation (T -1 or N-1) by the compound growth rate to determine the current 
observation’s  value. If you specify FOR n  as part of the phrase, FAME performs the compounding 
growth operation through a total of n observ ations.  
For example, if the previous observation’s val ue is 10 and you specify CGROW .5 FOR 3 , the 
next three values are 15, 22.5 and 33.75, regardless of their former va lues. Compare these 
values to the values obtained  with the simple g rowth rate set with  the GROW phrase described 
above.

Changing Values  
With the UPDATE command, you can enter one or mo re values for an existing series, or all ow FAME to 
prompt you for one or more values. Wit h the SET command,  you can change the  value of an existing 
scalar or one or more values of an existing series.  
The command uses the form: SET object -name = expression . 
Hint When you use the SET command with a scalar, it offers little more than an alternati ve to the 
SCALAR c omm and. But when yo u use the SET command with a series, it allows you to 
quickly change one or many values without affecting the others.  
You must ope n the database with write access ( ACCESS  UPDATE  or ACCESS SHARED ) before you 
can change t he value f or a sca lar or series in th e database.  
This simple example shows how to create a scalar and how to change its value with the SET command:  
SCALAR TAX_RATE = 4 6% 
SET TAX_RATE = 35%

www.fisglobal.com  136  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Users often invoke  the SET command to specify the values for nameli sts: 
SET MYLIST = {SERIES_1, SERIES_2 , SERIES_3}  
SET CARLIST = {CHRYSLER, FORD, GM, HONDA, MAZDA} 
Note that you do not need to preface the namelist name with an exclam ation point to keep it from 
expanding. A  namelist cannot expand in this context, because the SET co mmand ca n take only a singl e 
name.  
The SET command gives you several very special  capabilities. You can set individual values in a series 
by subscripting the m with a date or case reference in squar e brackets:  
SET STATE[15] = "Iowa"  
SET PARTS.INV[ 83M2] = 22 6 
With a  single SET command , you can change many values in a series. For example,  you can easily enter 
a year’s worth of monthly rent payments:  
FREQUENCY MON THLY 
DATE JAN07 TO DEC07  
SET RENT = 11.2 K 
The SET command can assign the results of an ex pression t o a seri es. The following e xample shows an 
alternative to the UPDATE command for growing a series:  
FREQUENCY A  
DATE 90 TO 95  
SET SALES = 1.08 * SALES[T -1] 
A company projecting its commission paymen ts for the next year could use the following SET command:  
DATE 2007 
SET COMMISSIONS = .03 * PROD_A_VOL * PROD_A_PRICE + .05 * PROD_B_VOL * & & 
    PROD_B_PRICE + .12 * PROD_C_VOL * PROD_C_PRICE  
If a special promotion were scheduled for the summer, with comm ission raised to 15% for product B, the 
revised c ommissions  would b e: 
DATE JUN07 TO AU G07 
SET COMMISSIONS = COMMISSIONS + 10% * PROD_B_VOL *  PROD_B_PRICE  
This adds the extra 10% commission for product B to the 5% alr eady calculated.  
At some time, you may b e faced with a situation where you’ve stored the data of a single t ime series in 
sever al series with non -overlapping ranges, but you need th e data in a single series. You can work 
around the problem by using the SET command and the OVERLAY function.  
For ex ample, assume that you have four monthly series c alled SALE S06, SAL ES07, SALES08, and 
SALES09. The following commands correctly combine thes e four series into the series NEWSALES, 
which contains 48 months of data:  
DATE 06 TO 09  
SERIES NEWSALES  
SET NEWSALES  = OVERLAY( SALES06, SALES07, SALES08, SALES09)

www.fisglobal.com  137  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Of course, you coul d have used the NEW  command instead of the SET command. You should 
rememb er, however, that the SCALAR, SERIES, NEW, SET, and UPDATE commands share so me 
capabilities but are not interchangea ble: 
 The SCALAR, SERIES, and NEW commands create data objec ts with data that you assig n at the 
time that you create them.  
 The SET and UPDATE  commands assign data values to existing scalars and series. They cannot 
create an object.  
Also note that for series , the SERIES and non -prompting UPDATE commands as sign value s based on a 
list of scalar  expressions or constants (one for each period), while  the NEW and SET commands assign 
values based on a single series expression evaluated over the working range. The fo llowing table shows 
when you should use each comm and: 
                                                                                          Creating a series  Updating a series  
                              Using a list of scalars                            SERIES                          UPDATE  
                              Using a series  expression                     NEW                               SET 
If you write systems, bear in mind that it is faster for FAME to modify an existing series with UPDATE  or 
SET than it is to overwrite it with SERIES or  NEW (with  OVERWRI TE ON).  
Changing Fo rmulas  
Just as you can change the data stored in scala rs and series with the SET command, so you can change 
formulas with the MODI FY command. The MODIFY command redefines  an existing formula without 
changing any of its other attr ibutes, such as its descrip tion. 
If you intend merely to reuse the name, but to c hange everything else related to a formula, you might as 
well use the FORMUL A command and specify OVERWRITE ON . Even  so, MODIFY is more efficient, so 
take this into account wh en you d esign systems.  
The MODIFY command is identical in form to the FORMULA com mand; the only difference is the name. 
The command uses the form:  
MODIFY for mula-name = expression  
You must open the  database with write access ( ACCESS UPDATE  or ACC ESS SHARED ) before  you 
can change a f ormula in the database.  
The following session creates a formula, assigns a description to it, and illustrates the effects of chang ing 
the formula with the MODIFY and FORM ULA commands.

Changing Data Object Names  
From time to time, you may  need to change the name of an existing data obje ct. Perhap s you ma de a 
typing error w hen you created the object, or your original series na me doesn’t fit in a growing data set, or 
you want to re -use the name for a n ew application where the name is more ap propriate. The RENAME 
command changes the name of  an existi ng data object in a single step without changing any other 
attributes.  
The RENAME  command uses the form: RENAME old -object -name AS new -object -name . 
As usual,  the RENAME command only works if the da tabase containing the data object has been opened  
for writi ng. 
* SCALAR FOOTNOTW:STRIN G = "See notes to Consolidated " + &&  
  "Financial Sta tements Section"  
* RENAME FOOTNOTW AS FOOTNOTE  
* DISPLAY FOOTNOTE  
 
FOOTNOTE  
 
See notes to Consolidated Financial Sta tements Section  
 
 
* DISPLAY FOOTNOTW  
 
Error: FOOT NOTW not f ound 
 
Note how, in the firs t command, the string was broken into two pieces so th at the line continuation 
characters (&&) could be used.  
Names of objects, al iases, and members of namelists in versi on 4 databases can be up to 242 
characters.  
To re name a dat abase or  a text file, use t he REFILE command described later in this guide in the  chapter  
TEXT FILES  (p. 242). 
Deleting Data Objects  
When you no longer need a data object, yo u can remo ve it fr om your database wi th the DELETE 
command. (If you want to remove a text f ile or a database, use the UNSAVE command, described later in 
this guide in the chapter  MORE ABOUT DATABASES  (p. 222)) Specify the  command name DELETE, 
followed by the name of the data  object; for example:  
DELETE SALES  
DELETE SALES, EXPENSES, PROFIT  
DELETE SAL ES.ADJU.BR.FORE, SALES.BR.RESEAS  
The fir st command deletes one time series, the second de letes thre e series , and the last comm and 
deletes two series.

www.fisglobal.com  140  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 Warning  Consider all of the consequences of your DELETE command before you issue it.  
Be especially caref ul when you delete a namelist! If you do  not preface a namelist name 
with an exclamation point, FAM E expand s the list and dele tes its contents.   For example 
DELETE !MYLIST delet es one namelist; DELETE MYLIST deletes t he 100 objects (for 
example) listed in MYLIST. Se e the disc ussion o f the CONFIRM optio n below.  
With several databases open, issue a WHATS c ommand before you delete an object to make sure that 
you’re deleting the obj ect from the correct database.  
One good way to be certain that you are deleting the right  data obje ct is to  include the databa se name 
with the object name; for example:  
OPEN BASE1,  PLAN 
DELETE BASE1'SALES  
DELETE PLAN'DIST1_FILM_SALES  
In this example, we op en the BASE1 and PLAN databases. If the data object SALES is not found in 
BASE1, the comm and fails.  
Hint Most efficient FAME u sers routinely use the DELETE command to clean up thei r databases. 
This reduces the amount of clutter in the database, and it free s some space for reuse by the 
database. It also reduces disk storage requirements, so tha t the data base can  be made 
smaller th e next time it is compressed with the COMPRESS utility . 
When you use a namelist or a wildcard specification to delete data objects , you may want to confirm the 
removal of  the individual objects as you delete them. The C ONFIRM opt ion has WILDCARD and 
NAMELI ST settings to control the destructive effects of wild cards and namelists on objects:  
 CONFIRM WILDCARD AUTO  and CONFIRM NAMELIST A UTO , the defaults, instruct FAME to 
confirm object deletion outside of a procedure. These  settings require you to confirm the wildcard 
specification or in a namelist specification.  We’ll demonstrate this protective feature below.  
 CONFIRM WILDCARD ON  and CONFIRM NAMELIST ON , such as the AUTO sett ing, instruct 
FAME to confirm all objects matched  by a wild card or namelist specificat ion in a destructive 
operation, even in a procedure.  
 CONFIRM WILDCARD OFF  and CONFIRM NAMELIST OFF  instruct FAME not to confirm an y 
object names when a wildcard or nameli st specification is used in a destructive operati on. 
The fo llowing sequence of stateme nts shows the creation of three series and one namelis t. The example

The CONFIRM option af fects destructive operations other than DELETE. F or example , the SC ALAR and 
SERIES com mands can use a namelist as their argument and thereby  create many data objects at once. 
If some of the objects already exist, and  OVERWRITE ON  is in effect, then the CON FIRM option will

 Use input files when you enter data. (We’ll dis cuss input files in the chapter  TEXT FILES  (p. 242))
