www.fisglobal.com  144 MISSING DATA V ALUES 
During your a nalyses of public and corporate data, you may find tha t some data is either missing or 
undefined. This chapter covers the followin g topics:  
 Definitions of missing data an d the three codes that FAME uses to identify miss ing data.  
 The MISS ING function, which  tests for the presence of missing data.  
 The IGNORE an d HOLIDAY options, which allow FAME to disregard missing data.  
 The REPLACE o ption, which FAME uses to control the fo rmatting of missing values and zeroes 
in reports.  
 Understa nding Mi ssing Data  
There ar e three main causes of missing data in series and scal ars. Missing data may be undefined, not 
available, or not computable:  
 Data m ay be undefined. FAME uses the data code  ND (for no data ) to represent this class of 
missing data.  
Examples  of undefined data include the number of electoral votes received by Harr y Truman in 
the 1972 presidential election, the team batting average of the Cleveland Indians in the 1983 
World Seri es, or the closing price of IBM stock on October 10, 2050. These ar e all examples of 
events that didn’t happen or that haven’t happened, so no data exists.  
If you do not assign a value to a scalar or to an observatio n of a series, FAME assigns ND. So, 
when  you create a series, all data values before the range that  you def ine and all data va lues 
after the range that you define are ND.  
 Data may not be available. FAME uses the data code NA (for not available ) to represen t this 
class of missing data.  
This class  of data is not always distinct from the undefine d class (N D), but typically the NA cl ass 
covers values that are missing from a sequence, ei ther because they were not recorded, or 
because they have been lost, or beca use they are being kept secret, but not because they could 
not exist.  
For example, in the  early day s of man y companies, sales and expense records are often spotty, 
either because r ecords have been lost, or because no one was responsible for consistently 
maintaining this data. Infant mortality ra tes for certain countries are unavailable because  these 
countries c hoose not to report  embarrassingly high rates.  
NA values must be assigned  by you, or created as the result of a calculation involving other NA 
values .

www.fisglobal.com  145  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
In order to use the HOLIDAY option, de scribed in this chapter, missing data values that  fall on 
holidays should be assigned the NA value.  
 Some data may not be computable. FAME us es the data code NC (for not computable ) to 
represent this class of missing data. 
Examples are mathematical computat ions that do not result in real numbers, such as the log of  a 
negat ive number, or the square root of a negative number.  
When you enter a mis sing data code in response to a prompt from the UPDATE command or as an 
assignment value in a SET command, you can u se any of the missing data codes: NA, NC, or ND. The 
three missing data codes are a co nvenience to you; ordinarily, FAME analyzes and graphs  all three 
identically. The HOLIDAY option, discussed later, can be used to make certain FAME functions handle 
NA va lues as holidays, rather than as missing data.  
When a FAME computat ion involves a miss ing data value, FAME returns a missing data value as t he 
result. For example, if you sum two series using the LSUM function and on e of the series includes a 
missing value  for one period, the resulting series contains a missing da ta value  for the period. Ho wever, 
the IGNORE option, described in this chapter, c an control this result.  
In cases where FAME encounters several missing data values, the priority of the codes is ND,  followed by 
NA, followed by NC. For example, ND * NC resul ts in ND , not NC.  
The interaction between missing data and open -ended ranges may be significan t to you. The data within 
a series deter mines the beginning date and the ending date of a n open -ended range . If you set an ope n 
range, FAME includes any NA or NC missing codes at t he beginning or end of the series; however, 
FAME excludes all ND missing cod es at the beginning and end of the serie s. This is reasonable, since 
FAME fills a series with ND va lues bef ore you specify dat a for the series. When you enter an NA missing 
code or  when FAME calculates an NC missing code, it suggests that you have some inf ormation about 
the nature of the missing  data.  
The following example illustrates missing values in an open -ended range:  
* DATE 98 TO 05  
* REPORT X_SERIES  
 
          1998  1999  200 0  2001     2002  2003  2004  2005  
          ----  ----  ----  ----  -------  ----  ----  ---- 
X_SERIES    ND    NA    NC    ND  9999.90    NA    NC    ND  
 
 
* DATE *  
* REPORT X_SERIES 
 
          1999  2000  2001     2002  2003  2004  
          ----  ----  ----  -------  ----  ---- 
X_SERIES    NA    NC    ND  9999.90    NA    NC  
 Checking for Missing Values  
The MISSING fu nction determines whether or not a data value is missing. Y ou can u se the function in 
input files and procedures to test data so that you ca n detect errors or omissions and take appropriate 
action.

www.fisglobal.com  146  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
To use the functio n, test the value of MISSING( expression ); if the value of the expression is NA, NC, or 
ND, the MISS ING func tion returns the lo gical value TRUE.  
 
* DISPLAY MISSING(X_SERIES[98]), MI SSING(X_SERIES[99])  
 
MISSING(X_SERIES[98])  
 
TRUE 
 
MISSING(X_SERIES[99])  
 
TRUE 
You can use the MISSING function with the SET command to change missing codes, as shown  in the 
following example:  
 
* DATE 19 90 TO 1992  
* SET X_SERIES = IF MISSING(X_SERIES) THEN 100.11 ELSE X_SERIES  
* DATE *  
* DISPLAY X_SERIES  
 
X_SERIES  
 
1989          NA  
1990      100.11  
1991      100.11  
1992     9999.90 
1993          NA  
1994          NC  
Disregarding Missing Values 
Two options,  IGNORE and HOLIDAY, allow some FAME functions to disr egard missing values.  
The IGNORE Option  
You can use the IGNORE option to mak e some FAME functions disregard missing values. In particular, 
functions that require a s eries or a  list of  values as their ar gument and that return a series or a scalar can 
ignore  missing values. The IGNORE option also affects totaling and time scale conv ersion. 
The IGNORE option affects one fo recasting command, ADJUST; it is discussed in the  FAME 
FORE CASTING  USER GUIDE . 
As a de fault, FAME uses IGNORE OFF , as the following example shows: 
* DATE 89 TO 94  
* TYPE AVE(X_SERIES)  
NA 
* IGNORE ON  
* TYPE AVE(X_SERI ES) 
3400.04

www.fisglobal.com  147  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The HOLIDAY Option  
In additi on to the IGNORE option, you can use the HOLIDAY option to make som e FAME functions 
disregard the NA missing value. When you specify HOLIDAY  ON, functions skip past NA missing values 
when figuring leads and lags in d ata. The default setting of the HOLIDAY option is OFF, so you must 
remember to specify ho lidays as NA and t o set the HOLIDAY o ption ON to take advantage of this 
capability. A list of functions that observe the HOLIDAY option is included in the documentatio n of the 
HOLIDAY option in the FAME C OMM AND REFERENCE . 
Changing Missing Codes and Zeroes  
Occasional ly, you want to print a str ing other than NA, NC, or ND for missing data in your output. The 
REPLACE option specifies strings of characters to replace each o f these missing data codes, as well as 
the zero value.  
The REPLACE option takes the four modifiers NA, NC, ND, and ZERO. Each of the modifiers, in turn, 
takes a string of text encl osed in quotes. The default setting of the REPLACE option is REPLACE NA 
“NA” , NC “NC”, ND “ND”, ZERO NULL . 
The follo wing example session illustrates the use of the R EPLACE opt ion: 
 
* SET X_SERIES[93] = 0 
* REPLACE NA "Not Available", ZERO " --" 
* DATE *  
* DISPLAY X_SERIES  
 
X_SERIES  
 
1989     Not Available  
1990            100.11  
1991            100.11 
1992           9999. 90 
1993                -- 
1994                NC

www.fisglobal.com  148 DATA ATTRIBUTES  
Each data object has some des criptive information associated with it:  
 Some of the characteristics of a da ta object are intrinsic and cannot be ch anged. For example, 
the date of an object’s creat ion and th e date o f its last revision  are intrinsic to the data object. A 
time series or a date scalar has a frequency intrinsically associated with it that cannot be 
changed. We have discussed these charact eristics earlier in this guide.  
 Other characteris tics, call ed attri butes, are not intr insic; you can change the setting for an 
attribute. Fo r example, the description of any data object can be changed.  
This chapter d iscusses the following points about attr ibutes:  
 You can display characteristics and attri butes with  the WHA TS command.  
 You can  add or change a description for an object with the DE SCRIPTION command.  
 You can add or change the documentation of an object with  the DOCUMENTATION command.  
 You control the OBSERVED attribute, which states how you meas ure the da ta for a  time series, 
with the OBSERVED option or command.  
 You control the BASIS attribute with the BASIS option or command. The BASIS attribute states 
wheth er you are using a five -day business wee k or a seven -day calendar week for the data 
objec t. 
 The ALI AS comma nd allows you to ad d aliases to the names of your objects. The CONFIRM 
option controls the use of aliases in destructive operations.  
This chapter end s with a short discussion of user -define d attributes, which allow you to create and use 
your own at tributes  for data objects. Two additional data object attributes, ASSOCIATE and 
STRINGLENGTH, are beyond the scope of this guide; they are discussed in FAME’ s COMMAND  
REFERENCE . 
Displaying Basic In formation  
The WHATS command displays basic descri ptive info rmation about a data object . The command uses 
the form WHATS list -of-object -names . Separate the object names with commas. The output varies, 
depending on the  nature of the data object.

Different data objects store different kin ds of characteristics and attributes. The output for the WH ATS 
comm and displays the fo llowing information:  
 Object name . The object name is c entered above the output.  
 Description . The description for the object, if it  exists, appears centered below the obje ct name. 
We’ll describe the DESCRIPTION attribute  later in this cha pter. 
 Class . FAME i dentifies the object as a SERIES, FORMULA, or SCALAR.  
 Type. FAME identifies series and scalars as NUMERIC, PRECISION, STRING, DATE , 
NAMELIST, or BOOLEAN. If FAME identifi es the type as a DATE, it also identifies the fre quency. 
Formulas d o not have a type.  
 Index . FAME identifies series as either time series (D ATE:frequency ) or case series (CASE). 
Scalars and formulas do not have an in dex. 
 DB name . FAME identifies the name o f the database that stores the object.  
 Created . FAME ident ifies th e date that you cre ated the object.  
 Updated . FAME identifies the date of the last update for the object.  
 First Value at . FAME identifies the date or case number of the first non -ND value st ored in a 
series. If all the data in a series is ND, FAME r eturns N C as the first date  or case number. Scalars 
and formulas do not have a fi rst value.  
 Last Value at . FAME identifies the date or case number of the las t non-ND value stored in a 
series. If al l the data in a series is ND, FAME returns NC as the last d ate or c ase number. Scalars  
and formulas do not have a last value.  
 Observed . FAME  identifies the OBSERVED attribute for  time series, formula or global formul a 
objects that return a time series. Onl y OBSERVED BEGINNING and OBSERVED END settings  
are valid fo r time s eries of types othe r than numeric or precision . We’ll describe the OBSERV ED 
attribute later in this chapter. Case series and scalars do not have an O BSERVED attribute.  
 Basis . FAME identifie s the BASIS attribute  for time series, formula or  global fo rmula ob jects that 
return a  time series. We’ll describe the BASIS attribute later  in this chapter. Case series and 
scalars do not have a BASIS attribute.  
 Documentation . The documentation for the ob ject, if it exists, appears beneath the other 
characteristi cs and a ttributes. We’ll de scribe the DOCUMENTATION attribute later in this chapt er. 
The object CITY.SALES is a namelist. To display attribute information ab out a namelist, you must put an 
exclamat ion point (!) before the name of the namelist.   If you omit t he exclamation point, FAME

Namelists do  not need to conta in the names of exi sting data objects; they need only contain legal FAME 
names. If you expand a namelist containing a name that does not identify an existing data object, an error 
occurs.  
Adding a Description to a Data Object  
To describe a series, scalar, or formula, we can assign a description attribute to the object with the 
DESCRIPTION command. The command takes the form:  
DESCRIPTION(object -name) = string-expression

www.fisglobal.com  152  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The description may be  either a string of text enclosed in quotes, or a  string da ta objec t or expression. In  
the following example, we add a description to the se ries RESEARCH:  
* DESCRIPTION(RESEARCH) = "Expenditure for Research and Devel opment, International"  
Note that the DES CRIPTION command wraps on the monitor . You cannot  use the d ouble am persand for 
line co ntinuation in the middle of a literal string. However,  you can use the double ampersand before or 
after the equals sign. You can a lso use the double ampersand after the s tring concatenation character. All 
three of the f ollowing s tatement s are equivalent to  the above:  
DESCRIPTION(RESEARCH) &&  
   = "Expenditure  for Research and Development, International"  
DESCRIPTION(RESEARCH) = &&  
   "Expenditure for Research and Developmen t, International"  
DESCRIPTION(RESEARCH) = "Expend iture for Research and " + &&  
   "Development, International"  
Descriptions should be kept b rief, since they are the default labels that FAME uses to label graphs and 
rows in reports. Lengthier descriptive in formation should be placed in the documentation a ttribute o f a 
data object. There is n o practical upper limit to the length of a description ; it could be thousands of 
characters long. However, descriptions should not  incorporate carriage returns because th ey are ignored 
on graphs, so they are effectively  limited t o one li ne. 
You can also su bmit a description by creating a string scalar to stor e the description and then setting the 
description equal to the scalar, as s hown below:  
SCALAR RD:STRING = "Expendit ure for R&D, International"  
DESC (RESEARCH) = RD  
All attri butes (description, documentation, observed, and basis ) have attribute references. The references 
look like functions rather than option references; they take the form of  the attribute name (or its unique 
abbreviation),  followed by a dat a object name enclo sed in parentheses. The attribute form is: attribute -
name(object -name) . 
We can use the DES C attribute reference to display the con tents of the description attribute of the series 
RESEARCH:  
 * TYPE DESC(RESEARCH)  
Expenditure for R & D, International  
 
When you use an attr ibute reference, FAME returns a string value. Attribute references can be ve ry 
useful in creating text for graphs an d reports, and in creating new attribute settings  for other  data ob jects. 
Apart from a ttribute references, the description of a data object appears in plots, in reports, and in other 
command output. Note also that wh en you give the WHATS command, FAME disp lays the description as 
part of the output.  
Addin g Document ation to  a Data Object  
If you want more detailed information for an object in add ition to the description, you can store a 
DOCUMENTATION attribute for an obj ect. Typically, documentation consists o f a long string of text. It

DOCUMENTATION(object -name) = string -expression

Specifying the  OBSERVED Attribute  
The OBSERVED attribu te of a time series describes how the data was me asured. FA ME uses this 
information wh en you draw plots or when you convert the frequency of  a time series. There are eight 
possible settings for the observed attribute : BEGINNING, END, AVERAGED, SUMMED, ANNU ALIZED, 
HIGH, LOW, and FORMULA . Only OBSERVED BEG INNING and  OBSERVE D END settings are valid for 
time series of types other than numeric or p recision.  The OBSERVED attribute settings are described 
below:  
 BEGIN NING specifies that each time series value repres ents a sin gle obse rvation made at the  
beginning of the period. The beginning checking accou nt balance on your monthly statement 
might be one example of this type of OB SERVED attribute.  
 END specifies that each time series val ue repre sents a single obse rvation made at the end of the 
period. Closing stock p rices are end -of-period observations.  
 AVERAGED specifies that each ti me series value is the average of observations ma de 
through out the period. The interes t rate figures reported each Friday by the federal gov ernment 
are averages of the daily interest rates reported during that week.  
 SUMMED specifies that each time series value  is the su m of obs ervations made thro ughout the 
period. Sales data is usually reported as s ums at a monthly or quarterly frequency.  
 ANNUALIZED specifies that each time series value is the annualized sum of o bservation s made 
throughout the perio d. The federal government reports the gross national p roduct each quarter 
and housing starts each month as annualized figures. FAM E treats ANNUALIZED data identically 
with AVERAGED data in time series conversion. Howeve r, it is u seful to  have the name 
ANNU ALIZED since so much data is reported as annualized.  
 HIGH specifies that each time seri es value is the high observation for the  period. Daily high stock 
prices are an example o f OBSERVED  HIGH.  
 LOW specifies that each time ser ies value is the low observation for the period. Stock prices are 
usually re ported as a low for the period. Daily lo w stock prices are an example of OBSERVED 
LOW.  
 FORMULA specifies that each time series value i s the mathematical combination of other time 
series. The resultant series ca n no longer be classified strictly as a SUMMED, END, AVERAGE, 
or any other OBSERVED attri bute time series. For example, ratio items, such as return on assets, 
should be given an ob served attribute FORMULA.  
However, not all calculated items are properly cla ssified as FORMULA data; for example, to tal 
sales across six divisions is still SUMMED da ta. FAME t reats th e FORMULA observed attribute 
identically to AVERAGED data, but you can se t the attribute to FORMULA for better database 
documentation.  
You can set th e OBSERVED attribute using either the OB SERVED option or the OBSERVED command.  
The OBSERV ED Option  
The OBSE RVED option takes a s a setting any of the values discussed earlier and ca n be set at any level, 
except argument -specific. The default setting is SUMM ED. If you look at the output of any of the earlier 
WHATS commands in this section, you w ill see th at all o f the time series c ontain the default SUMMED. 
The option value determines  the observed attribute for time series subsequently created with the SERIES  
and NEW commands.

The OBSERVED Command  
After you create a time series, you may realize that the object has the wrong OBSERVED at tribute. Y ou 
can r ectify the error wi th the OBSERVED command.  
The OBSERVED command takes th e form:  
OBSERVED(object -name) = observed -attribute  
In the following example,  we use the WHATS command to determine t he OBSERVED attribute of the 
INVENTORY series and  the OBSER VED comm and to change the a ttribute:  
* WHATS INVENTORY

The OBSERVED co mmand look s simila r to the DESCRIPTIO N and DOCUMENTATION commands. 
However, FAME does not e nclose the value of the OBSERVED attribute in quotes because it is a FAME -
defined value, not a user -specified string  of text. Even so, FAME returns a string value wi th the 
OBS ERVED at tribute reference.  
You may be concerned because OBSERVED is both a comman d and an option. FAME distinguishes 
between the command and the option, even  when they are abbreviated. FAME looks a head to the next 
non-blank character. If it finds  a left pa renthesi s, it knows that it  is dealing with the command; if it 
encounters any oth er character, FAME treats the statement as the option.  
Examples in Time Scal e Conversion and Graphics

For time s cale conversion, FA ME depends on the conversion method chosen and on the setting of the 
OBSERVED attribute. (We will detail time scale conversion in the chapter  TIME SCALE CONVERSION  
(p. 178)). The follo wing time scale conversion takes advantage of the sett ings of the objects’ OBSERVED 
attributes:

determine the quarterly value.  
 The s eries INVE NTORY ha s the OBSERVED attr ibute END. FAME uses the value of the last 
month in ea ch quarter to determine the quarterly value.

In plotting, the OBSERVED attribute governs the placement of each data point with respect to the tick 
marks. In the g raph on the previous  page, the data is plotted ac cording to  the set tings of the object ’s 
OBSERVED attributes:  
 The series LA.SALES has the OB SERVED attribute SUMMED. FAME plots the values between 
the tick marks becaus e SALES represents data collected over t he entire time interval.  
 The series INVENTORY has  the OBSER VED attr ibute END. FAME plo ts the value on the last tick 
mark of the interval bec ause it represents data observed at the end of the time interval.  
We generat ed the graph with this command:  
GRAPH LA .SALES, INVENTORY <PLOT AXIS RIGHT>  
Although this  graph use s the ob jects’ OBSERVED att ributes, we could have specified that they be plotted 
differently. The PLACEMENT modifier of the PLOT option, described in the FAM E G RAPHICS  USER GUIDE, 
overrides the def ault placement of data points with respect to tic k marks.  
Specifyin g the BASIS Attribu te 
The WHATS command displays a basis attribute for each time series and formulas or global formulas that 
return numeric and precision time series . There are only two values for the BASIS attribu te: DAILY or 
BUSIN ESS. 
Both graphics and tim e scale conversions use the BASIS attrib ute. The attribute tells FAME whether data 
values  are based  on a se ven-day calendar we ek (DAILY) or a five -day business week (BUSINESS). Thi s 
is significant in aggregation conversions because it affects the relative weights assigned to observations. 
We’ll detail time scale conversion in the chapter  TIME SCALE CONVERSION  (p. 178). 
The BASIS Option  
You can set the BASI S attribute as an option; it affects the creation  of subseq uent tim e series by the 
SERIES and NEW commands.  
The option has three settings, D AILY, BUSINESS, and AUTO. FAME uses the default BASIS AUTO . The 
default tell s FAME to assign the BASIS attribute app ropriate for the time series that is being create d. If 
the frequenc y of the series is BUSINESS, then the series uses the BUSINESS BASIS attr ibute. For all 
other time series frequencies, BASIS AUTO  assigns the basis a ttribute DAILY.  
The BASIS Command  
You can change  the bas is of an existing t ime series with the BASIS command. The command form is  
similar to the OBSERVED, DESCRIPTION, and DOCUMENTATION commands. The comma nd is one of 
the following:  
BASIS(series -name) = DAILY  
BASIS(series -name) = BUSINESS  
If you want, y ou can f orce your business time series to have basis DAILY. However, this basis i s 
inappropriate for most business day data. In some frequency conversions of  BUS frequency data with 
basis DAILY, th e data values for Monday are triple -weighted, sin ce these d ata valu es also represent

www.fisglobal.com  160  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Saturday and Sunday. Usually, data recorded at a busine ss day frequency should not be interpreted in 
this way.  
As with the other user -settable attribu tes, there  is an a ttribute reference for the BASIS attribute; for 
example DISPLAY BASIS(MYS ERIES). The BASIS attribute reference returns a string.  
You may be concerned  because BASIS is both a command and an option. FAME distinguishes between 
the command an d the opti on even when they are abbre viated. FAME looks ahead to the next non -blank 
charact er. If it finds a left parenthesis, it knows that it is dealing with the com mand; if it encounters any 
other charact er, FAME treats the statement as the option.  
Exam ple in Tim e Scale Conversion  
Consid er the following example, in which values that are measured weekly are combi ned into a monthly 
value, first with a D AILY basis and then with a BUSINESS basis:  
* WHATS SCORE 
 
 
                                SCORE 
 
Class:  SERIES                                  DB name:  BASICS13  
Type:   NUMERIC                                 Cre ated:  16-May-08 
Index:  DATE:MONTHLY                            Updated:  16 -May-08 
 
First Value a t: Jul 08                          Observed: AVERAGED  
Last Value at:  Sep 08                          Basis:    DAILY  
 
* FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
* CONVERT ON  
* TYPE SCORE 
19.89 
* BASIS(SCORE) = BUSINES S 
* TYPE SCORE  
20.15 
The results differ because F AME weight s the mo nthly averages acco rding to the number of observations 
in each month. For  BASIS DAILY, the monthly weights are 31, 31, and 30; but for BASIS BUSINESS , 
which has no weekends, the monthly wei ghts are 21, 23, and 22. We discuss the CONVERT o ption at 
length in  the chapter  TIME SCALE CONVERSION  (p. 178). 
Specifying an Alias  
Aliase s are special attributes for data objects. With t he ALIAS a ttribute , you can apply one  or more 
aliases to a data object so that you can retr ieve the object by its name or by any of its aliases.  
The ALIAS command has the form:  
ALIAS(object -name) = alias -namelist 
Within a database, all data object names an d aliases must be unique. If you atte mpt to reuse an alias 
name, FAME prints an error messa ge, just as it would for a name.

Alias:     C.HIGH  
 
The comm and WHAT S C17119610X01.HIGH  and the command WHATS C.HIGH  have the same effect. 
FAME displays the object name, rather than the alias; FAME lists the alias, if  any, after the other 
characteristics bu t before the DOCUMENTATION attribute.  
Use the fol lowing syn tax to a dd another alias to  the namelist and give the object C17119610X01.HIGH 
two aliases:  
* ALIAS(C17119610X01.HIGH) = ALIAS(C17119610X01.HIGH) + {C1711961 0.HIGH} 
Use the ALI AS attribu te refer ence to display the  namelist of aliases for the object.  
* TYPE !ALIAS(C. HIGH) 
C17119610.HIGH, C.HIGH  
Note  You must use the exclamation point precedi ng a command referencing a namelist to k eep the 
namelist from expanding.    
Use the REALNAME function to find the name of a data obj ect: 
* TYPE REALNAME(C.HIGH)  
C17119610X0 1.HIGH 
FAME is intelligent in its use of aliases.  Note that  the nam e and both aliases in the example begin with C. 
By default, if you use a wildcard specification such as C?, FAME will match it once per data object. So, for 
example, WHATS PRICING'C?  retrie ves the series C17119610X01.HIGH one time, not th ree times.  The 
result of wildcarding on aliases and names is controlled by the ITEM ALIAS a nd ITEM NAME option 
settings. If ITEM ALIAS ON  had been specified, the serie s C17119610X01.HIGH would have been 
retrieved three times (once for the name and once for  each alia s) by th e WHATS command. Th e ITEM 
options were discussed in the chapter  DATA AND  WILDCARDING  (p. 45). 
The CONFIRM option, mentioned e arlier in this gui de, uses the ALIAS setting to control any destructive 
effects of aliases on data objects:

www.fisglobal.com  162  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 CONFIRM ALIAS ON  instructs FAME to confirm the names matchi ng the aliases that you specify 
with a d estructive command. This setting requires you to confirm th e action  when you try to de lete 
or overwrite an object by naming an alias.  
 CONFIR M ALIAS OFF  instructs FAME not to confirm the names matching aliases that yo u use in 
destructive commands.  
 CONFIRM A LIAS AUTO , the default, tells FAME to use CONFIRM  ALIAS OFF  with pr ocedures 
and user -defined functions, and CONFIRM ALIAS ON  everywhere else . We’ll demonstrate this 
capability below.  
If you enter the following DELETE  command, FAME requires you to confirm t he name for the alias that 
you specify:  
* DELETE C.HIGH

Specifying Your Own Data Attributes  
There are many possibilities f or attribute types that could be assigne d with each data object. For 
example, for time se ries of bo nd price s, you may wish to store a string of text that identifies the type of 
bond, a daily date that specifies the maturity, a number identifying the coupon  rate, and a boolean value 
that states w hether the bond is callable. It would be handy to  have ISSU E_TYPE, MAT URITY, COUPON, 
and CALLABLE attributes to store this information.  
Six different kinds of user -defined data attributes are available: numeric, preci sion, stri ng, date , boolean, 
and name list. The names of the user -defined attributes are mai ntained in six namelists by your database 
administrator:  
 NUMERIC_ATTRIBUTE_N AME S contains the names of numeric user -defined attributes.  
 PRECISION_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES con tains the names of  precision user -defined attributes.  
 STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES contains the n ames of string user -defined attributes.  
 DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES contains the na mes of date user -defined attributes.  
 BOO LEAN_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES contains the names of boolea n user -defined att ributes.  
 NAMELIST_A TTRIBUTE_NAMES contains the names of namelist user -defined attributes.  
FAME beginners most often encounter user -defined attributes  in departmental databases that are crea ted 
and maintained by experienced FAME users.  
To create a u ser-defined attribute, you must add the name of the attribute to the appropriate attribute 
namelist. If the attribute namelist doesn’t exist, you must create  it. The ISSUE_TYPE attribute mentioned 
earlier would be stored in STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES . The MATU RITY att ribute belongs in 
DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES, the COUPON attribute belongs in N UMERIC_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES, and 
the CALLABLE attribute belongs in BOOLEAN_ATTRIB UTE_NAMES:  
* STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES = {I SSUE_TYPE}  
* DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES = {MATURITY}  
 
 
Error: Can not overwrite existing obje ct DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES when

www.fisglobal.com  163  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
OVERWRITE is OFF  
 
 
* TYPE !DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES  
ISSUE_DATE  
* SET DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES = DATE_ATTRIBU TE_NAMES + {MATURITY}  
* TYPE !DATE_ATTRI BUTE_NAMES  
ISSUE_DATE, MATURITY  
The database does  not have an objec t named STRING_ATTR IBUTE_NAMES, so the first command 
creates it as a name list. However, the namelist DATE_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES already exists, so the 
implicit NEW command fails, resulting in an error message. The TYPE commands show the content s of 
that namelist  before and after i t is modified by the SET command. These steps create p art of the structure 
necessary for the creation of user -defined attributes. The next step is to use the ATTRIBUTE co mmand to 
assign values to the user -defined attrib utes.  
The c ommand takes the form: ATTRIBUTE user -attribute(object -name) = user -value .  
In the following session, values are assigned to sever al user-defined attributes for the bonds  
CCI99.PRICE and FCC94.PRICE:  
* FREQUENCY DAILY  
* ATTRIBUTE  MATURITY(CCI99.PRICE) = 15 APR99 
* ATTRIBUTE MATURITY(FCC94.PRICE) = 15MAY94  
* ATTRIBUTE COUPON(CCI99.PRICE) = 9.000  
* ATTRIBUTE COUPON(FCC94.PRICE) = 8.875  
* ATTRIBUTE ISSUER(CCI99.PRICE) = "Citic orp" 
* ATTRIBUTE ISSUER(FCC94.PRICE) = "Ford Cred it Co." 
A user-defined attribute name list affects all of the data objects in the database t hat contains it, but does 
not affect any other database or the items they co ntain. If you want several databases to share the same 
user-defined attributes, each data base must have cop ies of the user -defined attribute namelists.  
User -defined attributes have  attribute references, just as do FAME’s predefined attributes. You can 
display an attribute setting:  
* TYPE MATURIT Y(CCI99.PRICE)  
15-Apr-99 
* TYPE CALLABLE(FCC94.PR ICE) 
FALSE 
You can  build systems arou nd the results of attribute tests. For example, you co uld design a report that 
selects all non -callable bonds with maturities prio r to the year 2000 and prints summary in formation for 
them.  
Hints   
o If you frequently create new user -defined attributes, yo u may want to assign aliases to the 
namelists that store the user -defined at tributes to save yourself tedious typing . For 
example, the following ALIAS command assign s the alia s S_A_N to the user -defined  
attribute namelist STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES:  
ALIAS(STRI NG_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES) = S_A_N  
From now on, you can revise your user -defined st ring attributes by modifying S_A_N, 
instead of STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES.  
o You can change the  name of a  user-defined attribute by changing the name that appears 
in its user -defined att ribute namelist. Suppose you want to change the inconveniently long 
name of the user-defined string attribute REPORT ING_AGENCY to AGENCY. If

www.fisglobal.com  164  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES i s {REPORTI NG_AGENC Y, UNITS, CURRENCY,  
COUNTRY}, use the following SET command:  
SET STRING_A TTRIBUTE_NAMES = {AGENCY, UNITS, &&  
   CURRENCY,  COUNTRY}  
Or, if you heeded  our first tip and created an alias for STRING_ATTRIBUTE_NAMES:  
 
SET S_A_N = {AGENCY, UNI TS, CURREN CY, COUNTRY} 
 
o Be very caref ul when you edit the user -defined attribute namelists.  As a rule, you should 
append new attributes to the end of a user -defined at tribute namelist with a SET 
command of t he form  
SET type ATTRIBUTE NAMES = type_ATTRIBUTE _NAMES + & & 
   {new_att1, new_att2}  
where type is BOOLEAN, DATE, NAMELIST, NUMERIC, PRECISI ON, or STRING.  
o Removing or inserting a name in a user -defined attribute name list is equivalent to 
renaming all of th e following names. If the user -defined attribute namelist 
DATE_ATTR IBUTE_NAMES contain ing the names {LAST, NEXT} is changed to {FIRST, 
LAST,  NEXT}, the attribute FIRST will contain the values formerly associated with  LAST, 
the attribute LAST will contain t he values formerly associated with NEXT, and the attribute 
NEXT wil l have all missing values.

www.fisglobal.com  165 DISPLAY AND REPORT D ATA 
For most busin ess applications, analysts use reports as analytical tools and to present results.  This 
chapter demonstrates several simpl e reporting commands:  
 The DISPLAY command p rints seri es, scalars, f ormulas, expr essions, and the results from 
formulas and expressions . 
 The TYPE command prints individual values for scalars, series, and expressions.  
 The REPORT command displays series, form ulas, and expressions in versatile displays  that give  
you many opti ons for contr olling the final appearance.  
We document the REPORT co mmand and the reporting options in the FAME R EPORTING  USER GUIDE and 
the FAME C OMM AND REFERENCE . Refer to these manuals fo r more complete information about FAME’s 
reporting fe atures.  
Displa ying Data  
The DISPLAY command lists data values and attributes of s eries, scalars, and formulas. If you specify a 
series, the DISPLAY command prints the information vertically in a single c olumn. The command also 
shows current optio n settings  and the resul ts of express ions. 
To use the DISPLAY command, specify the command name, followed by a list of names or expressions 
separated by commas. Each item wi ll appear in its own report. The command  uses the form: DISPLAY 
expression.  
Scalars  
You can u se the DISPLAY  command to p rint scalars. In the following example, TAX_RATE is a numeric 
scalar, TITLE is a string scalar, ENABLED is a boolean scalar, CITIES is a  namelist scalar, and ORIGIN 
is a date s calar:

Generating Simple Report s 
Reporting is one of the most frequentl y used FAME tools. To generate a report, sp ecify the REPORT 
command , followed by  the names of series, expressions, or formulas. The co mmand uses the form: 
REPORT expression -list. 
You can set options globally before a  report, at the command -specific level w ith the REPORT command, 
or at the argument -specific l evel on the it ems within yo ur REPORT command; for example:  
* DATE 08Q1 TO 09Q2  
* TITLE "Sales Report"  
* REPORT <DECIMAL 1> SALES <PREFIX "$">, EXPENSES AS &&  
    "Total Expenses", PROFITS, EXPENSES / SA LES * 100 AS &&  
    "Percentage" <DECIMAL 0 ; SUFFIX " %">

Total Expen ses   159. 9   144.5   14 8.9   151.2   166.3   157.4  
PROFITS          -10.6    29.0    49.3    51.0    38.1    48.4  
Percentage        107%     83%     75%     75%     81%     76% 
 
This report is attractive and help ful because of the FAME options and capabil ities expl oited in the 
example: 
 In this type of horizontal report, dates flow across the to p of the report and series fall down the left 
edge of the report by default.  
 If a ser ies has a description, it appears on the re port. If a  series does n ot have a des cription, 
FAME uses the name of the object or expressi on as the description. If you specify an AS clause 
with an object or expression, i t always overrides the object name or de scription.

 The TITLE option specifies title s for repo rts. This titl e appears on all reports during your session 
until you cancel it by  specifying TITLE NULL. You can enter up to six lines of titles for a report; for 
example TITLE #1 "Sales Report" and TITL E #2 "International Division”.  
 The DECIMAL option spe cifies the num ber of decima l places for data.  
 The PREFIX option specifies a strin g to appear before numeric data values.  
 The SUFFIX option specifies a string to ap pear after numeric data values.  
The prev ious report is a horizontal report — it has  dates acr oss the top of  the report. The SHOW

www.fisglobal.com  172 GRAPH DATA  
For most business applications, analysts u se graphs as analytical tools and to pre sent results. FAME can 
display series, f ormulas, a nd expressions in  almost an y graph that you can imagine. In this chapter, we 
introduce the following topics:  
 The GRAPH command.  
 How to use the DEVICE option to tell F AME  about your printer.  
 How to use the P LOT option to modify the appearance of t ime series  graphs.  
 How to s end your g raphs to a file.  
We document the GRAPH command and the  graphing options in the FAME G RAPHICS  USER GUIDE . Refer 
to that guide for more compl ete information about FAME’s graphics co mmands and options.  
Generating Simple Gr aphs  
Graph s are the easiest  way to un derstand data. The basic GRAPH command uses either of two forms:  
GRAPH expression -list 
GRAPH expression -list VS scaling -variable  
For exampl e, the following FAME statements produce d the graph on the next page:  
* DATE 08Q 1 TO 09Q2  
* DEVICE GRAPHIC MSWIN 
* CHANNEL GRAPHICS NetIncome.wmf  
* OPEN <ACCESS CREATE; KI ND GRAPHIC> NetIncome.wmf  
* GRAPH SALES, EXPENSES, SALES - EXPENSES <PLOT DRAW BAR, & & 
     DESCRIPTION "Net Income">  
The DEV ICE option told FAME to create the graph  for a Pos tScript laser pri nter and t o give it a portrait 
orientation.  
The GRAPHIC setting of the DEVICE option specifies the type of format that will be used, so that FAME 
can format output accordingly. The DEVICE G RAPHIC setting is one of the following v alues:  
 
Setting Graphic for mat 
X Not supported on Microsoft Windows. Graphs will be render ed using the X Windows 
System.  
MSWIN  Only supported on Microsoft Windows. Graphs wil l be rendered in a FAME window or 
in a f ile using Windows Metafile (WMF) format.

www.fisglobal.com  173  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Setting Graphic for mat 
PNG  Grap hs will be render ed in the PNG graphic format.  
POST  Graphs will be rendered usin g the PostScript programming language. This setting is 
also required for creating Pos tScript reports.  
 
To get a list of supp orted devices, use the FAME O NLINE  HELP for the DE VICE option or ch eck in the  
FAME C OMMAND  REFERENCE . 
The PLOT option supplied a de scription and told FAME to use bars to draw the expression SALES - 
EXPENSES . The PLOT  option offers a number of settings for customizing your graphs:  
 The P LOT AXIS s etting specifies whether data is plotted against the l eft or right axis.  
 The PLOT COLOR setting specifies the color for data on the graph.  
 The PLOT DESCRIPTION setting works like the AS clause in reports to specify the descriptio n 
for data on a g raph. 
 The PLOT DRAW setting specifies how to draw the data that you want to plot. BAR, 
HORIZONTAL, LINE, and VERTICAL are all valid settings.  
 The PLO T MISSING setting indicates how you want  FAME to handle missing values in the da ta 
you’re plotting.  
 The PLO T SHADING setting specifies the shading pattern (BACKSLASH, HATC H, 
HORIZONTAL, NONE, VERTICAL, or PAINT, for example) for bars that you plot.  
 The PLO T STYLE setting specifies the type of li ne (DASHED, DOTTED, or SOLID, for exampl e) 
for lin es that you plot.  
The PLOT option offers a number of other settings not listed he re.

* LABEL LEFT "Sales"

This is an example of a scatter graph. The expression following the VS keyword is u sed to sca le the 
bottom axi s. The SAL ES series is used to scale the left axis. Each plottin g symbol represents one 
quarter’s sales plotted against the previous quarter’s advert ising. 
These two graphs only hint at FAM E’s powerful graphic capabilities. For e xample, FA ME can:  
 Plot data  of differ ing frequencies on the same graph against time.  
 Put ma ny graphs on a single page, without requiring you to measure and calculate positions.  
 Automatically scale and label linear, l ogarithmic, and date axes.  
 Automatically  shrink ti tles and captions  to fit a graph.  
 Graph data according to its OBSERVED attribute (see the graphs at the end of the chapter  TIME 
SCALE CONVERSION  (p. 178)). 
 Annotate data poin ts and sha de regions.  
 Chang e line typ es and fill gaps caused by missing data.  
For more info rmation about plotting graphs, see the FAME G RAPHICS  USER GUIDE.

Storing Graphs in a File 
You can send FAME’s graphic outpu t to a file. There are a couple of reaso ns for doi ng this:  
 You may want to ma ke many copies of the same graph. It’s usually much si mpler to use the 
same graphic output file many times than to repeat a FAME session.  
 You may want to produce a hard copy of yo ur graph by sending it to a printer.  
Use the PICTU RE command to dir ect FAME’s  graphic output to a file. For example, the command  
PICTURE MOMENTUM  
creates the file MOMENTUM.PIC and directs all subsequent graphic outpu t to it. The graphic device type 
of the picture file is locked in when the first  graph is drawn to the file . If you n eed to create graphs for a 
different printer, open a n ew PIC file with the PICTURE command and change the DEVICE option before 
you draw the  first graph. To restore graphic output to your FAME session from a file, use th e command  
PICTURE TERMINAL

www.fisglobal.com  178 TIME SCALE CONVERSION  
Sometimes  you need to perform analyses that combi ne data re corded at differi ng time se ries frequencies. 
For example, you may need to combine  your monthly sales data with the federal government’s quarterly 
and annual economic data in a single analysis.  
FAME handles situations such as this properly, using conversion  options and func tions that  you specify. 
This chapter discusses the following tim e series topics:  
 Automatic time scale conversion with the CONVERT option.  
 Explicit ti me scale conversion with the CONVERT fun ction.  
 Differences between automatic and  explicit conversion.  
 Facto rs (such a s the object’s OBSERVED attribute) that affect time sc ale conversion.  
 FAME’s four conversion techniques: DISCRETE, CONSTANT, LINEAR, and CU BIC. 
The chapter closes with detailed ex amples of the four conversion techniques  as they a pply to data with  
OBSERVED attribute END. Additional graphs show how the conversi on techniques behave with other 
OBSERVED attributes.  
Using Automatic Conversion  
FAME performs time scale conversion either ex plicitly o r automatically. For automa tic conversion, you set 
the CONVERT option so that FAM E temporarily treats all time series as though they are stored at the 
current frequen cy. 
The CONVERT o ption uses  two modifiers: AUTOMATIC and TECHNIQUE. Because the s ettings of each 
modifier are different, the modifiers can be omitted:  
 AUTOMATIC takes  the settings ON and OFF. FAME uses CONV ERT AUTOMATIC OFF  as the 
default. If you  omit the setting ( CONVERT AUTO), the  modifier ( CONVERT ON ), or both 
(CONVERT ), FAME assume s CONVERT AUTO ON . 
 TECHNIQUE takes any of the four se ttings: CONSTANT, LINEAR, CUBIC, or DISC RETE. We’l l 
discuss these l ater in th is chapter. FAME uses CONVERT TECHNIQUE CONSTANT  as th e 
default.

Hint Use the format that makes the mo st sense f or the applicatio n you are developing. For 
example, you may set the frequency onc e and then specify the conversion method as you 
need it, or set your favorite convers ion method once and specify the frequenc y as you need it.  
Using Explicit Convers ion 
Explic it time scale con version us es the CONVERT function to create one time series at a  new frequency.  
The CONVERT function takes four arguments in the following order:  
 The time series name or expression.  
 The new  frequency. If you omit the frequency, F AME uses t he current workin g frequenc y. If you 
want to omit the frequency but specify the t echnique, you must use an asterisk (*)  as a 
placeh older for the frequency in the list of arguments.  
 The conversion technique: CONSTANT, LINEAR, CUBIC, or DISCRETE. If you omit the 
conversion technique, FAME uses the technique speci fied by th e CONVERT option.  (The defa ult 
setting for the CONVERT option is CONSTANT.)  
 The O BSERVED attribute to be used in converting the time series or formula or global formu la 
that returns numeric/precision time s eries.  If you omit the OBSERVED attribut e and you’ re 
converting a s eries or formula or global formula , FAME uses its OBSERVED attri bute for the 
conversion. If you omit the OBSERVED attribute and you’re converting an expression, FAME 
uses the setting of the  OBSERVED option for the conversion. In either cas e, the setting of  the 
OBSER VED option is assigned as the OBSERVED attribute for t he series returned by the 
CONVERT function.  
As with other functions, the arguments ar e enclosed in parentheses and separated by commas. You may 
omit any of the last three argu ments and FAME wi ll supply the default. If you want to omit an argument, 
but supp ly a subsequent argument, you must use an asterisk (*) as a place holder for the omit ted 
argument. The function uses any of t he following forms:  
CONVERT  (time -series,  freq uency,  conversion -technique,  OBSERVED -attribute, &&  
     BASIS-attribute,  IGNORE -boolean-setting)  
 
CONVERT  (time -series,  freq uency,  *,  OBSERVED -attribute)  
 
CONVERT  (time-series,  *,  conversion -technique,  OBSERVED -attribute)  
 
CONVERT  (tim e-series,  *,  *,  OBSERVED -attribute) 
 
CONVERT  (time -series,  freq uency,  conversion -technique) 
 
CONVERT  (time -series,  *,  conversion -technique)  
 
CONVERT  (time -series,  fr equency)

When to Use Automatic or Explicit Conversion  
You should k now when to use t he differe nt methods of time scale conversion and when conversio n is 
unnecessary:  
 There are times when it seems appropriate to transform the frequenc y of a time series, but FAME 
does not re quire you to do so. For example, FAME’s GRAPH comm and can plot data  of differ ent 
frequencies against a single axis, so time series conversion is not necessary. The following 
GRAPH command is valid:  
GRAPH HS6P1, GNP, CONVERT (FYMFR, ANN)  
This one command di splays a monthly series (HS6P1), a quart erly serie s (GNP), and an a nnual 
series on a single graph.  
 The COPY command is not affected  by time scale conversion. COPY always copies data at its 
original frequency.  
 Automat ic conversion with the CONVERT option tr ansforms an entire time series, regardle ss of 
the current date rang e. The adv antage to this is that you don’t have to worry that th e converted 
data values in a series might change when you change the date range.  
Explicit conversion with the CONVERT functio n limits the transformation of the objec t to the 
working date range . The adva ntage is that the function doesn’t transform data that  you don’t plan 
to use.  
 If you want a conversion to handle an object as though it had  a different OBSERVED attribute 
than it actually has, you can use the CONVERT fu nction wit h the OBSERVED at tribute ar gument. 
For example, the two following sets of stateme nts are equivalent:

www.fisglobal.com  183  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
OBSERVED (SIX) = AVERAGED  
CONVERT ON  
FREQUENCY MONTHLY  
NEW_SIX = SIX 
OBSERVED (SIX) = SUMMED  
NEW_SIX = CO NVERT (SIX, MONTHLY, *, AVERAGED)  
Notice  how the f irst example requ ires you t o change the OBSERVED attribute for the series SIX fro m 
SUMMED to AVERAGED and back to SUMMED. In both cases, the OBSERVED attribute of NEW _SIX is 
taken from the current setting o f the OBSERVED option.  
Factors Influenci ng Time Sc ale Conversion  
When FAME pe rforms a time scale conversion, it considers a number of factors:  
 The frequency of the existing time series and the frequency of the result ing series.  
 The OBSERVED attribute of th e original series: ANNUALIZED, AVERAGED,  BEGINNING , END, 
FORMULA, H IGH, or LO W. 
 The BASIS attribute of the original series: BUSINES S or DAILY.  
 The setting of the IGNORE option.  
 The conversion technique: CONSTANT, CUB IC, DISCRETE, or LINEAR.  
Understanding t he Four Conversion Techniques  
FAME suppo rts four c onversion techniq ues, which  are, in order of increasing computational effort:  
DISCRETE 
CONSTANT  
LINEAR  
CUBIC  
To understand these techniques, you first must understand  the basic concepts of aggregation and 
distribution as they apply to FAME’s OBSE RVED attri bute settings.  
 Aggregation is the process of combining values at a higher frequen cy (for example, DAILY) to 
form a corresponding value for a lower frequency (for exam ple, MONTHLY).  
 Distribution is  the proce ss of spreading a  single va lue at a lower frequency (for example, 
MONTHLY) to for m values for a higher frequency (for example, DAILY).  
 Conversions between frequencies  at the same level, such as ANNUAL(AUG) and ANNUAL(DEC) 
are treated as aggregati ons. 
At the end of this cha pter, ther e are six pages of graphs illustrating aggregation and  distribution for 
different OBSERVED attributes. Referring to these graphs will help you to follow the discussion of the 
different conversion techniques. The first t hree pages  show aggregation  for OBSER VED END 
(BEGINNING follows similar rules), OBSERVED LO W (HIGH is similar), and OBSERVED AVERAGED

www.fisglobal.com  184  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
(SUMMED is similar, AVERAGED and FORMULA a re identical). The last three pages of g raphs show the 
corresponding distributio ns. 
Aggreg ation 
To aggregate three monthly values  to a quarterly value, FAME applies the operation implied by the 
OBSERVED attribute a s follows:  
 OBS ERVED   operation  
 
 SUMMED   sum them  
 AVERAGED   average them  
 ENDING   take the last value  
 BEGINNING   take the first value  
 HIGH    take the maximum  
 LOW    take the minimum  
(As m entioned above, the OBSERVE D attributes ANNUALIZED and FORMU LA are treated the s ame as 
AVERAGED.) In cases of pure ag gregation (where each target period is entirely compos ed of input 
periods that lie completely within it), all of FAME ’s conversion techniqu es give the same result, as 
described by  the above table. In fact, FAME  makes us e of this fact to  avoid the  work of L INEAR or CU BIC 
conversions in the case of pure aggrega tion. 
Distribution  
To distribute one quarterly value over three months, FAME chooses the monthly values so that they 
aggregat e to the correct quarterly value. Obviou sly, there  are many ways to  choose su ch values. (For 
instance, [1,2,3], [2,3,1], [4,0,2], a nd [0,6,0] all aggregate to 6 with OBSERVED SUMMED, and to 2 with 
OBSERVED AVERAGED; while [1,2,3], [3,2,1], [0,3,1], and [3, 3,3] all aggregate to 3 with OBSERVED 
HIGH.) FAME’ s four conversion  technique s specify four plausible ways to choose one set of val ues that 
aggregate to the desired value.  
The DISCRETE Conversion Technique  
The DISCRETE techn ique shoul d be regarded as a “quick a nd dirty” method when speed is the overriding 
concern.  For the DISCRETE technique, FAME treats all conversions as either a simple aggregati on or a 
simple distribution. (Aggregatio n is used for the case of equal length p eriods wit h different endin g points, 
for example, different weekly frequencies.)  
For aggreg ation, the input periods that end in the target period are aggregated to give the tar get value. 
See the bottom graph of the f irst three graph pages for examples of a ggregation  with TECHNIQUE 
DISCRETE.  
For distribution, the input value is distributed over t he target periods that end in the input period. For 
DISCRETE distribution with OBSERV ED END (BEGINNING), the last (first) tar get period ending in the

www.fisglobal.com  185  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
input period re ceives the  input value and all other periods ending in the input period are set to ND. For all 
other OBSERVED attributes, all target periods ending in the input period are give n the same value. 
Together with the cons traint that the target periods ending in  the input  period should ag gregate to  the 
input value, this uniquely determines the values for the target periods. See the bottom graph of the fourth 
through sixth graph pages for examples of DISCRETE distribution.  
DISCRETE conversion treats all input peri ods that e nd in a given tar get period  as though they were 
entirely contained in that target  period. As a consequence, DISCRETE aggregation  tends to shift values 
forward in time  whenever periods do not match up nicely , while DISCRETE distribution  tends to s hift such 
values backward i n time. Th erefore, if you use the DISCRETE technique to convert a WEEKLY(FRI) 
series to WEEKLY(WED) and back again, the result will be shifted one en tire period forward, since both 
conversi ons are treated as aggregations.  
The Con tinuous Ti me Conversion Tec hniques  
The remaining techniques, CONSTANT, LINEAR, and CUBIC, all operate (conce ptually) in two steps:  
 They build a “con tinuous time” representation of the inpu t series ( this is the ultim ate in 
distribution).  
 They aggregate the continuous time represe ntation to the desired frequency.  
The three techniques differ in the way that they bu ild the continuous time representation. Since building 
the continuous time repre sentation is a form of dist ribution, these techniques differ only in the way they do 
distri bution. 
The Continuous Time Representation  
The continuous time representation is a ma thematical abstraction of what the serie s might have been at 
each instant in tim e, if its values were sprea d out smoo thly. Of course, the continuous time representation 
is chosen so that it aggregates to the correct values at the input frequency.  
For the O BSERVED attributes AVERAGED and SUMMED, aggregation of such a continuous time 
representati on requires integ ration (as  defined in the integral calculus). But, if you think instead of 
averaging or summing a SECONDLY time series, you will have a very good app roximation.  
The Importance of the BASIS Attribute  
The BASIS a ttribute determines which of two continuous time scale s is used, DAILY or BUSINESS. The 
DAILY basis uses ordinary time measured in days (or  fractions of days) elapsed since the be ginning of 
1850. The BUSINESS basis coun ts only we ekdays.  
The BUSIN ESS basis is appropriate for data that measures things (like sto ck trading) that just don’t 
happen on weekends. This includes most data at the BUSINE SS frequency, and also data at lower 
frequencies (WEEKLY, MONTHLY, and so on) th at was gat hered by aggregat ing data f rom weekdays.  
By default, FAME gives BUSINESS frequenc y data the BASIS attribute BUSINESS, and all other 
frequencies of data the BASIS attr ibute DAILY. The BASIS attribute and its  effects on time scale 
conversion are di scussed in  the chapter  DATA ATTRIBUTES  (p. 148).

www.fisglobal.com  186  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The CONSTANT Conversion Technique  
The three di fferent continuous time techniques corre spond to t hree different wa ys of maki ng the idea of 
“spreading values out smoothly” precise . In the CONSTANT technique, the continuous time 
representation is chosen so that it is level throughout each input period. T his means that the continuous 
time repre sentation has sudden change s in value  between the end of one period and the start of the ne xt. 
It is not hard to see that the condition that the representation be constant in e ach input period, together 
with the cond ition that it aggregate to the value for  that peri od, completely de termines t he representation 
for each of FAME’s OBSERVED attribut e values. In fact, the CONSTANT continuous time representation 
in a period is just th e input value for that period, except in  the case of OBSERVED SUMMED, where it i s 
the inpu t value divided b y the numb er of days in the period. Hence, FAME really has littl e or no work to do 
to calculate the CONSTANT continuous time representation, and the CON STANT technique is only 
slightly slow er than the DISCRETE technique.  
The top graph on t he six pages of g raphs at t he end of the chapter shows CONVERT TECHNIQUE 
CONSTANT . The first three pages show aggregation; the last three show distribution.  
Time scal e conversion for intraday and daily patt ern frequencies  
The CONSTANT technique d oes not ex trapolate the inp ut values to gaps in the intraday pattern and daily 
pattern freq uencies. This means that if an input value is not defined for a particular observatio n, then that 
value is not extrapolated i n the corresponding output. If values ar e outside of the target fre quency ran ge, 
they are considered NC or ND.  
When doing time scal e conversion from a higher frequency to a lower frequency , for CONSTANT 
SUMMED, the v alue for a particular period at the targ et frequency is calculated as the sum of  the input  
values of only t hat period  at the source frequency . For CONSTANT AVERAGE, the va lue for a particular 
period at the target frequency is calculated as the average of t he input values of only that period at t he 
source frequency.  For CONSTANT SUMMED , CONSTANT  AVERAGE, CONSTAN T HIGH, an d 
CONSTANT LOW observed attributes, NC is returned for  the periods because borrowing of input values 
within the date range is not allowed. For CONSTANT BEGINNING and CONSTANT END,  ND is returned 
for the periods that are  not defin ed in the input s eries. For CONSTANT BEGINNING and CONSTANT 
END, ND is returned f or periods that are not defined in the input series.  
When doing time scale conversion  from a lower frequency to a higher freq uency , for CONSTANT 
SUMMED, the value fo r a partic ular period at th e target f requency is calculated as the input value at the 
sourc e frequency divided by the number of periods at the target frequency preceding and in cluding that 
period. For the next period  in the target date range, the value is calculated  as the input val ue divided  by 
the number of periods at the target frequency prec eding and including that period but occurring after the 
previous period at the source  frequency. For CONSTANT AVERAGE, the va lue for a particular period at 
the targe t frequenc y is calculated a s the inpu t value at the source frequency. This value is applica ble to 
all the periods at the target frequency preceding and including that period. F or the next period in the 
target date ra nge, the value is calculated as the inpu t value at  the source frequ ency. This  value is 
applicable to all the periods at the target frequency preceding and including that period but occurring after 
the previous period . For CONSTANT BEGINNING and CONSTANT EN D, ND is returned for periods that 
are n ot defined  in the input ser ies only w hen IGNORE is set to OFF. If the source frequency is 
BUSINESS, the BASIS attribute is also considered as BUSINESS. As a result, NC is retur ned for periods 
occurring on Saturday an d Sunday.

www.fisglobal.com  187  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
How CONSTANT and DISCRETE Conv ersion Dif fer 
The C ONSTANT technique differs from the DISCRETE technique primarily in the way that it ha ndles 
conversion when a short period ove rlaps two long periods. DISCRETE allocat es the sho rt period entirel y 
to the s econd long period, while CONSTANT allocates it proport ionately to the amount of overlap.  
The other important difference between the CONSTAN T and DISCRETE techniques arises with th e 
OBSERVED attributes BEGINNING and END.  CONSTANT assigns values to  all targe t periods, while 
DISCRETE assigns values only to the f irst or last target period ending in the input period.  
The LINEAR and CUBIC Conversio n Techniques  
For the LINEAR and CUBIC te chniques, the continuous time representa tion is a linear or cubic s pline. 
The graph of a linear spline consists of straight line se gments (equation y = ax + b) that join each other at 
the end points. (These joining p oints are called the knots  of the spline .) 
A cubic spline is similar to a linear  spline, e xcept that:  
 Inste ad of bein g pieced together from straight lines, it is pieced to gether from cubic curves 
(equation y = ax3 + bx2 + cx + d).  
 Instead of merely having the same value at the knots, the pieces are required to have the same 
value, slo pe, and cu rvature at the kn ots (that is, in terms of the calculus, the value of the functio n 
and its first two derivatives must match).  
In practice, this means that when you lo ok at a plot of a cubic spline, the curv e is so smooth that you 
cannot tell wher e the knot s are. 
The middle  two graph s on the six pages of graphs at the end of the chapter  show the techniques LINEAR 
and CUBIC. The first three pages show aggregation; the la st three show distribution.  
Time scale c onversion for intraday and daily pattern  frequenci es 
When using CON VERT TECHN IQUE LINEAR time scale conversion, if the input freque ncy is continuous, 
you do not need to apply CONVERT TECHNIQUE CONSTANT when convertin g to higher frequency. To 
obtain behavio r similar to time scale conversion that uses conti nuous frequency, apply CONV ERT 
TECHNIQUE CONSTANT before applying CONVERT TECHNIQ UE LINEAR for aggregation scenarios 
for intraday pattern and daily pattern frequencie s. If the values are out of the frequenc y range, they are 
considered NC or ND.  
When using CONVERT TECHNIQUE  CUBIC tim e scale conversion, if input frequency is continuous, 
there is no need to apply CONVERT TECHNIQUE CONSTANT when converting to higher freque ncy. To 
obtain behavior similar to time scale conversion that uses continuous fr equency, a pply CONVERT 
TECH NIQUE CONS TANT before applying CONVERT TECHNIQUE CUBIC for aggre gation scenarios for 
intraday pattern and daily pattern frequencies.  
Technical Discus sion of Spline Conversions  
For the LINEA R and CUBIC spline techniques, FAME plac es the kno ts as follows:  
 For OBSERVED  BEGINNING, at the beginning of the input period.  
 For OBSERVED END, at the end of the input period.

www.fisglobal.com  188  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 For all other OBSERVED attributes, at t he midpoints of the input periods.  
It turns out that if you place knots in all i nput perio ds for LINEAR, an d all but the first and last input 
periods for CUBIC, then the c ondition that the spline aggregate to the correct value in each input period, 
togethe r with the definition of a linear or cub ic spline, gives a system of linear equa tions with  a unique 
solutio n, with tw o exceptions. In the case of OBSERVED HIGH and OBSERVE D LOW, you only get 
upper or lower bounds on the spline instead of equations. For thi s reason, FAME never uses spline 
techniq ues when converting series with HIGH or LOW OBSERV ED attributes. In stead, it automatically 
substitutes the CONSTANT technique for s uch series when you request LINEAR or CUBIC.  
FAME needs at least two non -missing inpu t values to compute a linear spline, and  at least four to 
compute a CUBIC spline . If you s pecify the CUBIC technique for a series with two or three values, FAME 
will use L INEAR instead. If you specify either LINEAR or CUBIC for a series with only one value , FAME 
will use CONSTANT instead.  
Those with mathematical inclinations will note  that each  of the three con tinuous ti me representations 
(CONSTANT, LINEAR, and CUBIC) is sp ecified by a small number of constants in each time period (or 
region between knots).  The form of the representation is one f or which the integral is easily calculat ed in 
closed form. This mak es it easy  for FAME to aggregate these representations to any de sired frequency 
using any observed attribute.  
The Effect of the Date Range on Spline Conversions  
For spline techniques, the r ange of input periods over which the spl ine is com puted can affect the result  in 
a given target period.  
For explicit  conversion wit h the CONVERT function, FAME converts the current DATE range to the 
frequency of the series being converted and computes the spline over that range. It then converts  the 
DATE range to the targ et frequen cy and aggregates the spline over that range.  
For automatic conversion with the CONVERT option, FAME computes the spline over the range * t o *. 
FAME does this because the user can not always specify the desired date rang e for the conversion, since  
other fac tors may dictate a different range.  
For instance, the date range for the command DISPLAY <JAN90 TO DEC90> SALES was set to 
determine the ra nge of values printed out; but if SALES is being automatically converted, the us er might 
prefer some values  from Dece mber of 2009 to affect the spline calculation. FAME en sures consistent 
results by always computing the spline over the range * to * when do ing automatic  conversions using 
spline t echniques.  
The Effect of Missing Values on Convers ion 
It only remai ns to disc uss the treatment of missing values in conversion.  
The Effect on the DISCRETE and CONSTANT Techniques  
For DI SCRETE and CONSTANT conversion, if the I GNORE opti on is OFF, any mi ssing valu e in the 
values needed to compute a converted value gi ves a corresponding missing result. (We showed an 
example of the effect of the IGNORE  option earlier in this chapter.) If mul tiple missing values enter into 
the calc ulation, F AME applies its u sual hiera rchy to determine which missing value is assigned to t he 
result.

www.fisglobal.com  189  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Note that for the BEGINNING OBSERVED attribute, only the first input perio d in the target period enters 
into the c alculation. Similarly, for the END OBSER VED attrib ute, only the las t input pe riod in the target 
period enters into the calculation.  Therefore, missing values in other locations will not affect the result.  
If IGNORE i s ON and there is at least one non -missi ng value for the calculation, missing va lues are 
omitted. Thus, a m issing res ult occurs only if all the input values needed for a g iven target period are 
missing values.  
The Effect on the LINEAR and CUBIC Techniques  
For spline techniques, FAME uses the ava ilable data to calculate a spline from t he first n on-missing value 
in the inp ut to the last. Thus, the spline is defined over an in terval of time with no gaps. Missing values 
result in missing knots, hence in fewer e quations and fewer unknowns.  
FAME assign s non -missing results to all output peri ods for wh ich the spline ha s the nece ssary 
information. For AVERAGED and SUMMED, this means  all output periods contained in the spline interval. 
For BEGINNING or END, it means those beginning or ending in the spline interval. All output periods 
outside thi s range ge t ND values.  
The IGNORE opt ion has no effect on spline conversions.

www.fisglobal.com  200 FORMAT OUTPUT  
The defaul t formats that affect the appearance of FAME’s output have been carefully ch osen to be  
attractive in most c ircumstances. However, your specific application may require  a different look than that 
supplied by the default. Fortunately, FAME provides you a gre at deal of flexibility in formatting out put, not 
only in reports (where you expect suc h control) but also i n ordinary listings and analytical commands.  
You can alter t he appearance of three of FAME’s five data types by using formatting options:  
 You can dis play numeric data with a varying number of decimal places, and with or witho ut 
commas.  We’ll begin this cha pter by discussing the DECIMAL and COMMAS options that 
perfo rm these functions.  
 You can display numeric data in fractional format by taking advantage  of the FRACTION and 
DECIMAL options.  
 You can use the IMAGE DATE and IMAGE D ATE AXIS o ptions to display dat es using dynamic 
variables so that they can take on virtuall y any format that you can imagine.  
 You can use the IMAGE BOOLEAN option to display boolea n values as TRUE  or FALSE , YES or 
NO, ON or OFF, or related abbreviations.  
The two dat a types that cannot b e explicitly reformatted are namelists, which are usually ex panded 
anyway, and strings, which are stored and displayed exactly as you specify them.  
Case numbers are not a data type, but you  can format them in a variety of way s. You can  even substitute 
a series of labels for the case numbers on graphs and reports. T he IMAGE CASE and IMAGE CASE 
AXIS options provide this labeling flexibility.  
Controlling the Display of Decimal Places  
The DECIMA L option controls the number of deci mal places  that FAME displays i n numeric output. The 
DECIMAL option affects reports, lists produced by the DISPLAY command, and some of the fields in the 
output of analytical comma nds such as the EXTRAPOLATE and SUMMARIZ E commands.  
The option takes a posit ive or neg ative integer, the nu mber 0, or the keyword AUTO as its setting:  
 If you specify a  positive integer, FAME uses the integer to control the number of decimal places 
that app ear to the right of the decimal point. F or example, DECIMAL 4  causes PI to a ppear as 
3.1416; DECI 2  causes PI to appear as 3.14.  
 If you specify the number 0, FAME does  not print fractional digits or a decimal point. DECIMAL 0  
causes PI to appear as 3 and 9 8.6 to appear as 99, for example.  
 If you  specify a negative integer, then FA ME rounds the numeric value on the output to the 
specified number of places to the left of the decimal. For example, DECIMAL -2 causes the

www.fisglobal.com  201  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
number 2627.3  to be expressed as 2600, th e number 2983.5 to be expressed as 3000,  and the 
number 15 to be expressed a s 0. 
 If you specify AUTO, FAME maximizes the number of significant digits it displays. FAME uses 
scientific notation for values that are very  close to zero so that you can see the n on-zero digits 
(FAME will always use  scientifi c notation for extrem ely large numbers, regardless of the setting of 
the DECIMAL option). FAME does not print the decimal point if it does not also print digits to the 
right of the decimal.

Controlling the Appe arance of Fractions  
The FRACTION option, together with a special setting of the DECIMAL o ption, allows you to display 
fractional values instead of decimals. The FRAC TION optio n has four settings:  
 FRACTION R, the default, causes numbers to be printed in eig hths. Instead of a decimal point, 
FAME inserts the character r to indicate eighths. The n umber 5.5 is displayed as 5r4 (five and 
four eighths).  
 FRACTION X  causes num bers to be  printed in sixteenth s. Instead of a decimal point, FAME 
inserts the character x to indicate sixteenths. The number 5.5 is displayed as 5x8 (five and eight 
sixteenths).  
 FRAC TION T  causes numbers to be printed i n thirty -seconds. Instead of a decim al point, FAME 
inserts the char acter t to indicate thirty -seconds. The number 5.5 is displa yed as 5t16 (five and 
sixteen thirty -seconds).  
 FRACTION L  causes numbers to be printed us ing the least common denominator of the three 
formats, R, T, and X. For exam ple, 3.062 5 is displayed as 3x1 (three and one sixteenth).  
None of the fractional formats i s used unless you also specify DECIMAL FRACTION . 
Just as it does with decimals, FAME roun ds to the nearest fraction. The followin g report compares the 
same data valu es printed  using several differ ent formats:

Controlling the Appearance of Dates and  Date Valu es 
Dates appear as pa rt of the output of many FAME commands. FAME allows you to s pecify the format for 
dates in your output. For example, the date January 5, 2009, can ap pear in any of the following forms in a 
report or a graph:  
JAN09 
5-Jan-09 
Jan. 5, '09  
January 5, 2009  
JAN 5 (2009) 
January 5th  
5 JAN 09  
V JAN MMIX 
You control the actu al format of dates on reports with the IMAGE DATE option and on graphs with the 
IMAGE DAT E AXIS option. These options use dynamic  string date variables  to designate the format  for 
dates. Two funct ions, DATEFMT and TODAY, also use dynamic string variables t o designate the format 
for dates.  
Dynamic string date variables specify a format for a da te. When FAME prints a date on a report or a 
graph, FAME dynamically substit utes the a ctual date for the st ring date variable that you specify.  
To specify a dynamic st ring date variable, you enter special names inside angle brackets (<>) as part of a 
string. Like other strings in FAME, date stri ngs must be enclosed in double quote s; for exa mple: 
IMAGE DATE "<MT XTL> <YEAR>" 
IMAGE DATE "<MTXTL> OF <YEAR>"  
In the first exa mple, the string contains two dynamic string date variables separated by a space. In the 
second example, literal text is also inc luded with the dynamic string date v ariables. Next, we’ll explain 
how these dynamic string date variables work.  
Dynamic String Date Variables  
Dynamic string date variables consist of a root and an optional suffix.  
Roots for Dates  
There are thirteen legal r oots for dynamic string date variabl es; they a re defined below:  
 F prints text describing the frequency of the date; for example , DAILY  or MONTHLY .

www.fisglobal.com  205  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 Y prints the two -digit year number; for example, 80 or 89. 
 YEAR  prints the four -digit year number; for exampl e, 1981  or 1989 . 
 FY prints the two -digit fisca l year number; for ex ample, 82 or 89. (FAME bases the fiscal year on 
the setting of the YEAR option.)  
 FYEAR  prints the four -digit fiscal year number; for example, 1983  or 1989. (FAME bases the 
fiscal year on th e setting of the YEAR option.)  
 P prints period -of-year information;  for example, 1 or 4. 
 FP prints period -of-fiscal -year inform ation; for example, 2 or 4. (FAME bases the fiscal year on 
the setting of the YEAR option .) 
 M prints month information; for examp le, 3, MAR , or March . 
 W prints weekd ay informa tion; for example, 2, MON, or Monday . 
 D prints the day of the month, for example,  10 or 31. 
 HH prints the hour of the day, for example, 9 or 15. 
 MM prints the minute of t he hour, for example 07 or 45. 
 SS prints  the second of the minute, for examp le 03 or 24. 
With the exception  of the root F (which displays the frequency), FAME uses an integer to represent the 
date information when you do not specify a suffix. For example, FAM E displays January as 1 with the 
“<M> ” dynamic variable; FAME displays We dnesday as  4 with the “<W>” dyn amic variable.  
Suffixes for Dates  
There are nine legal suffi xes for dynamic string date variables. In some instances, several suffixes may 
have the s ame effect with a particular root. The s uffixes are defined below:  
 R causes the number  to be printed as a R oman numeral; for example, XI or VII. 
 S pads the number to t he left with an appropriate number of spaces; for example, “    1” or “  99” . 
 Z pads the number to the left with an appropriate n umber of leading zeros; for example 002 or 
098. 
 T uses the shortest  possible uppercase textual form; for example, M for Monday or J for January.  
 TL uses the shortest possible lowercase textual form; for example, t for Tuesday or f for February.  
 TXT uses an  abbreviated uppercase textual form;  for examp le, WED  or MAR . 
 TXTL  uses an abbreviated uppercase and lowercase textual form; fo r example, Thu or Apr. 
 TEXT  uses a full -length uppercase textual form; for example, FRIDA Y or SEPTEMBER . 
 TEXTL  uses a full -length  uppercase and lowercase textual for m; for exa mple, Saturday  or 
October. 
Four combinations of roots and suffixes are illegal: F  (by itself), FR (for roman numeral frequencies), FS 
(for frequencies padded with spaces) , and FZ (for frequencies padded with ze roes).  
Hint Two basic rules may help  you remem ber the various text suffixes:
