o The degree of abbreviation of the word TEXT  corres ponds to the amount of abbreviation 
in the text representation. For example, TEXT  prints the complete word, TXT prints a 
partial word, and T prints the shortest poss ible versi on of the word.  
o The t railing letter L causes lowercase letters to appear where th ey are appropriate. For 
example, TEXT  prints the complete word with all uppercase letters , TEXTL  prints the 
complete word with up percase and lowercase letters.  
The < FISCAL> Da te Variable  
A special  string date variable, <FISCAL> , can be incorporated as part  of a dynamic date string. If the 
YEAR option (see the chapter  FREQ UENCIES, DATES, AND CASES  (p. 61)) has been used to speci fy a 
fiscal year ending in a month other than December, then  the variable <FISCAL> is replaced with the 
string FY (a blank follows the Y). If YEAR EN D DECEMBER  (the default) is in effect, < FISCAL> is 
replaced with a null stri ng. 
The <F ISCAL> variable can r educe the confusion that often surrounds the use of fiscal y ears by making it 
more readily apparent when fiscal year dates are being used. For exampl e, suppose that today’s date is 
June 1, 1989, that we’re working with quarte rly data, and that YEAR END SEP TEM BER  is in effect. This 
means that today falls in the thir d fiscal  quarter of fiscal  year 1989 (the third quarter includes April, May, 
and June), e ven though June is part of the second calendar  quarter of calendar  year 1989 . Then the  
format IMAGE DATE QU ARTERLY “<FY>Q<FP>”  displays today’s date as 89Q3 , while the  format 
IMAGE DATE QUARTERLY “<FISCAL><FY>Q<FP>”  displays today’s date more revealingly a s FY 
89Q3 . 
Interpretation of Dynamic Str ing Date Variables  
When interpreting  the dynam ic string date variab le, FAME uses the time period that contains the end of 
the interval corresponding to the date. Three examples clarify this:  
For the DAILY date 9APR84 : 
<Y> is 84.  
<M> is 4.  
<D> is 9.  
<W> is 2. (April 9, 1984, is a Monday.)  
 
For the MONT HLY date APR84:  
<Y> is 84. 
<M> is 4.  
<D> is 30. (30 is the last day of April, the  month in which APR84 ends.)  
<W> is 2. (April 30 is a Monday.)  
 
For the ANNUAL date 1984:  
<Y> is 84.  
<M> is 12. (December is the last month of 1984.)  
<D> is 31. (The  31st is t he last day of Decemb er of 1984.) 
<W> is 2. (December 31, 1984, is a Monday.)

Using Dynamic String Date Variables  
Two date options, IMAGE DATE and IMAGE  DATE AXIS, use dynamic string date vari ables. Three 
functions, DATEFMT, MAK E, and TOD AY, also use dynamic string variables.  
The IMAGE DATE option determines the defau lt appearance of date labels in display listings, reports, 
analytical output, and all oth er forms of printed output.  
The format o f date tick labels on graphs is dete rmined by the IMAGE DATE AXIS o ption which is 
discussed in the FAME G RAPHICS  USER GUIDE. 
Two functions, DATEFMT and TODAY, can have their own label formats specified, or they will default to 
the current setting of the VA LUE context of the IMAGE DATE option  (see belo w). 
The MAKE function  can be used to convert a string into a date at a specified frequency, using the form 
MAKE( DATE( frequency), string -expression, image -rule) . If you use IMAGE as the image -rule, FAME 
will u se the setting of the VALUE context of the IMA GE DATE option as an extra format for interpreting 
string -expression . What this m eans is that you can use the MAKE function to read a date that is specified 
in a non -FAME  format. See the C OMMAND  REFERENCE  for details.  
The IMAGE DATE option takes two kinds of modifiers: context  modifiers that tell where the option is used, 
and frequency  modifiers that tell which frequency class is being affected:  
 The four context modifiers are ROW, COLUMN, INDEX, and VALUE.  
 The s ixteen frequency modifiers are ANNUA L, SEMIANN UAL, QUARTERLY, BIMON THLY, 
MONTHLY, TWICEMONTHLY, BIWEEKLY, TENDAY, WEEKLY, BUSIN ESS, DAILY, HOURLY, 
MINUTELY, SECONDLY, PPY, and YPP.  
If you specify both a context and a  frequency, FAME narrowly focuses the op tion setting. If you omit one 
modifi er, FAME a pplies the option for  all contexts or all frequencies that you do specify. If you  omit both 
modifiers, FAME applies the option setting in all possible cases.

www.fisglobal.com  210

Each modifie r pair takes as its setting a string of text enclosed in quotes; the string contains o ne or more 
dynamic st ring date variables enclosed in angle brackets.  
You can set the IMAGE DATE option either by rows or by columns; that is, you may specify IMAGE 
DATE f requency context  setting, context settin g or you may specify IMAGE DATE cont ext freque ncy 
setting, frequenc y setting. For example, you can set the following formats as  four option settings:  
IMAGE DATE MONTHLY VALUE "<MTEXTL> <Y>"  
IMAGE DATE MONTHLY INDEX " <MTEXT> <YS>"  
IMAGE DATE QUARTERLY VALUE  "<PTL> QTR OF <YEAR>"  
IMAGE DATE QU ARTERLY IN DEX "<YZ>:<PZ>"  
 
By setting the options as rows, you can achieve the same effect with the following two IMAGE DATE 
frequency  option settings:  
IMAGE DATE MONTHLY VALUE "<M TEXTL> <Y>", INDEX "<MTEXT> <YS>"  
IMAGE DATE QUARTERLY VALUE "<PTL> QTR OF < YEAR>", IN DEX  &&  
  "<YZ>:<PZ> " 
 
By setting the options as columns, you can achieve the sa me effect with the following two IMAGE DATE 
context  option settings:  
IMAGE DATE VALUE MON TH "<MTEXTL> <Y>", QUARTER &&  
  "<PTL> Q TR OF <YEAR>"  
IMAGE DATE INDEX MONTH  "<MTEXT> <YS>", QUARTER "<YZ>: <PZ>"

Controlling  the Appearance of Ca se Labels 
Case labels appear a s part of the output of all FAME case series. FAME allows you to specify the format 
for case labels in your output. For example, the case label 12 can appear in any of the fol lowing forms in 
a rep ort or a graph:  
12 
"12" 
12th 
12TH 
XII 
You control the actual  format of cases on reports with the IMAGE CASE option and on graphs with the 
IMAGE CASE AXIS option. These options use dynamic s tring case variables  to designate th e format f or 
case numbers on re ports and graphs.  
Dynamic string case variables specify a fo rmat for a case number. When FAME prints a case number on 
a report or a graph, FAME dynam ically substitutes the actual case for t he string case variable that you 
specify. 
To specify a dynamic stri ng variable, you enter variables inside angle brackets (<>) within a dynamic case 
string. Like other strings in FAME, a dynamic case string must be e nclosed in double quotes; for example:  
IMAGE CASE INDEX "<NS>"  
IMAGE CASE IN DEX "This is the <NTXTL> case"  
In the first example, the string only contains the dynamic s tring variable. In the second example, literal 
text is also included with the dynamic str ing variable. Next we’ll explain how the se dynamic string 
variables work.

www.fisglobal.com  216  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Dynamic Stri ng Case Variables  
Dynamic string case variables consists of a root and an optiona l suffix. As a special case, you can also 
specify a string case series in a dynamic strin g case label, using < SERIES:seriesname >. 
Roots and Suffixes  
The only legal r oot for dy namic string case var iables is the letter N. The root N instructs FAME to print t he 
integer corresponding to the case number.  
Legal dynamic string case variables are comp osed of the root with no suffix or with a single suffix. There 
are nine lega l suffixes . In some instances, several suffixes may have the same effect. The suffixes are 
defined as follows:  
 R causes the case number to be printed as a Roman numeral; for exampl e, VII or CIX. 
 S pads the case number to  the left with an appropriate number  of spaces  so that the total nu mber 
of characters available for the NS dynamic string case variable is five. For example, case number 
1 appears as “        1” , case number 22 appea rs as “      22” , and case number 2345 a ppears as “  
2345” . Case numbers wit h five or more digits are never  padded. 
 Z pads the case number to the left with an appropri ate number of zeros so that the total number 
of characters available for the NZ dynamic s tring case variable is five; for example  00003  or 
00345 . Case numbers with f ive or mor e digits are never pa dded. 
 T, TXT, and TEXT  all have the same effect. They append  a two-letter, uppercase suffix to the 
integer; for example, 1ST, 2ND, 3RD, or 99TH . 
 TL, TXTL, and TEXTL  all have the same effect . They append a two -letter, lowercas e suffix t o the 
integer; for ex ample, 4th, 9th, or 101st . 
For example, you can use the foll owing variables to format case numbers and display case number 24:  
Dynamic String Case Va riables    Interpretation  
“<N>”        24 
“No. <N>”       No. 24  
“<NS>”              24 
“<NZ>”        00024  
“THE <NT> ITEM”      THE 24TH ITEM  
“For the <NTL> time”      For the 24th time  
Dynamic String Case Labels  
In addition to dynamic string case variables , case series offer one additional method fo r labeling. You can 
use dynamic stri ng case labels to completely cu stomize case series.

www.fisglobal.com  217  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Dynamic string case labels can use the form “<SERIES:seriesname>.” For this type of labeling, 
seriesname  names a string -valued c ase series. You can use the <SERIES: ser iesname> specification in 
combinatio n with oth er strings, including  dynamic string case variables.  
For example, to label three values of a single case series with the texts Men, Women , and Total , you 
specify the foll owing sequence of statements:  
CASE 1 TO 3 
SERIES TEXTLABEL:STRING BY CASE = "Men", "Wo men", "Total"  
IMAGE CASE "<SERIES:TEXTLABEL>"  
REPORT SEX  
If you want to use the l abels stored in the series TEXTLABEL to label the bottom axis of a bar chart, 
specify the  following sequence of statements:  
IMAGE CASE AXIS "<SERIES:TEXTLABEL>"  
GRAPH SEX 
This capability is most o ften used for labeling the bottom axes of bar graphs.  
Using Dynamic String Case Variables and Labels  
Two options, IMAGE CASE and IMAGE CASE AXIS, use  dynamic string case variables and dynam ic 
string case labels:  
 The IMAGE CAS E option d etermines the appeara nce of case labels in display listings, reports, 
analytical output, and all other forms of printed output.  
 The IMAGE CASE AXIS option determines the appearance of tick labels on graphs; we discuss 
the IMAGE CASE AXIS option i n the FAME  GRAPHICS  USER GUIDE. 
The IMAGE CASE option uses the INDEX, ROW, and COLUMN modif iers. INDEX specifies the case 
format for analytical output and subscripts. ROW specifies  a row label in a DISPLAY or REPORT 
comm and. COLUMN specifies the heading fo r a column  in a REPORT command.  
Each modifier pair takes as its setting a string of text en closed in double quotes; the string contains one 
or more dynamic string case variables or  labels enclosed in angle brackets.  
If you omit the modifier, then FAME sets  the forma t for all three field s (INDEX, ROW, and COLUMN). This 
is the simplest way to set the IMAGE CASE option.  
FAME uses the following default setting for the IMAGE CASE option:  IMAGE CASE INDEX “<N>”, ROW 
“<N>”, COLU MN “<N>” .

Controlling the Appearance of Boolean Data  
By defau lt, boolean values appear as TRUE or  FALSE, re gardless of how you e nter them. When you 
display the stored values, there may be contexts where TRUE and FALSE seem inappropriate. When 
such a situation arises, you can u se the IMAGE BOOLEAN option to change th e appearance of boolean 
values. One function, MAKE, can use the set ting of the IMAGE BOOLEAN option as the format for 
convertin g a string to a boolean value.

www.fisglobal.com  220  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The IMAGE BOOLEAN option  controls how boolean values are dis played. It  has a single, option al 
modifier, VALUE, which exists primarily to make the optio n form similar to the IMAGE CASE and IMAGE 
DATE options. The option or modifier takes any  one of five settings:  
 TRUEFALSE  causes all boolean values to appear as TRUE  or FALSE . This is the default setting. 
 TF causes values to appear as T or F. 
 YESNO  causes values to appear as YES or NO. 
 YN causes values to be appear as Y or N. 
 ONOFF  causes valu es to appear as ON or OFF. 
The following  IMAGE BOOLEAN options affect the ap pearance o f a boolean scalar an d a boolean series 
that we display:  
* TYPE B_VALUE  
TRUE 
 
* IMAGE BOOLEAN VALUE YESNO  
* TYPE B_VALUE  
YES 
 
* TYPE @COMMAS  
NO 
 
* DISPLAY ANSWERS  
 
ANSWERS 
 
    1     YES  
    2     YES  
    3      NO 
    4     YES  
    5      NO  
    6     YES  
 
* DISPLAY <IMAGE BO OLEAN TF> ANSWERS  
 
ANSWERS 
 
    1     T 
    2     T 
    3     F 
    4     T 
    5     F 
    6     T 
 
The IMAGE BOOLEAN option affects all boolean out put, including the appearance of option references 
such as @COMMAS.  
The MAKE  function can be used to conver t a string into a boolean value, using the form 
MAKE(BOOLEAN , string -expression, image -rule) . If you use IMAGE as the image -rule, FAME will use 
the s etting of the VALUE context of the IMAGE  BOOLEAN option as an extra format f or interpr eting 
string -expressi on. What this means is that you can use the MAKE function to  read a boolean that is 
specified in a non -FAME format. See the C OMMAND  REFERENCE  for det ails.

www.fisglobal.com  222 MORE ABOUT DATABASES  
Earlier in this guide in the chapter  INTRODUCTION TO DATABASES  (p. 40), we described the basic 
steps for creating a database, opening a database with all o f the different ACCESS modes, and closin g a 
database. In this section we’ll review tha t information and off er more advanced information about 
databases, including the following topics:  
 Creating databases.  
 Opening databases, handling databases with non -FAME  names, and the modes of access to 
datab ases.  
 Closing databases.  
 Opening dat abases fro m input files and pro cedures. 
 Cataloging databases and subsets of objects from da tabases.  
 Assigning description and documentation attributes to databases.  
 Resolving datab ase and data object naming conflicts.  
 Deleting databases from the system.  
 Changing the  order in which datab ases are searched for a data object.  
 Using the STORE option to specify which database stores newly created objects.  
 Posting and restoring databases t o insure that updates are not lost.  
 Using the temporary WORK database.  
FAME stores dat a objects in special database files, which are binary files designed for rapid re trieval of 
data. Your computer disk storage allocation constrains the size of your databa ses to one physical disk.  
FAME dynamical ly expands databases as you add data  objects. When you delete a dat a object from a 
database, FAME allows you to reuse the disk space with a new data object. Utilities are available to 
compress and verify your databas es. They are described in an appendix of  the C OMMAND  REFERENCE . 
You store, r etrieve, m anipulate, and delete  data using the name of the data object; FAME does the 
datab ase and data object formatting for you.  
Creating a FAME Database  
You create a new FAME datab ase file with the CREATE command usi ng the fol lowing form: CREATE 
filespec AS channel -name . FAME requires you to specify filesp ec although the AS channel -name  
clause is optional, as described below:  
 Filespec  names th e database file specification.

www.fisglobal.com  223  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
If the fi le specification is not enclosed in quotes, it  must follow FAME nam ing conventions. That 
is, the name must be 1 to 64 character s long; it must begin with a letter, a dollar sign ($), or a 
percent sign (%); and it may  contain letters, numbers, dollar signs ($), percent signs (%), pound 
signs (#), at -signs (@), underscores ( _ ), and dots (.).  
The file specification must also follow  all operating system conventions for your system. For 
example, some operating systems li mit file names to eight characters.  
If you do not specify an extension for t he databas e file, FAME automati cally supplies a default 
extension of DB. 
Information about using a file specification that is not a legal FAME name appears next in this 
section.  
 AS channelname  optionally specifies the na me for the channel that you’ll use f or the dat abase. 
We’ll describe  channels later in this chapter.  
You can repeat filespec AS channelname  any number of times, separated by commas, to create multiple 
databases and as sign multiple channels; for example:  
CREATE HOUSE  
CREATE SALES.DB  
CREATE MYB ASE.ABC AS  MBASE 
CREATE YOURBAS E AS YBASE, OURBASE.XYZ AS OBASE  
The first CREATE command cr eates a database file named HOUSE.DB. FAME assigns the DB extension 
to the file named HOU SE and assigns the channel named HOUSE t o the database file.  
The second CREA TE command  creates a database n amed SALES.DB and assigns it the channel name 
SALES.DB. When  you create or open a database using only filespec  and omitting AS channelname , you 
must use the entire filespec to refer to the database, even when the extension is  DB. 
The t hird CREATE command c reates a database named MYBASE.ABC and assigns it to the cha nnel 
MBASE.  
The last CREATE command creates two databases, YOURBASE.DB and OURBASE.XYZ, a nd assigns 
the first one to the channel YBASE and the second one to the chan nel OBASE.  
Channels  
FAME uses c hannels to communicate with open files. (FAME may also commu nicate with some devices, 
such as printers, via channels.) For example, you might have ei ght databases, three output files, one 
input command file, and one audit fil e open. FA ME uses the channel n ames that you assign to the 
databases and files to keep trac k of its communications and talk to each database or file.  
Usually, FAME uses a channel n ame that is the same as the root name of  the open file. For example, if 
you issue the CREATE SALES  command,  then the root name is SALES, the database file extension is  
DB, and FAME assigns the channel name SALES to the database. However, FAME gives you the  ability 
to assign a channel name that i s completely different from the file  name; for  example:  
CREATE OMCI S_DEC08.NDX AS DBASE  
This example simplifies the database na me. The database file, named OMCIS_DEC08.NDX, is referred 
to by its channel name, DBASE.

www.fisglobal.com  224  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
After you open a database in FAME, you r efer to it by its channel name, not the name u sed by the 
computer’s  operating system. In the above example, you refer to the da tabase as DBASE, not 
OMCIS_DEC08.NDX; for example:  
WHATS DBASE'SALE  
After the CREATE comm and shown above, the following command i s not legal:  
WHATS OMCIS_DEC08.NDX'S ALE    —Illegal channel specifi cation 
FAME allows you to use up to 250 channels at any time . Your operating system may have a stricter limit 
on open files.  
Opening a Database and C ontrolling the Access  
In most FAME sessi ons, you open a previously -created F AME databa se. At its simplest, the OPEN 
command specifies a channel name. FAME appends the extension DB to the channel name, then opens 
the corresponding system file. For example:  
OPEN SALES 
OPEN FORECAST, HISTORY  
The fi rst OPEN command opens the database SALES.DB. The second OPEN comma nd opens the 
databases FORECAST.DB and HISTORY.DB. FAME assi gns the channel names SALES, FORECAST, 
and HISTORY, to the respective databases.  
File Spe cifications and Channels  
If a database d oes not have the extension DB or if two databa ses have similar root  names, you can use a 
more explicit form of the OPEN command  to specify the file name and the channel name; for example:  
OPEN FOREXCH.FOR AS FX  
OPEN SALES.OCT AS OCT, SALES.NOV AS NOV  
OPEN OPEXOC93 AS A  
This method of ope ning a file allows you to substitute a simple channel name f or a complicated database 
name. Note that if we do not provide an extension in the specif ication of the file name, FAME 
automatic ally appends the extension DB. 
You c an always check to see what dat abases you’ve got open by giving the TYPE @OPEN.DB  
command . 
Databases with Non -FAME Names  
Sometimes you need to open  a database with a non -FAME name. This c an happen because the 
operating syst em allows you to give a file a name that is illegal in FAME, such as a name starting with a  
number, like 3RD_PLAN , or a name that is a reserved word, such as BLANK . Other times, th is can 
happen because you need to open a  database on someone else’s director y or on a common disk area, 
and the file specification that you need to use requires illega l characters such as slashes or brackets.

www.fisglobal.com  225  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
For example, if you are working in the UNIX ope rating system, you may want to open a da tabase called 
SALES.DB in the direct ory /users /jkg. The name SALES. DB is acceptable to FAME, but the file won’t be 
found by OPE N SALES because FAME will look at your directory, not at /users/jkg . Outside FAME, you 
can refer to the file as /users/jkg/sales. db. Within FAME, however, you need t o follow f ile specification 
conventions. 
FAME allows you to enclose any file specification inside double quotes to inform FAME that the enclosed 
text string may not represent a leg al FAME name, but that the string does c orrectly identify a file.  To open 
the database in the above example, we specify the following:  
OPEN "/users/jkg/sales.db" AS SALES  
This OPE N command opens the database using the c hannel name SALES. Whenever you encl ose the 
file name in double quo tes, FAME requires the AS channel -name  clause to define the channel name.  
Even when you enclose the file specification in quotes, you can omit the fi le extension if it’s DB. For 
example:  
OPEN "/users/jkg/sales" AS SALES  
This command is  equivalent to the OP EN command shown above.  
You can use a string literal as a fi le specification in every command that uses a file specification, including 
the COMPILE, CRE ATE, EDIT, EXHIBIT, INFO, INPUT, LOAD , OPEN, OUTPUT, PICTURE, REFILE 
and UNSAVE com mands.  
Controlling th e Access Mode  
FAME uses the ACCESS option as a command -speci fic or argument -specific modifier to the OPEN 
command to control the way you open a file . For example, in s ome situations, you may be permitted  only 
to read data that is stor ed in a database. In this case, you cannot update, delete, c reate, or otherwise 
alter the existing data.  
FAME offers five modes for opening a databas e: UPDATE, READ, CREATE, OVERWRITE, and 
SHARED.  
You cannot set the ACCESS op tion globa lly.  
The UPDATE Mode  
The default, ACCESS UPDATE, allows you to not only read from a database, but also to writ e to it: 
OPEN MYBASE  
OPEN <ACCESS UPDATE > MBASE_2  
OPEN BASE_3 AS B3 <ACCESS UPDATE>  
OPEN "C:\DEV\BASEFOUR"  AS FOUR 
The READ Mode  
The most frequently used database access mode is READ. ACCESS READ al lows several users to use a 
database sim ultaneously. If you open a database for readin g, you can retrieve i ts contents for display and

www.fisglobal.com  226  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
manipulation, and copy them to y our own database, but you cannot make any changes to the read only  
database:  
OPEN <ACCESS  READ> YOURBASE  
OPEN <ACCESS READ> YBASE 2 
OPEN B_THREE AS BASE3 <ACCESS READ > 
OPEN "C: \DEV\FOUR " AS FOUR < ACCESS READ> 
If you open a database with ACCESS UPDATE, CREA TE, or OVERWRITE, then no one else can access 
it. FAME does support “many readers and one  writer” by allowing one user to open a database ACCESS 
SHARED and many user s to open it ACCESS READ.  
The C REA TE Mode 
The third method, ACCESS CREATE, causes OPEN to function exactly like the CREA TE command. 
There is no difference betwe en the following commands:  
CREATE YO URBASE 
OPEN <ACCESS CREATE> YOU RBASE 
You cannot use the CREATE access mode if the database already exists.  
The OVERWRITE Mode  
If you want to create a new dat abase file, regardless of the existe nce of ano ther file with the sa me name, 
you can automatically replace the old file by speci fying ACCESS OVERWRITE:  
OPEN SALES.OCT AS OCT <ACCESS OVERWRITE>  
OPEN <ACCESS OVER> SALES .NOV AS NOV, SALES.DEC AS DEC  
ACCESS OVE RWRITE creates a new version of the file. On s ome operating systems , ACCE SS 
OVERWRITE also deletes the old version of the datab ase file.  
The SHARED Mode  
ACCE SS SHARED allows one user to open a data base for updating while other users open the s ame 
database with ACC ESS READ. For example, a system administrator can open a dat abase with ACCESS 
SHARED to enter new data values and analysts can open the same database  with ACCESS READ to 
manipulate the data : 
OPEN <ACCESS SHARED> PRICES                   --System administra tor 
OPEN <ACCESS READ> "/system/prices" AS PRICES --Analyst #1 
OPEN "/system/prices" AS PRI <ACCESS READ>    --Analyst #2  
Users who have the database  open for READ access will not see the c hanges made by the administrator 
until: 1) the  administrator closes  or posts the database; and 2) the user reopens the database .

www.fisglobal.com  227  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Limitations  
Once you open a database, you cannot chan ge the access mode. For example, if you open a file with 
ACCESS READ, but th en realize  that you must update  it, you must close it with the CLOSE command 
and then reope n it with the proper access mode.  
The ACCESS option that you specify must not conflict wi th any operating system access codes for  the 
database. For example, if the o perating s ystem protects a data base so that you can read it but not write 
to it, you cannot  use the ACCESS UPDATE option in FAME to change the data.  
You can always check the access  mode for a database by using the ACCESS  function ; for example , 
DISPLAY ACCESS (MYB ASE). The ACCESS function returns one of three access modes:  READ, 
SHARED, or UPDATE as a string.  
Closing Databases  
When you finish using a database,  you should close it, especially if it h as been opened with ACCESS 
UPDATE. Y ou can clo se a database in eith er of two ways:  
 Issue the EXIT command to leave the FAME sys tem and return to your operating system. FAME 
automatically closes all open databases and  text files.  
 Issue the CLOSE command wi th a list of database channel n ames or the keyword ALL. If you 
specify ALL, FAME closes eve ry channel you’ve opened, including channels assigned to 
databases and channels assigned to text files.  
The following session cov ers some of the topics we’ve discuss ed in this  chapter:  
* OPEN MYBA SE, YOURBASE.ABC AS YBASE<ACCESS READ>  
* DISPLAY ACCESS (MYB ASE), ACCESS (YBASE)  
 
ACCESS (MYBASE)  
 
UPDATE 
 
 
ACCESS (YBASE)  
 
READ 
 
 
* TYPE @OPEN.DB  
MYBASE, YBASE  
 
* CLOSE MYBASE  
* TYPE @OPEN .DB 
YBASE 
 
* CLOSE ALL  
* TYPE @OPEN. DB 
The ses sion shows the OPEN c omm and with two different access modes (MYBASE is opened wit h the 
default, UPDATE access), the ACCESS function, the @OPEN.DB system variable to displ ay the open 
databases, and the CLOSE com mand to close the various databases . At the end of the session, all of the 
databases are close d, so the final TYPE @OPEN.DB  command displays a blank line.

www.fisglobal.com  228  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Opening Databases from a Pro cedure or Input File  
Sometimes, when you  are building a system using a proce dure or an  input file for comma nd entry, you 
want to prompt a user for the name of a databa se to open. For example, you may want to print the 
following message:  
Please enter the na me of the historic database:  
The user sh ould respond, for example:  
Please en ter the na me of the historic da tabase:  HISTBASE.DB  
The procedure or input file then opens the appropriate database and assigns it to a predefined channel. 
FAME requires you to use  the FILE function with the OPEN command  for this usage. Where you would 
ordinarily en ter the file specific ation, you substitute FILE(string expression) , where string expression  
contains the string that the user specifies; for example:  
 
* EXHIBIT MYOPEN.IN P 
SCALAR DBSTRING:STRING  
RESPONSE KEYBOA RD 
PROMPT "Enter historic database n ame: ":DBS TRING 
OPEN FILE(DBSTR ING) AS HIST 
 
* INPUT MYOPEN  
Enter historic database name: M YBASE 
 
* TYPE @OPEN.DB  
HIST 
In this example, DBSTRING  (in the input file) is a string sca lar that contains a file specification s upplied by 
the user in response to t he prompt from the PROMPT comma nd. The user enters MYBASE  in response 
to the prompt, and FA ME opens the MYBASE database and assigns it to the channel HIST.  
You can use the FILE fun ction with any FAME command that accepts  a file specification. In addition t o 
the OPEN  and CREATE commands,  the COMPILE, EDIT, EXHIBIT, INFO, INPUT, LOAD, OUTPUT, 
PICT URE, REFILE, and UNSAVE commands can use the FILE function.  
Cataloging a Database  
The CATALOG command dis plays information about an open data base and i ts contents. The comm and 
has the form:  
CATALOG db -name'wildcard -specification  
The wildcard specification is optional. For example:  
CATALOG X_BASE  
CATALOG X_BASE'Y?  
The fi rst CATALOG command displays all the obj ects in the database; the second com mand displ ays all 
objects that begin with the letter Y. Depending on the type of access use d to open the database, the 
CATALOG command can display the following information for the  database and appropriate objects:

www.fisglobal.com  229  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 The n ame of the channel assigned to the d atabase.  
 The name of the file t hat stores the database.  
 The description of the database.  
 The creation date of the database.  
 The last update date for the database.  
 The documentation  of the database.  
 The name, basic charac teristics, and the description of ea ch data ob ject in the database or of 
each data object that meets the wildcard specification .

Restricting Data Object Classes for a Catalog  
The ITEM options allow you to specify the varieties of objects that you want to display wi th a wildcard 
specification of the CATAL OG command. For example, if you do n ot want to  include formulas amo ng the 
objects you’re displaying, you can use the following option to exclude formulas during wildcarding:  
ITEM CLASS FORMULA OFF  
We outlined the ITE M options earlier in this guide when we introduced wildcarding. For some set tings of 
the ITEM options, you can turn the entire setting off or on with a single command and then fine tune the 
option to display the results that you want; for example:  
ITEM CLA SS OFF, SERIES ON  
ITEM FREQUENCY OFF, MO NTH ON 
ITEM INDEX OFF, DATE ON  
This sequence o f statements turns of f all classes (series, scalars, and formulas), then turns se ries on; 
turns off all frequencies, then turns monthly on; and turns off both index types  (case and date), then turns 
date indexe s on. As a result, only monthly time  series ap pear when you use a w ildcard specification such 
as CATA MYBASE'? . 
The following l ist shows modifiers and settings that you can use with the ITEM options:  
ITEM ALIAS   OFF/ ON 
 
ITEM BASIS   OFF/ON  
   BUSINESS  OFF/O N 
   DAILY   OFF/ON  
 
ITEM CLASS   OFF/ ON 
   FORM ULA OFF/ON  
   SCALAR  OFF/ON 
   SERIES  OFF/ON  
 
ITEM FREQUENCY  OFF/ON  
   ANNUAL  OFF/ON 
   WEEKLY  OFF/ON  
   any frequency  OFF/ON  
 
ITEM INDEX   OFF/ON

Assig ning a Description and Documentation to a Database  
As with a data object, you can assign a description attribute and a documentat ion attribute to a database. 
Databas e descript ions and documentatio n can help you to remember the purpose of a database or to 
define a database for other users.  
Two additional database attributes, DIMENSION and EXTRA DOT S, are beyond the scope of this guide ; 
they are discussed in FAME’s C OMMA ND REFEREN CE.  
The database des cription attribute and the database documentation attribute assignment commands are 
identical in form to those for data objects:  
DESCRIPTION(db -name) = string-expression  
DOCUMENTATION(db -name) = string -expression  
You can use the DESCRI PTION and DOCUMENTATI ON attribute references to find the stored texts for a 
particular database. The attribute references may be abbreviated. The following example shows how to 
set these database attributes and  how to retrieve them:  
* OPEN MYBASE  
* DESC (M YBASE) = "Sample Seri es and Scalars"  
* TYPE DESC (MYBASE)  
Sample Series and Scala rs

Guide

database documentat ion with the FAME editor; for example:  
EDIT DOCU(MYBASE)  
Resolving Database and Data Obje ct Naming Conflicts  
Since the commands u sed to assign descriptions and docum entation t o data objects and to  databases 
are identical, how can FAME distinguish a channel  name from a data object name?  
The rule is that the channel name takes precedence over th e data object name. In the event that a 
command could refer to either a chan nel or a d ata object, FAME assu mes that you intend to specify the 
channel.  
To get the data object, preface its name with the channel name, followed by an apostrophe: channel -
name'd ata-object . 
This convention for referenc ing data objects is also useful when  multiple databases are open, s ince 
identically -named data objects may appear in several da tabases. The following FAME session illustrates 
how FAME resolves the ambiguity of like -named databases and data objects:  
 
* CREATE SAMPLE AS SAM  
* SERIES SAM  
* DESCRIPTION (S AM) = "First Descript ion" 
* DESC (SAM'SAM) = "Second Description"  
* CATALOG SAM

Unsaving Databases and Files  
We have alread y touched on the topic of unsaving databases with the discussion of the OPEN command 
and the ACCESS OVERWRITE option setting. How ever, sometimes you want to remove a  database from 
your disk withou t replacing it; in these cases, you should use the UNSAVE co mmand. First, if the 
database is open, you must close it. Then, you issue the UNSAVE comm and using the full file 
specification fo r the database name.  
At the end of t he followi ng session, you unsav e two databases:  
OPEN SALES.OCT AS OCT, SALES.NOV AS NOV  
     . 
     . 
     . 
CLOSE OCT, NOV  
UNSAVE SALES.OCT, SALES.NOV  
Because the UNSAVE command w orks only with files that are not curren tly open, you must specify a full 
database nam e, not just the chann el name, when you delete a database. Note that the UNSAVE 
command can unsave any file, not just FAME databases.  
Searching Through Databases

them contains a series  named SALES. Which SALES series appears when you issue the DISPLAY 
SALES statement?  
FAME searches all open databases in the order they were opened u ntil it finds a data object with the 
specified name. However, you are often most inter ested in the last dat abase you opened, not the first one 
that you opened. The SEA RCH command allows you to change your search list so that FAME searches 
databases in any order you specify.

Appendin g a Database to the Search List  
In the  examples of the SEARCH command, each new database that we opened was added to the search  
list automatically. The APPEND option d etermines whether FAME extends the s earch list  when we open 
new dat abases. 
APPEND ON , the default, causes newly opened database s to be added to the end of the search list. 
APPEND OFF  keeps newly opened databases from  being added automatically to the search  list.

Specifying a Database for Storing Data Objects  
Just as the SEARCH command controls the order in whic h FAME searches databases for data, the 
STORE option controls the database t hat FAME u ses for storing data.  
You may find the STORE option especially useful when you’re  developing an analysis. With the STORE 
option, you can ensure that temporary variables a nd preliminary results are stored in the  WORK 
database.  
By default, FAME sto res data o bjects in the first d atabase that you open with write access (ACCESS 
CREATE, OVER WRITE, SHARED, or UPDATE) in the search sequence. However, the STORE option 
allows you to  explicitly reassign data storage to any  database opened with write access. In the fol lowing 
example, FAME stores new data objects in the databases associated with the  channels BASE2 and 
MYBASE:  
 
* OPEN BASE1 <ACCESS READ>, BASE2, MYBASE  
* TYPE @STORE  
AUTO 
 
* SERIES ONE  
* TYPE DB(ONE)  
BASE2 
 
* STORE MYBASE  
* TYPE @STORE  
MYBASE 
 
* SERIES MYS ERIES 
* TYPE DB(MYSER IES) 
MYBASE 
 
This session uses the OPEN command to open thre e databases (two with the default ACCESS 
UPDATE), the @STORE option reference to display the setting of the STORE option , the SERIES

command to  create a new series,  the DB function to show where the series are stored, and th e STORE 
option to explicitly identify the database that stores newly created series.  
Post ing and Restoring a Database  
The POST an d RESTORE commands allow you to post  databases  so that you can retu rn to a database 
at a specific point in its development.  
The POST command causes FAME to post, or store, all data  updates that you’ve entered for one or more 
databases. To use the POST comm and, enter  the command name fol lowed by the keyword ALL or the 
name of the database or data bases that you want to post; for example  
POST ALL  
POST YOUTH, VIGOR  
The first POST comman d stores all changes made to any open da tabases. The second POST command 
saves updates  in the YOUTH and VIG OR databases.  
The RES TORE command causes FAME to restore a database to the status that it had at the time of t he 
last POST command. To use the RESTORE  command, enter the command name fol lowed by t he 
keyword ALL or the  name of the database or databases that you want to return t o their previous state; for 
example:  
RESTORE ALL  
RESTORE YOUTH, VIGOR  
The first RESTORE c omm and causes all open databases to retu rn to the status that they had when they 
were opened or last posted . The second RESTORE command returns two databases to the st atus that 
they had when they were opened or last posted.  
Users often think of the POST an d RESTORE commands as paired commands si nce they are often used 
together. Yo u can use the commands for a nu mber of clever applications:  
 You can POST a database before adding new data to series in the database. If the new data 
looks good after you’ve worked  with it, you close the database or POST  it again. If the data 
doesn’t look good, you can remove it by issu ing the RESTORE command. This allows you to test 
data before  saving it.  
 Many sophisticated users regularly POST their databases to make sure that the ir data is not lost 
if they have a hardw are failure. POST is often used with out RESTOR E to insure that upda tes will 
not be lost in the event of a crash, loss of commun ications, or other disaster.  
The following examples show how the POST and RESTORE command s work:

* CATALOG BASE1

Using the Tem porary WORK Database  
In an earlier chapt er, we introduced the WORK database,  the speci al temporary database  that FAME 
automatically creates at the beginning of every s ession and automatically unsaves at the end of the 
session.  
If you have never used a work space, you may ignore the WORK database and update data only in 
permanent da tabases or  in your own temporar y database. However, the WORK database can be very 
convenien t, particularly when you are doing exploratory or preliminary work. Many users perform 
experimental work in the WORK database and  copy data objects to permanent data bases as t hey want to 
save them . 
When you are uncertain about the effects of a command or a n option on your data, you may want to store 
the results of the command or option in the WOR K database. To do this, copy the data  you need to the

www.fisglobal.com  239  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
WORK database, clos e your per manent database (or s et SEARCH NONE  and STORE WORK ), and start 
testing. You may l earn a great deal about the command or option, and you will not add any unnecessary 
data to your permanent database.  
The WORK dat abase is always at the head of the d atabase se arch list; it is not named by the @SEARCH 
system variable  because you cannot move it out of first position, and you cannot close it except  by exiting 
FAME. If you enter the FAME environment, but do not open a datab ase, FAME creates new data obje cts 
in the WORK database. As soon as you open an update -acce ssible database, new data objects are 
stored there.  
There are several ways to explicitly store new data objects in the WORK datab ase. You can use the 
database label WORK' when  you create them. You  can use the option STORE WORK  to specify that all 
new data objects are stored in WORK. Or, in the NEW command, you can preface a data object name 
with a forward slash (/) to store it in th e WORK database.   For example, the following  sets of commands 
are equivalent:  
NEW WORK'EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
NEW /EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES 
/EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
STORE WO RK 
EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
The NEW c ommand als o allows you to prefa ce a new data object name with a minus sign ( -) as a 
shortha nd method of specifying OVERWRITE ON . For exa mple, the following sets of commands  are 
equiv alent: 
NEW <OVER ON> WORK'EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
NEW -/EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
-/EPS = EARNINGS / SHARES  
If you store new data objects in WORK, you can test a new scenar io without “committing it to paper,” 
since the new series and scalars must b e delibera tely copied to a perm anent database for them to be 
saved. By issuing the command SEARCH NONE, you can direct FAME to search only the WORK 
database for data objects.

www.fisglobal.com  242 TEXT FILES  
In addition to databases, FAME communicates with text files. Text files are system files that contain lines 
of text, or lines of character s. 
You can open a text file for a variet y of purposes in FAME:  
 As a place wh ere you ca n store commands and options for later input.  
 As an audit file to record commands  and options as you issue them.  
 To store output, such as reports and statistics, from you r FAME session.  
The next chapter of this  guide,  INPUT FILES  (p. 250), explains how to use text files for input. The last 
chapter,  CHANNELING AND OUTPUT FILES  (p. 274), explains how to use text files  for all classes of 
output. 
This chapter explains how to open, close, examine, re name, and unsave text files. You use many of the 
same commands that you use with database s to control your interactions with text  files, including 
CREATE, OPEN, CLOS E, and UNS AVE. Several differen ces exist between the ACCESS option as used 
with a database and as used with a text file. And, you must use the KIND option when you create or open 
a text file.  
Creating a Text File  
You can  create a text file with the CREATE command. I n the last chapter, w e showed that if you issue the 
command CREATE MYFILE , FAME c reates a database named MYFILE.DB and assigns it the channel 
name MYFILE.  
To create a tex t file, you must explicitly specify that  you want a text file by using the K IND option . You 
issue the KIND option on a command -specific or argument -specific basis; for  example:  
CREATE <KIND TEXT> AUDIT, FINAL  
CREATE MYDATA, MYFILE<KIND TEXT>  
The first CREA TE command creates two text files, one n amed AUDIT.TXT and one named FINAL.T XT. 
FAME u ses the TXT extension  as the default for text files. The channel names for the tw o text files are 
AUDIT and FINAL. The command opens the text files for writing, since it does not make sense to create 
an empty t ext file for reading.  
The second CRE ATE comman d creates the databas e named MYDATA.DB and the text file named 
MYFILE.TXT. The ch annel names are MYDATA and MYFILE, respectively. Both files are open for writing.  
FAME do es not require the channel name to be th e same as the file name. For example , the foll owing 
commands are le gal:

www.fisglobal.com  243  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
CREATE <KIND TEXT> AUDIT.ONE AS A1  
CREATE AUDIT.TWO AS A2 <KIND TEXT>  
To assign a different channel name, u se the form CREATE filespec AS channel -name. In this command 
form, argument -specific o ptions must follow th e channel name rather than the file specification.  
The follo wing command is illegal because we insert the KIND option into the middle of the argument : 
CREATE ILLEGAL.ONE <KIND TEXT> AS ILL    — Illegal syntax  
If you do not exp licitly cr eate a new file as a text file, FAME creates a database. You cannot convert a 
database to a text file. To create a text file instead of a database, you must close the dat abase, unsave it, 
and create the text fi le using the KIND TEXT option.  
In ad dition to the TEXT setting, the  KIND option also takes the DB setting, which is the default . You are 
only required to use the DB setting when you are when mixing different kinds of  files in the same 
CREATE command ; for e xample:  
CREATE <KIND TEXT> ONE, TWO,  THREE, FO UR <KIND DB>, FIVE, & & 
   SIX, SEVEN, EIGHT <KIND DB>  
This command creates six te xt files and two databases.  
Channels  
FAME uses channels to communicate with open files. ( FAM E may also communicate with some devi ces, 
such as printers, via channels. ) For exam ple, you might have e ight databases, three output files, one 
input command file, and one audit file open. FAME uses the channel names that you assign to the 
databases and  files to keep track of its communicatio ns and talk to each database or file . 
Usually,  FAME uses a channel name which is the same as the root name of the open file. Fo r example, if 
you issue the CREATE <KIND TEXT> MYSALES  command, then the root name is MYS ALES, the text 
file extension is TXT, an d FAME assigns the channel name MYSA LES to the  text file. However, FAM E 
gives you the ability to assign a channel name that is completely different from the file name; for example:  
CREATE <KIND TEXT> MYBASE_LOAD_JAN0 9.LOG AS NEWLOG  
This example simplifies the text file name; now you can refe r to the f ile specification nam ed 
MYB ASE_LOAD_JAN09.LOG by its channel name, NEWLOG.  
After you open a text file in FAME, you refer to it by its channel name, not the name used by t he 
computer’s operating system. In the a bove example, you refer to the file as NEWLOG,  not 
MYBASE_LOAD_JAN0 9.LOG. 
FAME allows you to use up to 250 channels at any time . Your operating system may have a stricter limit 
on open files.  
Opening a Text File and Controlling the Access  
You can use the O PEN command to open an existing text  file or t o create a new text f ile. In its simplest 
form, the OPEN command opens a database  for updating:

www.fisglobal.com  244  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
OPEN MYTEXT  
In this example, FAME tries to open a database named MYTEXT.DB  and assign it the channel MYTEXT. 
Even if the file MYTEXT.DB does not exist , FAME doe s not look for a text  file named MYTEXT.TXT. 
Instead, FAME throws an error.  
If you specify OPEN BADSPEC.TXT, FAME tries to open the file BADSPEC.TXT as a database and 
assign it the channel BADSPEC.TXT. In this case, an error results because the f ile is not  a database.  
As with the CREATE command, you must specify the KIND option at the command -specific or argument -
specific level within FAME to open a text file; for example:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT> MYTEXT  
OPEN MYTEXT <KI ND TEXT>  
These alternative forms bot h open the  text file MYFILE.TXT  for reading.  
File Specifications and Channels  
You can use a  more elaborate file specification so that the channel name does not match the file name;  
for example:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT> MYTEXT1 A S A, MYTEXT2 AS B  
This example o pens two existing text files, MYTEXT1.TXT and MYTEXT2.TXT, f or reading. It assigns two 
channels, named A and B, to the text files.  
You can open both text files and databases with a single O PEN command; for example:  
OPEN BASE1 , MYTEXT1 AS A <KIND TEXT>, MYT EXT2 AS B <KIND TEXT>  
For the sake of clarity, you should pr obably open databases and text files with separate commands.  
You can use the OPEN command  to open a text file to store any kind o f FAME output, including reports, 
command resu lts, error messages, warnings, progress messages, audit trails, or the output of the WRITE 
command.  
You can use the OPEN command to open a text file for reading with the READ command (this is seldom 
done). Howe ver, you cannot use the OPEN command  to open a  text file for inputt ing commands and 
options; you must use the INPUT command to open an input file.  
You can always check to see what text files you’ve got open by giving  the TYPE @OPEN.TXT  command . 
 
Text Files w ith Non -FAME Names  
Sometimes yo u need to open a text file with a non -FAME name. This can ha ppen because the operating 
system allows you to give a file a name that is illegal in FAM E, such as a name starting with a number , 
like 3RD_PLAN , or a name that is a  reserved word, such as BLANK . Other times, this can happen 
because you need to open a text  file on someone else’s directory or on a common disk area, and the file 
specification th at you need to use requires illegal char acters such as slashes or brackets.

www.fisglobal.com  245  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
For exampl e, if you are running  the UNIX operating system, you may want to open a text file  called 
SALES.TXT in /home/users/fameuser . The name SALES.TXT is acceptable to FAME, but the file won’t 
be found by OPEN <KIND TE XT> SALES  because FAME will look at your direc tory, not at fameuser . 
Outside FAME, you can refer to the file as /home/users/fam euser/sales.txt . Within FAME, you’ll need to 
follow file specification conventions to ide ntify the file.  
FAME allows you to enclo se any file specification inside dou ble quotes  to inform FAME that the enclosed 
text string may not represent a legal FAME name , but that the string does correctly identify a file . To open 
the text file in the above  example, we specify the follow ing: 
OPEN "/home/users/fameuser/sales.txt" AS SALES <KIND TE XT> 
This OPEN command opens the text file for reading using the channel name SALES. Whene ver you 
enclose the file name in double quotes, FAME requires the AS channel -name  clause to define the 
chan nel name. 
Even when you enclose the file specification in qu otes, you can omit the file extension if it’s TXT. For 
example:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT> "/home/u sers/fameuser/sales" AS SALES  
This comma nd is equivalent to the OPEN command  shown abo ve. 
You can use a str ing literal as a file specification in every command that us es a file specification, including 
the COMPILE, CREATE, EDIT, EXHIBIT, INFO, INPUT, LOAD,  OPEN, OUTPUT, PICTURE, REFILE 
and UNSAV E commands.  
Controlling the Access M ode 
So far , all the examples of  opening text files have opened them for reading, the defaul t access. However, 
you’re more likely to want to add text to an already existing text fil e. In this case, you must use the 
ACCESS  option to specify a different mode of access to the file. There ar e four ACCESS modifiers that 
can be used with text files and  the OPEN command: READ, CREATE, OVERWRITE, and APPEND. (You 
can only use the UPDATE mode  when opening a database.) The ACCESS op tion may be used only at 
the command -specific and argument -specific  levels of option specification.  
The READ Mode  
The default, ACCESS READ, allows you to open  a text file for reading only; for examp le: 
OPEN <KIND TEXT> S_FILE  
OPEN <KI ND TEXT; A CCESS READ> T_FILE AS  TF 
OPEN V_FILE <KIND TEXT>  
OPEN W_FILE AS WF <KIND TEXT; AC CESS READ>  
You cannot add new text to a file opened with this access mode. This is the on ly modifier that allows you 
to read from , rather than write to, a text file.  On most o perating systems, you  cannot open a text file for 
both reading and writing.

www.fisglobal.com  246  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The A PPEND Mode  
If you want to add tex t to an existing text file, such as an audit f ile, you should open it for APPEND 
access; for example:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT; ACCESS A PPEND> AUD  
OPEN AUD2 AS A <KIND TEXT; ACCESS APPEND>  
The first command opens the existing  file AUD.TXT so that new commands and o ptions can be written to 
it. FAME as signs the channel name AUD  to the text file. If AUD.TXT does not exist, ACCESS APPEND 
cause s the OPEN command to create the file. This OPEN command, however, is not sufficient by i tself to 
cause auditing to begin. For au diting to begin, you must direct the  audit cla ss of output to the c hannel 
AUD with the CHANNEL AUDIT option, described in the c hapters, INPUT FILES  (p. 250) and 
CHANNELING AND OUTPUT FILES  (p. 274). 
The second command opens the existing fi le AUD2.TXT and assigns it to the A channel.  
The CREATE Mode  
The ACC ESS CREATE option, when specified wi th an OPEN  command for a KIND T EXT file, functions 
identically to the CREATE command for te xt files. For example, the following two commands are 
equivalent:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT; ACCESS  CREATE> TEXT1  
CREATE <KIND TEXT> TEXT1  
The CREATE command is slightly short er than th e OPEN command with A CCE SS CREATE. Both of the 
above statements create and open t he text file TEXT1.TXT for writing on the channel TEXT1. If the file 
TEXT1.TXT already ex ists, both commands fail.  
The OVERWRITE Mode  
The CREATE command does not give you a provision for autom atically replacing an existing text file with 
a new text file. To do this, you must use t he OPEN command with ACCESS OVERWRITE an d KIND 
TEXT.  
Suppose you produce a f ile contai ning several pages of  statistical output that you need to review daily. 
You do no t want to increase the length of the statistical output file, so ACCESS APPEND is inappro priate. 
You should open the existing fil e with OVERWRITE mode so that you cr eate a new  file every day; for 
example: 
OPEN SCENARIO.TXT AS OUT1 <KIND TEXT; ACCESS OVERWR ITE> 
This example creates a new text file with the name SCENARIO.TXT and assigns it to th e channel OUT1. 
Depending on your operat ing system, the old file may be auto matically deleted upon creation  of the new 
version or a new version of the file may be crea ted. You redirect output to the channel OUT1 with the 
CHANNEL command, documented in the next chapter.

www.fisglobal.com  247  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Limitations  
Once you open a file, you cannot change its acc ess mode. If you open a file with ACCESS READ but 
then reali ze that you must append to it, you must close it with the CLOSE command and reopen it wit h 
the proper access mode.  
The ACCESS opt ion that you specify may not conflic t with any  operating system acc ess codes for the file. 
For example, if the operating system  protects a file so that you can read it but not write to it, you cannot 
use the ACCESS O VERWRITE option in FAME to change the da ta. 
You can always check the access mode for a  text file by using t he ACC ESS function ; for example, 
DISPLAY ACCESS (MYFILE) . The ACCESS function returns one of four access modes: APPEND, 
CREAT E, OVERWRITE, or READ as a string.  
As de scribed in the preceding chapter und er the hea ding Opening Databases from a Pro cedure or Input 
File (p. 228), text files also su pport the FILE function. For example, in  an input file, you must specify 
OPE N <KIND TE XT; ACCESS OVERWRITE>  FILE (filestring) AS channel -name  when a user enters 
the na me of a text file as a string.  
Closing Text Files  
You can close a text file in either of two ways:  
 Issue the EXIT command to leav e the FAME system and return to your  operating  system. FAME 
automat ically closes all open databases and text files.  
 Issue the CLOSE command with a list of text file channel names or the keyword ALL. If you 
specify ALL, FAME closes every channel you’ve ope ned, inclu ding channels assigne d to text files 
and channels assigned to databases. After yo u close a text file, you can exhibit, edit, rename or 
delete it within FAME.  
In the follo wing sequence of commands we show how to  create a new text file, open an exi sting text  file, 
check for open  files, check the access mode for an open file, and close a text file.  
 
* CREATE <KIND TEXT> TEST1.FIL AS T1  
* OPEN <KIND TEXT; ACCESS APPEND> TEST2  
* TYPE @OPEN.TXT  
T1, TEST2  
 
* DISPLAY AC CESS(T1), ACCESS(TEST2)  
 
ACCESS(T1)  
 
CREATE 
 
 
ACCESS(TEST2)  
 
APPEND 
 
 
* CLOSE T1 
* CLOSE TEST2

www.fisglobal.com  248  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Exhibiting Text Files  
Since text  files consist of lines of text, eventually you’ll want to look at a file’s contents. You  can examine 
the contents of a text file  by using the EXHIBIT command and na ming the f ile with the form EXHIBIT 
filespec . 
On some operating systems, you must close a f ile before you can exhibit it. This prohibits you from 
looking at any kind of output file  that is currently in use. You can’t use  a channel name with the EXHIBIT 
command, but must use a complete f ile specification. If the file has a name that is legal in F AME, the 
command can be as simple as the following example:  
* EXHIBIT FAME.INP  
CHANNEL EC HO INFO 
DEVICE TERMINAL VT240, GRAPHIC V T240 
DECIMAL 0  
This is a FAME input file that FAME executes each ti me you enter the system.  
If you omit the file name extension , FAME appends the TXT extension.  
If the file does not reside in your account or has an i llegal FAME name, you can use a detailed  file 
specification enclosed in doub le quotes.  The next example ass umes that you are on a personal computer 
running FAME for Wi ndows: 
* EXHIBIT "C: \FAME\fame.inp"  
 
--FAME.INP input file for FAME  User Guide : 
CHANNEL E CHO INFO 
DEVICE GRAPHIC POSTP  
LENGTH FUL L 
WIDTH 70  
GLUE DOT  
This FAME input file is st ored in the FAME dire ctory on the C drive.  
Renaming Files  
From time to time, you may want to change the name of an existing file. This happens when you want to 
use the na me for another file, or when the file is  no longer current and you want to g ive it a n ame that 
reflects its  status. 
To rename a file within FAME, use the REFILE comman d. On some operating systems, you must first 
close the file if it is open. (Remember, the  RENAME command changes the name of a da ta object in a 
FAME database.)  
Because the file may not be open, you cannot use a channel name in the REFILE process. The proper 
command form is: REFILE oldfile AS newfile , where both oldfile and newfile are complete fi le 
specifications; for example:  
REFILE MYFILE. DAT AS MYFILE.OLD  
REFILE "9NOV09.LOG" AS L9NOV.TXT  
REFILE "C: \ABC\RULES.INF" AS " C:\ABC\SPEC.TXT"

www.fisglobal.com  249  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The first statement shows the simple replacement of one legal FAME file name with another. In the 
second stateme nt, we change an invalid FAME name t o a valid one so that the OPEN command can be 
simplified to OPEN <KIND TEXT> L9NOV . The fin al statement illustrates the renaming of a file on 
another user’s directory; you must hav e operating system permission in order t o do this.  
Unsaving Files  
You can un save any s ystem file with the U NSAVE command, provided that the file has the appropriate 
operating system permission code. On some operating systems, you must first close the file if it is open. 
We do not recommend unsav ing open files, even if the operatin g system p ermits it.  
When you u nsave the file, you should provide its file name extension, since you are not referencing it via 
a channel name; for example:  
UNSAVE TRIAL1.AUD  
If the file has a name that is not a legal FA ME name, you can unsave it by includ ing its ex act specification 
in quotes. If you’re running under the UNIX operating system, y ou would issue the following command:  
UNSAVE "/home/users/jmc/revenue/9nov09.log"  
This co mma nd deletes the file 9NOV09.LOG from t he subdirectory revenue  of user jmc, provided that you 
have operati ng system permission to unsave the file.  
Remember, the UNSAV E command is used to unsave text files and databases, but the DELETE 
command is used to d elete data objects from databases.

www.fisglobal.com  250 INPUT FILES  
The chapter  TEXT FILES  (p. 242) explained how to exhibit, rename, and unsave a text file. In this 
section, we’ll explain how to use a t ext file as an input file. This chapter covers the following topics:  
 The def inition an d purposes of an inpu t file. 
 The INPUT command for using input files, as well as how to display an input file as you execute 
it, and how to handle errors that an input fi le may generate.  
 How to use an automatic  FAME start -up file.  
 How to generate  and use a n audit file.  
 How to prompt a user for information to be used in an input file.  
 How to nest input files inside each other.  
 How to open a database or a text file within an  input file.  
The next chapter discusses procedures, a more sophisticated sys tem-buildi ng tool. The final ch apter 
discusses output from FAME.  
What Is an Input File?  
An input file is a text file holding commands, options, and responses that you want to use i n a FAME 
session. There are two types of  text files that store commands and options:  
 The first type of text  file contains a list of commands, options, and responses ex actly as you 
would interactively issue them in FAME. This is called an input file.  
 The se cond type of text file contains FAME com mands and options that have been com piled. 
This is called a procedu re. 
We’ll discuss input files in this chapter. We discuss pr ocedures in the chapter  PROCEDURES  (p. 265). 
Both input f iles and procedures are covered in m ore detail  in the FAME S YSTEM  BUILDING USER GUIDE. 
FAME input files have several uses:  
 Typically, you develop an input file to handle a set of commands and options that you regular ly 
enter and only occasionally change.  
 You can create an input file for a ne w analysis  or a new graph that you’re developing. When you 
use an input file, it’s easy to make revisions and you can avoid redoing previous work because of 
a mistake.  
 You can deve lop an input file as a time -saving devic e. While your FAME session runs itse lf, you 
can attend to other res ponsibilities.

www.fisglobal.com  251  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Controlling Input  
Although input files are te xt files, they are not opened in the same way as other text files. Input files must 
be op ened and executed with the INPUT command . The command uses the form INPUT fi le-
specifi cation  and performs t he following operations:  
 The INPUT command opens a text file  and sets the KIND and ACCESS options. You cannot use 
the KIND option with the INPUT comm and since the INPUT command only uses te xt files. 
Similarly, you cannot use the ACCESS  option with the INPU T comm and since the INPUT 
command only needs ACCESS READ for  the file.  
 The INPUT command automatically assigns the FAME -defined channel INPUT to the file that you 
specify. (We’ll discuss ch anneling in the chapter  CHANNELING AND OUTPUT FILES  (p. 274)) 
FAME allows you to supply a complex file specification, enclosed in quotes, so tha t you can use a 
file with a non -FAME nam e as an input file; for example:  
 INPUT "C:\FAMETXT\EXAMPLE.TXT"  
Note that unlike the OPEN command, no AS clause can appear wit h the INPUT command. For 
example, the following command is illegal:  
 INPUT BADFILE.TXT AS  BAD    — Illegal AS clause  
 The INPUT co mmand causes FAME to begin accepting  input fro m the text file. The file runs until 
it is completed or it is aborted by an error . 
The following FAME session displays an input file and then uses the input file to produ ce a simple report:  
* EXHIBIT EXAMPLE.IN P 
 
-- This file prints the quarterly  sales rep ort for the last 4  
-- complete quarters  
 
BLOCK 
  TRY -- Open BASICS20 if it isn' t already open, trap the error  
-- if it is  
    OPEN <ACCESS READ> BASICS20  
  END TRY 
  FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
  DATE THISDAY( QUA) - 4 TO THISDAY( QUA) - 1 
  TITLE #1 TEXT "Quar terly Sales Report"  
  DECIMAL 0 
  LPREFIX "$"  
  REPORT SALES, EXPENSES, &&  
    PERCENTAGES <LPREFIX ""; DECIMAL 1; SUFFIX "%">  
  CLOSE BASICS20  
END BLOCK  
 
* TYPE THISDAY( Q) 
09:1 
 
* INPUT EXAMPLE  
 
                   Quarterly Sales Report  
 
                                09:1    09:2    09:3    09:4  
                              ------  ------  ------  ------

FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Total Sales                   $24000  $25000  $26000  $28000  
Total Expenses                $21700  $26700   $22500  $24800  
Percentage: Expense s / Sales   90.4%  106.8%   86. 5%   88.6% 
 
 This example demonstrates the following points:  
 EXAMPLE.INP is a standard input file. You display the contents of a text file with the E XHIBIT 
command. You must supply the INP extension with the EXHIBIT command.  
 You do not  have to provide the extension for the file specification with the INPUT command;  
FAME appends the INP extension if you do not specify one. If the file specification does  not use 
the INP extension, you should i nclude the extension in your command ; for exam ple, you must 
specify  INPU SALES.REP . 
 The INPUT command opens the file SALES.INP and assigns it to the FAME -defined channel 
called INPUT. Then, FAME executes the commands  and options stored in the file. Finally , FAME 
closes the file and returns c ontrol to the user.  
 All of the commands and options in the input file appear between a BLOC K and END BLOCK 
command pair. Therefore, any options set inside the block return to their  original settings when 
the block ends. This helps avoid surprises later in your FAME session, such as an u nexpected 
title on your next report, or too few decimal plac es with your DISPLAY commands. Note the use 
of the double hyphen ( --) to set off comments . The structured TRY command is used to isolate a 
command that might fail, s o that its  failure won’t cause the input file to stop executing. The 
THISDAY function is us ed to calculate the range for the report dynamically, using date arithmetic.  
Echoing Stat ements from an Input File  
In the last ex ample, FAME did not display the comm ands or op tions from the input file as it executed 
them. In many cases, however, you want t he statements to appear in your FAME session so that you’ll 
know where you are in your se ssion. You can use a special class of ou tput, called ECHO , to print the 
lines of an in put file in your FAME  session as FAME reads them. Echoing does not affect command s that 
you enter interactively.  
To make input file statements echo in your FAME session, enter the following statement:  
CHANNEL E CHO DIALOG  
This option directs the E CHO output  to your FAME session . You can make CHANNEL ECHO DIALOG  
the first line of your in put file so that the contents of the file echo in your FAME session.  
To turn off the echo ing of input file statements in your FAM E session, enter the following state ment:  
CHANNEL ECHO NONE  
Handlin g Errors 
When an input file encounters an error, FAME prints  an error message and terminates execution of the 
file. If you want to ignore the error a nd try to execute additional statements in the input file, then you 
should s pecify the  following option:  
ABORT OFF

When you specify ABORT OFF , FAME discards any errone ous statement it encounters in an input file 
and moves to the next statement.  
The ABORT o ption can be handy when you’re using an input file to e xamine a n umber of data objects  
from a database, but you’re not sure that you remember all the names correctly, as in the following 
example:  
* EXHIBIT ABORT_TEST.INP  
BLOCK 
CHANNEL ECHO DIALOG  
OPEN BASICS20  
-- When you se t ABORT OFF, the entire file does no t fail 
-- when FAME encounters an error. 
ABORT OFF  
WHATS SALES, PROFITS, EXPENSES  
WHATS SAL ES 
WHATS PROFITS  
WHATS EXPENSES  
-- When the default, ABORT ON, is in effect, an error cau ses 
-- execution of the input file to te rminate and control to return  
-- to the termi nal. 
ABORT ON  
WHATS SALES, PROFITS, EXPENSES  
WHATS SALES  
WHATS PROFITS  
WHATS EXPE NSES 
CLOSE BASICS20  
END BLOCK

You should note a few points about  this example:  
 The option CHANNEL EC HO DIALOG  does not appear in th e FAME  session, but every 
subsequent command and option from  the input file does appear.  
 The user enters just two commands: EXHIBIT and INPUT. The ec ho from the input file produces 
the othe r lines that look like commands.  
 When FAME can not find an item name d PROF ITS for the WHATS command, the entire 
command fails. B ecause of this type of error, you can understand, for example, the advantage of 
giving th ree separate WHATS commands rather than one WHATS command with three series.  
With the default setting, ABOR T ON, an error terminates the execution of an input file and  returns control 
to the interactive user (or the level at which the INPUT command is prot ected by a TRY command).  
In production  applications, most u sers prefer to have ABORT ON , so that an error causes an inp ut file to 
stop working. For this reason, you usually set the ABORT OFF  option inside a B LOCK and END BLOCK 
command pair.  
The TRY  Command  
Another way to deal with er rors in an  input file is to enc lose commands that might cause an error inside a 
structured TRY command. The TRY command has the form:  
TRY 
   sequence of statements  
OTHERWISE  
   alternative sequence of statements  
END TRY 
You can omit the OTHERWISE  if you om it the alternative sequence of statements. FAME executes 
commands and options in the initia l sequence of statements  until it encounters an error. Then, it executes 
the alternative sequence of statements . The TRY command is probably most frequently used to make

sure a needed database is open. If you try to open a database that’s already open, an error results. But, if 
you enclose the OPEN command in a TRY block, you can be sure it’s open without risking an error:  
TRY 
   OPEN MYBASE  
END TRY 
The TRY command is  described  in more detail in bo th the COMMAND  REFERENCE  and the FAME SYSTEM  
BUILDING  USER GUIDE. 
Using Automatic Start -up Files  
In the chapter  TEXT FILES  (p. 242), we made passing ref erence to the use of a file called fame.inp . 
This special in put file automatically executes as soon as you enter the FAME environment. fame.inp  is 
called the automatic start -up file.  
If the re are options that you always want to use, yo u should store them o n your directory in the file named 
fame.inp . Many users set the DEVICE, DECIMAL, and LENGTH options in their automatic start -up files. 
For example, t he following fame.inp  automatic start -up file includes a number of popular o ption sett ings: 
*  EXHIBIT FAME .INP 
CHANNEL ECHO DIALOG  
DECIMAL 3  
DEVICE GRAPHIC POSTP, TER MINAL VT240  
LENGTH FULL  
PAUSE OFF  
You might also use an input file to open databases and load procedures that you routinely use.  
System managers can create a system -wide fame.inp automatic start -up file so that all users on a 
system begin with the same def aults. A system -wide start -up file is a handy tool for companies or systems 
that use spec ial FAME settings for all applications.  
Using Audit Files  
Audit files give you a convenient way to create an input file or to keep a record of a FAME session. After 
you start auditing a se ssion, every statement that you type in your FAME session and every line fro m 
every in put file that you use  appears in the audit file.  
Audit files are particularly hel pful as you work on a graph, since the process usually involves several 
iterations: you s et some options and draw a graph; then y ou examine the result, change a few options, 
and try again; then yo u change the titles and add some footings and draw it again;  and so on, until you 
have the exact graph that you want.  
If you save all of your com mands in an audit file, you can turn  it into a n input file. Use an operating 
system editor such as Notepad to make the appropri ate changes to the audit file.  
You must perform two steps to cre ate an audit file: create a text fil e, and ass ign the AUDIT class o f output 
to it. To create and start using an audit file call ed SALES.TXT, you enter the following statements:  
OPEN <KIND TEXT; ACCESS APPEND> SALES

ACCESS AP PEND is a safe access specification, since it creates the file if it doesn’t already exis t, and 
appends text to the end of the fi le if it does exist.  
When you want to stop aud iting your session, enter the following statement:  
CHANNEL AUDIT NONE

Controlling Response s from the FAME session  
When you are running an input file, you may want the file to paus e and accept input from the user. For 
example, you may want to prompt the us er to ente r a data value or to specify the name of a database.  
Specifying the Location of t he Response  
By default, when you are using an input file, FAME expects all input to come from the input file. To 
override this ex pectation, specify RESPONSE KEYBOARD  in your i nput file. With this option setting, 
FAME directs commands that prompt for input to accept responses from the FAME session.  
To turn off prompting, type RESPONSE INPUT . The RESPONSE option affects the EDIT and U PDATE 
commands, which you already kn ow about, and the PROMPT and AC CEPT commands, which we’ll 
describe below.  
When the default RESPONSE INPUT  option setting is in effect, all prompts must be answered within the 
input  file; for example:  
* EXHIBIT RESPONSE.O NE 
FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
DATE 08:1 TO 09:4 
SERIES RESP.A 
UPDATE RESP. A 
1, 2, 3, 4 
5, 6 
7 
SAVE

RESP.A

08:2     2.00  
08:3     3.00  
08:4     4.00  
09:1     5.00  
09:2     6.00 
09:3     7.00

When RESPONSE KEYBOARD  is in effect, FAME  accepts c ommand responses from  the FAME session. 
When the user completes his or her respon se, FAME returns control to the input file until it encounters the 
next prompting command . 
The following example illustrates the use of the RESPONSE option to direct  FAME to t ake responses 
from th e FAME  session when it encounters the UPDATE command:  
* EXHIBIT RESPONSE.TWO  
RESPONSE KEYBOARD  
FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
DATE 08:1 TO 09:4  
SERIES RESP.B

RESP.B    
 
08:1 > 20, 40, 60 
08:4 > 80, 100, 120  
09:3 > S AVE 
 
RESP.B

08:2      40.00  
08:3      60.00

In addi tion to the EDIT and UPDATE commands, th e RESPONSE KEYBOARD  setting accepts keyboard 
entry from the PROMPT and ACCEPT commands, which are described next.  
Prompting Use rs for a String  
The PROMPT command prints a prompting message and then reads the next lin e from the INPUT 
channel into an existin g string variable. The command requi res the PR OMPT command name, fo llowed 
by a string, a colon, and a string variable: PROMPT m essage -string:stringvar . The message -string 
prompt  is a string that appears in the FAME s ession and can be as simple as the messa ge enclosed in 
quotes. Stringvar  is the string  variable that you us e in the input file; for example:  
SCALAR INIT:STRING  
PROMPT "Please enter your initials -- ":  INIT  
Because FAME takes its response from the INPUT cha nnel, you must specify RESPONSE KEYBOARD  
before the PROMPT command if you wa nt the use r to enter a response  to a prompt. Otherwise, FAME 
does not print the prompting m essage and takes the next line of the input file as the response.  
The following example s hows how you can use the PROMPT command to prompt a user for file names:  
* EXHIBIT PRO MPT.INP 
RESPONSE KEYB OARD 
SCALAR DB, NEWDB:STRING  
PROMPT "Enter the name of the e xisting database:  ": DB  
PROMPT "Enter the name of a new database:  ": NEWDB  
TRY 
  OPEN <ACCESS READ> FILE(DB) AS ORIGINAL  
END TRY 
CREATE FILE(NEWDB) AS NEWBASE  
RESPONSE INPUT  
TYPE DB + " open for  reading as ORIGINAL"  
TYPE NEWDB + " open for writing as NEW BASE"
