FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
* INPUT PROMPT  
Enter the name of the existing database:  BASICS20  
Enter the name o f a new database:  NEWBASE  
BASICS20 open  for reading as ORIGINAL  
NEWBASE ope n for writ ing as NEWDB  
 
We’ll d escribe the FILE function, which we use in this input file, at the end of this chapter.  
Another useful way to prompt a user for information is the AC CEPT command.  
Prompting Users for One or  More Values  
Like the PROMPT command , the ACCE PT command  prints a message and then reads the next line f rom 
the INPUT channel. Unlike the PROMPT command, the ACCEPT command takes data types oth er than 
strings and the command can acce pt values for more than one variable . 
The comm and form for the ACCE PT command is similar to the form for the PROMPT command. En ter 
the command name, followed by a string expression, a colon, and a list of variables: ACC EPT message -
string: var1, var2, ..., varn . The message -string  prompt can be as simp le as a message enclo sed in 
quotes. Var1  through Varn  represent numeric, precisio n, date, string, or boolean variables.  
Again, you must specify RESPONSE KEYBOARD before t he ACCEPT command if you want a user to 
enter a response in the FAME session . If you d on’t specify RESPONSE  KEYBO ARD, FAME does not 
print the prompt and uses the next line of the input file as the response.  
The following example shows how you can use the A CCE PT command to prompt for the informat ion 
needed to set a date range:  
* EXHIBIT ACCE PT.INP 
FREQUENCY BUSI NESS 
SCALAR ENDDATE:  DATE  
SCALAR SPAN  
RESPONSE KEYBOARD  
ACCEPT "Enter the end date (ddmmmyy) and the span:  ": ENDDATE, &&  
  SPAN 
RESPONSE INPUT  
DATE ENDDATE - SPAN TO ENDDATE  
TYPE @DATE  
 
* INPUT ACCEPT  
Enter the end date ( ddmmmyy) a nd the span:  4JUL09,  15 
 
Error: 4JUL09 is not a date at BUSINESS frequency  
Enter the end date (ddmmmyy) and the span:  3JUL09, 15  
12JUN09 TO 3JUL09  
Note how FAME re -prom pted when an invalid date was entered. F AME will automatically re -prompt if an 
incorre ct data type or too f ew responses are supplied.

www.fisglobal.com  263  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Nesting Input Files  
You can nest input files (that is, use the INPUT command in an input file), but it is not recommended.  This 
is because the INPUT command does not initiate the execution of an inp ut file, b ut merely establishes  it 
as the source for future input from FAME. If your input file uses INPUT commands together with 
structured commands such as IF and LOOP, FAME may not produce the results that you expect.  Instead 
of using the INPUT command inside an input file, use a pro cedure. Furthermore, don’t use an input file 
from inside a p rocedure; call another procedure instead. Procedures are described briefly in the next 
chapter and in considerable detail in the FAME SYSTEM  BUILDING  USER GUIDE. 
Opening Datab ases and Files from a n Input File 
Eventually, you may want to design an input fil e that allows the user to enter the name of a database or 
another file for opening. For e xample, you may have multiple users on a  single account and want each 
user t o tag his or her databases with  his or her own initials.  
In these cases, you use the FILE f unction with the COMPILE, CREATE, EDIT, EXHIBIT, INFO, INPUT, 
LOAD, OPEN, OUTPUT, PICTURE , REFILE, or UNSAVE command to allow a u ser to enter a file 
specification in  response to a prompt. Instead of the usual file specification, you use the form FILE(strin g-
expression) , where string -expression  provides the file name for a database or other fil e. 
When you use the FILE function with the OPEN o r CREATE command, you  must use the AS channel 
form of the command and explicitly name the channel yourself. For example, the following command 
sequences are legal:  
SCALAR DB:STRING = "BASE1"  
OPEN FILE(DB) AS HI ST 
SCAL RP:STRING = "MONTHLY.REP"  
CREATE <KIND  TEXT; ACCESS OVERWRI TE> FILE(RP) AS RPT  
The first set of commands opens the data base BASE1.DB and assigns it to the channel HIST. The 
second set of commands opens the te xt file MONTHLY.REP and assigns it the c hannel name RPT.  
The following seque nce of com mands is illegal beca use the OPEN command omits the AS channel -name  
clause:  
SCALAR DBASE:STRING = "B_BASE1"  
OPEN FILE(DBASE)    — Illegal without AS clause  
The string exp ression that follows the FILE function m ay not incorporate the AS channel cl ause , but it can 
use string con catenation to form the file name, as shown below:  
SCALAR ROO T:STRING = "BASE1"  
SCALAR EXT:STRING = "DB"  
OPEN FILE(ROOT + "." + EXT) AS FIRSTBASE  
Beca use the OUTPUT, INFO, INPUT, EXHIBIT, an d UNSAVE commands do not need to cre ate channe l 
names from the file  specification, they do not require you to append the AS cha nnel clause. For example, 
the following sequence of commands is legal:  
SCALAR EX:STRING =  "C:\USERS\DEFAULT\PMS\BOOK2\SALEPLAN.IN P" 
EXHIBIT FILE(EX)

www.fisglobal.com  265 PROCEDURES  
You can creat e your own commands u sing FAME procedures. Procedures are similar to input files,  which 
were discussed in the last chapter, but offer additional capabilities. This chapte r explains:  
 What procedures are.  
 The adv antages of procedures over input fil es. 
 How to  create and use proce dures and procedure files.  
 The TRACE option for debugging pr ocedures.  
 How to use procedures efficiently.  
For more detailed information on procedures and system building, refer to the FAME SYSTEM  BUILDING  
USER GUIDE. 
What Is a  Procedure ? 
A procedure is a us er-defined command; it is a named sequence of FAME statement s that can be 
compiled, loaded into the FAME environment, and then invoked as a command. There are a number of 
advantages to usin g procedures, over and above the adv antages of fered by input files:  
 Procedures extend the FAME language. They enable you to cus tomize FAME to your exact 
specifications.  
 You can pass arguments to a procedure.  
 Temporar y data objects can be created within pro cedures without regard to the existe nce of 
identically -named data o bjects in any open databases, including WORK.  
 Syntax errors are discovered during compilation of the procedure; hence, a compiled procedure is 
syntac tically correct.  
 Compiled procedures can  execute significantly faster than c omparable input files.  
 Procedur es are independent of databases, so you can compile a proced ure even before you 
have created the data objects that it will use.  
Procedures and input files are also conceptually different. A n input file is little more than a c onvenient way 
to enter a bunch of commands and options without doing a lot of typing. A pro cedure, on the other hand, 
is really the equivalent of a single command: it is a user -created command.

www.fisglobal.com  266  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The Steps in Using a Proce dure  
The steps you go through to use  a procedu re vary depending on whether you are creating it for the first 
time (or for the f irst time after it has been changed) or whether you are simply using an existing 
procedur e.  
When you create a procedure or modif y an existing procedure, you take th e followin g steps:  
 First, creat e a text file that contains the source code for one or more procedures.  
 Second, start a FAME session and compile the source file.  
 Third, load the com piled procedure file so that you can use  its procedures.  
 Fourth, use the pro cedures.  
 Fifth (and optionally) , unload procedures when you are finished using them.  
We pre sent an overview of the process of creating and using a procedure below. For more detail,  consult 
the FAME SYSTEM  BUILDING  USER GUIDE 
Create a Procedure Source File  
Begin by c reating a procedure s ource file or by modifying an existing source file. The sour ce file is a text 
file, similar to an input file, that includes one or more structured PR OCE DURE commands that define 
procedures.  (The file may also include FORM, FU NCTION, an d MENU structured com mands.) The file 
name should have the extension PRO . You may  use an operating system editor to build the file. For 
example, the following text file, EXAMPLE.PRO, contains two procedures, ca lled QSALES and TWO:  
* EXHIBIT EXAMP LE.PRO 
PROCEDURE qsales  
-- This file prints the quarterly sales report for the last 4 compl ete quarters  
BLOCK 
  TRY 
    OPEN <ACCESS READ> BASICS20  
  END TRY 
  FREQUENCY QUARTERLY  
  DATE THISDAY( QUA) - 4 TO THISDAY( QUA ) - 1 
  TITLE #1 TEXT "Quarterly Sal es Report"  
  DECIMAL 0  
  LPREFIX "$" 
  REPORT sales, expenses, percentages <LPREFIX ""; DEC IMAL 1; &&  
    SUFFIX "%">  
  CLOSE BASICS20  
END BLOCK  
END PROCEDURE -- qsales 
 
--------- ---------------------------------------- ------------------  
 
PROC two  
TYPE "This is the  second procedure"  
END PROC -- two 
You may recognize the procedure QSALES as the input file, EXAMPLE.INP, from the previous chapter 
(look under the heading Controlling Input , p. 251), with a PROC EDURE command inserted at the 
beginning and an END PRO C added to the end.

www.fisglobal.com  267  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Compile the Procedure File  
You must enter the FAME environment and co mpile the procedure source file with the  COMPILE 
command. If the source file  has the e xtension PRO, you nee d only specify the file name, without 
extension, in order to  compile. The compiled procedure is stored in a file with the same name as the 
source cod e and with the extension PC. To compile the two procedures in EXAMPLE.PRO as  
EXAMPLE.P C, we type:  
* COMPILE  EXAMPLE 
 
Procedure source file is: /home/users/tkb/basics2/ example.pro  
 
Procedure QSALES  
 
Errors: 0  
Warnings: 0  
Procedure calls:      None  
 
Procedur e TWO 
 
Errors: 0  
Warnings: 0  
Procedure c alls:      None  
 
Total of 0 Errors a nd 0 Warni ngs 
 
Procedure code f ile is: /home/users/tkb/basics2/example.pc  
 
At this point, t he steps are the same, regardless of whether you are using a procedure for the first time  or 
the thousandth time. Once a procedur e source file has been created and c ompiled, y ou never need to 
recompile unless you have changed the source code, or you are go ing to use the procedure with a new 
release of FAME. Now you must load the procedure file . 
Load the Procedure File  
Before you can  use your compiled procedures, you m ust load t hem with the LOAD com mand. If the 
compiled procedure file has the extension PC (w hich it will, unless you have deliberately renamed it), then 
you issue the LOAD command u sing only the file name, without extensi on. To load the three procedures 
in EXAMPLE.PC , we type:  
* LOAD EXA MPLE 
 
The @PROCEDURE System Variable  
If you need to know the  names of the procedures that you have loaded during your FAME session, use 
the @PROCEDUR E system variable . For example:  
* TYPE @P ROCEDURE  
QSALES, TWO

www.fisglobal.com  268  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
Call the P rocedure by Name  
To use a proced ure once it has been loaded, you invoke it by name, with any required arguments (and 
any local option settings you might choose).  “Calling by name” means that the pr ocedure na me is the first 
word of the command that invokes it; you do not use any “calling”  words like “DO,” “RUN,” or “USE.” For 
example, to use the procedures QSALES and TWO from  EXAMPLE.PC, now that they have been 
loaded, we type QSALES, then TWO:  
* QSALES 
 
                   Quarterly Sales Report  
 
 
                                89:2    89 :3    89:4    90:1  
                              ------  ------  ------  ------ 
Total Sal es                   $25000  $26000  $28 000  $31000  
Total Expenses                $26700  $22500  $24800  $ 27300 
Percentage: Expenses / Sales  106.8%   86.5%   88.6%   88.1% 
 
 
* TWO 
This is the second procedure  
Unload the Procedure  
If you have finished usi ng a procedure, you may unload it with t he UNLOAD command. You unload 
indivi dual proce dures by name, just a s you call them, not by the names of the files that they wer e loaded 
from. For example, to unload the procedure QSALES from EXAMPLE.PC, we type:  
* UNLOAD QSALES  
The PROCEDURE Command  
A proc edure is a special kind of structure d command.  It is special becaus e the PROCEDURE command, 
itself, may only appear in a file; it may never be issued interactively. The first line in a procedure is always 
the command  PROCEDURE followed by the name of the p rocedure.  
The name of a procedure mu st be a le gal FAME name (see th e rules for naming data objects in the 
chapter  DATA AND  WILDCARDING  (p. 45)). In addition, it may not be either the n ame, an abbreviation of 
the name, or  an extens ion of the name of a FAM E command or option (a violation of this rule is trapped 
when you attempt to compile the procedure). The name is used to invoke the procedure afte r it has been 
compiled and loaded.  
The l ast line of a procedure is always END PROCEDUR E or just END . 
There are three special commands which cannot be used interactivel y, but which can be used inside a 
procedure; they are ARGUMENT, LOCAL, and RETURN. One op tion, TRACE, may be used only with 
proce dures and user -defined functions, an d can appe ar either inside or o utside a procedure.  
 If you want to be able to pass arguments to a procedure, the second line  of the procedure source 
code must be an  ARGUMENT command. A procedure can h ave only o ne ARGUMENT 
command.

www.fisglobal.com  269  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 If you want data objects to be created, temporarily, within a procedure, you can use the LOCAL 
command to create scalars, series, and formulas.  
 The R ETURN command may be included in a proce dure to terminate its execution; oft en, 
RETURN  is used within an IF  or TRY command in the procedure.  
 The TRACE option may be us ed inside a procedure so that you can trace a portion of the 
execution of the procedure.  
Procedures may also include any other FA ME options or commands, including pr ocedure ca lls, with the 
excepti on of the CANCEL, CATCH, FUNCTION, HELP, PROCEDURE, REDO, an d SUBSTITUTE 
commands (there are three other commands, EDIT, UNLOAD, and ?, that you can use inside a 
procedure, but that you sho uld probably not use).  
Hint It is in advisable to use the INPUT comm and inside a procedure, because the results will 
probably not be what you expect. When the INPUT command is used inside a procedure, the 
INPUT channe l is reassigned, but FAME will not accep t input from the channel until it 
encounters a  command, such as ACC EPT, UPDATE, READ, or EDIT, that takes input from 
the INPUT channel, or until the procedure is completed (see the S YSTEM  BUILDING  USER 
GUIDE ). If you  want to execute commands from another f ile while you are inside a procedure , 
you must  make the other file a procedure, too.  
The Form of the PROCEDURE Command  
The basi c form of the procedure command is  
PROCEDURE procedure_name  
ARGUMENT argument_list  
sequence of commands and options  
     . 
     . 
     . 
END PROCEDURE  
where the ARG UMENT comm and is optional. The procedure shown below illustrates the basic form of a 
proced ure and also shows the use of the three special procedure commands. Its purpose is to all ow a 
user to easily produce graphs of a time series using different power tr ansformati ons of the data.  
* EXHI PICK.PRO 
PROC $pick_transform  
ARGUMENT dat  
LOCAL SCALAR p ower -- procedure $pick_transform  
LOCAL SCALAR done:BOOLEAN  
 
LOOP 
   ACCEPT "Enter desire d power:  ":  power  
   IF power EQ 0  
      GRAPH LOG( dat)  
   ELSE IF power LT 0 
      GRAPH -(dat**power)  
   ELSE IF power GT 0  
      GRAPH dat**power  
   ELSE 
      SIGNAL CONTINUE:  "Invalid power"  
   END IF

www.fisglobal.com  270  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
   ACCEPT "Are you finished?  ":  done  
 
   IF done 
      RETURN 
   END IF 
 
END LOOP  
 
END PROC -- $pick_transform  
Note tha t ARGUMENT  is the second line o f the procedure; this is the only place that this command ma y 
appear (of course, comment lines and blank lines may intervene between the PROCEDURE co mma nd 
and the ARGUMENT command, but no c ommands or options may). Note also t he use of the dollar sign in 
the procedure name; this helps avoid naming conflicts with oth er FAME command and option names, 
since the character $ never appears in any FAME -defined  command or option name. If you make $ t he 
first character of your procedure  names, th ere will be no confli cts between the abbreviations of FAME 
commands and options a nd the abbreviations of your procedure calls.  
The comment following  the first LOCAL SCALAR command has been inclu ded to make it easier  to follow 
the execution of the procedure when TRACE ON  is in effect (see Hints for the Efficient U se of 
Procedures , p. 272). 
Hint More advice about nami ng procedu res: it is inadvisabl e to give similar names to procedures 
that will be loaded an d used together. If names are too similar, you won’t be able to make 
much use of abbrevia tions. So, you should try to avoid situa tions where, for example, 
procedures  named $CL EAN, $CLEANUP, and $C LEAR are loaded at the same time. The only 
one of these thre e procedures that could be abbreviated is $CLEANUP, and its shortest 
abbreviation is $CLE ANU . 
The Form of a Procedure File  
A proc edure file may include one or more p rocedures,  as we illustrated wi th EXAMPLE.PRO. Apart from 
the procedures, the file may cont ain only blank lines or comment lines (two hyphens “ --” begin a 
comment); that is, no FAM E commands or options may appear in a pr ocedure file outside the context of a 
procedur e. The following rudi mentary example is illegal:  
* EXHI BADPROC.PRO  
TYPE "Here co mes procedure $a"  
PROC $a 
TYPE "This is procedure $a"  
END PROC  
TYPE "Here comes procedure  $b" 
PROC $b 
TYPE "This is procedure $b"  
END PROC  
When we try to compile thi s file, an  error occurs:  
* COMPILE BADPROC 
Procedure source file is: /home/users/tkb/basics 2/badproc.pro  
 
1: TYPE "Here comes procedure $a"  
Error: Missing keyword 'PROCEDURE' or 'F UNCTION' or 'FORM' or  
'MENU' 
 
Warning: Compilation terminated due to severe  errors.

www.fisglobal.com  271  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 
Total of 1 Error and 1 Warning 
 
 
Error: 1 syntax error in /home/users/tkb/basics2 /badproc.pro.   
Procedure code file not created  
 
The next example shows a legal  version o f the preceding procedure file, with app ropriate comment lines:  
 
* EXHI GOOD PROC.PRO  
 
-- The next procedure  is procedure $a"  
PROC $a 
TYPE "This is procedure $a"  
END PROC -- $a 
 
-- The next procedure is procedure $b"  
PROC $b 
TYPE "This is procedure $b"  
END PROC -- $b 
 
-- There aren't any more pro cedures in this file  
 
This procedure  file will  compile and load, an d the procedures will run.  
The TRACE Option  
The TRACE option  is useful when you are debugging a procedure. When TRACE ON  is in effect, each 
statement  in the procedure is displayed as it is executed, so you can see exactly whe re an erro r arises. 
TRACE OFF , the default, does not echo commands, although it does echo t he line that produces an 
error.  
TRACE may be set outside a procedure so that the whole pr ocedure is traced, or it may be set insi de the 
procedure so that only a segm ent is tra ced. Typically, you w ill not want to set TRACE inside any but the 
longest procedu res, since you will want to remove it before the final compilation. If you specify TRACE 
without a setting, ON is assumed.  
The ex ample below illustrates the use of T RACE with the procedure $PICK_T RAN SFORM, shown earlier 
in the heading The Form of the PROCEDURE Command  (p. 269). 
 
* LOAD PICK  
* $PICK HOUSE1  
Enter desired power:  2  
 
14:       G RAPH dat**power  
 
Error: No graphic device specified  
 
* TRACE ON  
* $PICK HOUSE1  
3: LOCAL SCALAR power -- procedure $pick_transform

www.fisglobal.com  272  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
4: LOCAL SCALAR done:BOOLEAN  
6: LOOP 
7:    ACCEPT "Enter desired power:  ":  pow er 
Enter desired power:  2  
9:    IF power EQ 0  
11:    ELSE IF power  LT 0 
13:    ELSE IF power GT 0  
14:       GRAPH dat**power  
 
Error: No graphic device specified  
 
Note that when TRACE OFF  was in effect, only the line  that caused the error was echoed, but w hen 
TRACE ON  was in effect, every st ep of the way to the error was displayed. The numbers are the line 
numbers of the procedure  file. This information can be very handy if you’re using the FAME editor to fix 
your pro cedure file. TRACE counts blank lines an d comment lines, but does not print them.  
Hints for the Efficient U se of Procedures  
There are a number of things that you can d o to use your procedures more efficiently and effectively.  
 Once you have debugged a group  of related procedures, you should incor porate them all in a 
single procedur e file. Th is economizes on the use of communication channels and makes it 
easier to ensure that you load all of the procedures that you need to perform a particular task.  
 When you bundle many procedures into a single fil e, use a delimiter to separate the p rocedures.  
For example, a line of hyphens separates procedures very neatly and is handled a s a comment 
line by FAME because it begins with two hyphens.  
 Your procedure files are a l ittle neater to work with if you include  the procedure name as a 
comment in the END PR OCEDURE name. For exa mple: 
   END PROCEDURE -- $REPSPREAD  
 It is a good idea to in clude the procedure name as a comment in the first executable line of a 
procedure, perhap s as part of a LOCAL command. For exampl e: 
   LOCAL SCALAR dc:STRING -- procedure $cur rtbspread  
This will b e a big help when you specify TRACE ON  for a large system th at has many procedure 
calls. The comment will be printed with the command, so that every time you enter a new 
procedure, you’ll k now which one.  
 Your procedure files are easier  to read and comprehe nd if you give each command and option its 
own line, instead  of separating them by semicolons on the same line. Abundant comments will 
help others fo llow your logic. Blank lines can set off  discrete parts of the code and give  room for 
writing revisions on the printed copy.  
 Use consistent conventions with regard to capitalization to make your source code easier to read. 
For example, you could always cap italize all FAME commands and options, m ake variable names 
lowercase, and ma ke comment s mixed upper an lowe r case. We have followed these 
conventions in this chapter.  
 Do not use the NEW command with OVERWRITE ON when you want to change the values in a 
data object. You should use the SET command instead.

www.fisglobal.com  273  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
 Wherever it makes sense, us e conditio nal expressions inste ad of IF commands, because 
conditional expressions are somew hat more efficient.  
 Use implicit loops and conditional expressions instead of the LOOP an d IF commands.  
 It is usually more econom ical to reevaluate an expression sev eral times , rather than creatin g a 
local variable to store it. However, a local variable is  preferable if the range incorporates a large 
number of observations, or if the expressio n appears repeatedly.  
 When you use a loc al variable, it is better to initial ize it in the LOCAL command, it self, than with a 
later SET command.  
 When you need a tempora ry variable, it is better to create a local variable than to store a data 
object in the W ORK  database, since retrieval is faster because local storage is always sear ched 
befor e WORK or permanent d atabases. 
 Set all options that are critical to the procedure , even if you use the default settings.  
 Use BLOCK and END BLOCK inside your procedures to  limit the scope of the options that you  
set there.  
 Do not set options that are a matt er of personal taste.  Let the user set them outside the 
procedure.

www.fisglobal.com  274 CHANNELING AND OUTPUT FILES  
The chapter  TEXT FILES  (p. 242) explained  how to exhibit, rename, and unsave text files . The chapter  
INPUT FILES  (p. 250) explained how to store commands and options in a file. In this chapter, we explain 
how to use FAME’s ch anneling capabilities and output fil es. Output  files are text files  that you use as a 
destination for FAME’s output. This chapt er covers the following topics:  
 The definition of an output file and the purposes of chan neling and output files.  
 How to use the OUTPUT channel and the OUTPUT comman d. 
 How to use the INFO channel and the INFO command.  
 How to use the MESSAGE channel and the  MESSAGE command.  
 How to use channeling with FAME output.  
A summary at the end of this ch apter lists the commands and options use d to redirect both input and 
output from the F AME system.  
This chap ter describes how to redirect output between text files and FAME’s predefined windows. It does 
not tell you how to create or use your own windows. Th at is discussed in the FAME/WINDOWS  
REFERENCE  GUIDE. If you want to send you r graphs t o a file, see the chapter GRAPH DATA  (p. 172). 
What is an Output File?  
As you use FAME, you’ll fin d instances when it is convenient to rou te analytical results and reports  to an 
output file, rather than ha ve the information appear in your FAME session:  
 If you ex pect lengthy output from a command, you may not want to tie up your FAME session 
while it is  printing.  
 If you work at a CRT, you may  need to generate a hard copy of your analy sis for careful study.  
 You may need to generate copies of a report, or reports, i n specific formats for different analyses.  
In these cases, FAME allows you to direct your ou tput to a text file so that you can disp lay, print, or study 
the output l ater. 
Conc eptually, the process of  directing output from a FAME command to a device, a file , or a window 
entails three steps:  
1. FAME assigns the output from each command to a specific c lass of output.  
2. FAME sends each class of  output to a specific channel.  
3. FAME connect s each channel to a spec ific output device, file, or window.

www.fisglobal.com  275  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
You can visualize th e process as follows:  
                                                  1                                             2                               3 
Output from a  Command     ——>     Class of Outp ut      ——>     Channel     ——>     File  
You cannot affec t step one. However, FAME gives you considerable control over steps two and three. 
The quick est and easiest way to redirect output i s with the OUTPUT, INFO, and MESS AGE comman ds, 
discussed in the fol lowing section. The CHANNEL option, discussed later in th is chapter, gives you finer 
control over the redirection of output.  
Using the OUTPUT, INFO, and MESSAGE Commands  
The easiest way to redirect output is with the OUTPU T, INFO, a nd MESSAGE commands. Wit hout 
learning the details of channeling, you can use thes e commands to send output to text files.  
By default, all textual output is connected to one or another of the FAME -defined channels,  OUTPUT, 
INFO, and MESSAGE. These  channels are initially connected to the FAME session (to the OUTPUT, 
INFO, and MESSAGE win dows, respectively), but can be reassigned to other windows or files via the 
OUTPUT, INFO, a nd MESSAGE commands:  
 Use the OUTPUT comm and to redirect the standard, exp ected, tex tual output of most of F AME ’s 
commands: reports, analytical results, output from the DISPLAY command, output from WHATS, 
and so on.  
 Use the INFO command to redirect status m essages: errors, warnings, and progress messages.  
 Use the MESSAGE command  to send t he text of messages to a  file. 
The OUTPUT Command  
The simplest way to open an out put file is with the OUTPUT command; for example:  
OUTPUT <ACCESS OVERWRITE> ANALYSIS  
This co mma nd creates a text file named ANALYSIS .TXT if the file does not already  exist and connects it 
to the FAME -defined channel named OUTPUT. If ANALYSIS.TXT already ex ists in the current working 
directory, then ANALYSIS.TXT is opened in OVERWRITE mode.  All cl asses of output directed (by the 
CHANNEL  option) to the OUTPUT channel wi ll hencefo rth go to the file ANALY SIS.TXT. If you have 
already assigned another file to the  OUTPUT channel, the OUTPUT command closes the open file.  
In this example, FAME unsaves any existing file named ANALYSIS.TXT and rep laces it with a new file. A 
less risky appr oach is to open the file  with ACCESS APPEND; this access method creates the file if none 
exists, or appends text to the end of the file if it already exists.  
By default, FAM E connects output from the TYPE and WRIT E commands and the REPORTS, RESUL TS, 
and TR ACE classes of output to  the OUTPUT channel. In other words, just about all of FA ME’s textual 
output  —  reports, analytical results, output from the WHATS, CATALOG, and DIS PLAY commands, for 
example  —  is connec ted to the OUTPUT channel and can  be redire cted with the OUTPUT com mand. 
Note  You can reroute output from the REPORTS, RESUL TS, and TRACE classes to a different 
channel with the CHANNEL option (discussed later in thi s chapter). You cannot reroute the

www.fisglobal.com  276  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
outpu t of the TYPE command, which is always  conn ected to the OUTPUT chan nel. You can 
use a channel specification with the WRITE c ommand to redirect its output from the OUTPUT 
channel.  
The OUTPUT command takes a file speci fication as its only argument. The OUTPU T command does not 
take a channel  name. For  example:  
OUTPUT REGTEST  
OUTPUT ANALYSIS.ONE  
OUTPUT "15NOV09.LOG"  
In the first ex ample, we do not specify an extension with the file name, so FAME automatically appends 
the TXT extension. The second example shows the specification of a file name with a roo t name and an 
extension.  The third example creates a file using the non -FAME name  enclosed in quotes.  
Because the OUTPUT command automatically assigns the channel OUTPUT to the text file instead of 
building a file  specification from a channel nam e that you  specify, you cannot use  an AS clause to name 
the channel, as you could with an O PEN or CREATE command. The following example is illegal:  
OUTPUT ANALYSIS.OUT AS OUT    — Illegal AS clause  
Error, wa rning, and  progress messages do no t appear in the output files created in these examples, n or 
do commands appear in the output files. If you want all of the commands and options that you issue 
during  your FAME  session to be stored wi th the results, you can direct audit output to the OUTPUT  
channel with the option CHANNEL AUDIT OUTPUT . If you want status messages in the same file,  type 
CHANNEL ERRORS OUTPUT , WARNINGS OU TPUT , PROGRESS OUTPUT . If you cha nge your m ind 
about auditing and s tatus messages, type CHANNEL AUDIT NONE , ERRORS INFO , WAR NINGS INFO , 
PROGRESS INFO . 
To restore output to your FAME session from an output file, type:  
OUTPUT TERMINAL  
You can abbreviate the command name OUTPUT, but you cann ot abbrevi ate the FAME -defined fil e 
name TERMINAL. For example, OUTP TERM  connects the OUTP UT channel to the text file TERM.TXT.  
If you want the results of commands to go to several d ifferent files, you can precede each act ion 
command with an appropriate O UTPUT comm and; for example:  
OUTPUT <ACCESS OVERWRITE> ANALYSIS.OUT  
    FIT SALES_DIST1 BY S ALES_FORCE1  
OUTPUT <ACCESS OVERWRITE> REPORT.OUT  
    REPORT SALES_DIST1, SALES_FORCE1, SALES _DIST1.FITT  
OUTPUT <ACCESS APPEND> ANALY SIS.OUT 
    FIT SALES_DIST2 BY SA LES_FORCE2  
OUTPUT <ACCESS APPEND> REPORT.OUT 
    REPORT SALES_DIST2, SALES_FORCE2, SALES_DI ST2.FITT 
OUTPUT TERMINAL  
 
Assuming that the default values of the CHANNEL option are in effe ct for this example, FAME prints the 
results of both FIT commands in the file ANALY SIS.OUT. FAME prints the  two reports in the file 
REPORT.OUT. We used ACCESS OVERW RITE the first time that we accessed each file, and we used 
ACCESS APPEND for subsequent acc ess to the files ANALYSIS.OUT and REPORT .OUT. An easier way 
to achieve th is outcome  with the CHANNEL option  is shown later in this chapter under the heading 
Connecting a Channel to a File or Window  (p. 280).

www.fisglobal.com  277  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The INFO Command  
You can use the INFO comma nd to direct progress me ssages, warnings, and errors to a file. Progress 
messages  describe the status of lengthy operations and are generated by the SIGNAL command. 
Warnings  identify minor mistakes that could caus e a command to perform in unexpec ted ways. Warnings 
may be generate d by FAME or by the use of the SIGNAL command. Errors are  generated by FAME, or 
by the SIGNAL command, and explain why a command or option has failed . 
Ordinarily, these messages appear in t he INFO window of your FAME sessi on, but yo u can send them to 
a tex t file with the INFO command. You might want to do this i f an input file or procedure that you’re 
debugging generates many errors, especially if you’ re debugging with ABORT OFF  so that you can catch 
a lot of errors in a si ngle test.  
The INFO command opens a file and assigns it to the FAME -defined channel INFO. A fter you issue the 
INFO command, all output that FAME directs to the channel INFO is printed  to that file. By default, FAME 
connects  the output classes ERRORS, PROGR ESS, and W ARNINGS to the channel I NFO . 
Note  You can reroute output from the ERRORS, WARNING S, and PROGRESS classes to a 
different channel with the CHANNEL option (discussed later in t his chapter).  
The INFO command takes a f ile specification as its only arg ument, as in the following example s: 
INFO STATUS  
INFO FIRST.PAS  
INFO "15NOV.INF"  
The first example creates the file STATUS.TXT (FAME automatically adds the extension TXT) and 
assigns it to the channel INFO. In the second ex ample, we provide a file name ext ension, so  the INFO 
command create s the file FIRST.PAS. The third example creates a file th at has a non -FAME name.  
To reattach the INFO channel from a file to your FAME session, type:  
INFO TERMINAL  
You cannot abbreviate the  command name INFO, nor can you a bbreviate the FAME -defined file na me 
TERMINAL. For example, INFO TERM  connects the INFO cla ss of output to the text file named 
TERM.TXT.  
The MESSAGE Command  
You can use the MESSAGE co mma nd to send the output of the MESSAGE channel to a file. The 
MESSAGE co mmand take s a file specification a s its only argument; for example:  
MESSAGE ASK_ME  
This exa mple creates the text file ASK_ME.TXT. All subsequent output from the MESSAGE channel will 
be sent to ASK_ME.TXT, until you reconnec t the MESSAGE channel to your FAM E session with the 
command:  
MESSAGE TERMINAL 
You can abbreviate MESSAGE, but you can’t abbr eviate the reserved word TERMINAL.

www.fisglobal.com  278  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The ACCESS Option  
By default, FAME uses the ACCESS CREATE mode for the OUTP UT, INFO, and MESSAGE commands . 
This means that if a file with the specified name does not exist, FAME creates the file. However, if a file 
with the specif ied name already exists, the OUTPUT, INF O, or MESSAGE command fails.  
Two other sett ings of the ACCESS optio n get around this situation:  
 ACCESS OVERWRITE creates a n ew file, even if another file of the same name already exists . 
The e arlier version of the file may be  automatic ally deleted on some ope rating systems.  
 ACCESS APPEND  creates a file if one does not exist, or appends tex t to the end of an existing 
file.  
In the following example, the user att empts to c reate a new file:  
* OUTPUT OUTCOME 
  
Error: Cannot create file; C: \USERS\DEFAULT\KXR\OUTCOME.TXT already exists  
 
 
* OUTPUT <OVERWRITE> OUTCOME  
  
Error: Cannot create file; C :\USERS\DEFAULT\KXR\OUTCOME.TXT already exists 
 
 
* OUTPUT <ACCESS OVERWRI TE> OUTCOM E 
The first OUTPUT comma nd fails because the default access method, ACCESS CREATE , cannot 
overwrite an existing file. The second OUTPUT command fails because we specified th e OVERWRITE 
option, which affects data o bjects, rather than the ACCESS OV ERWRITE op tion. The third OUTPUT 
comm and deletes the file OUTCOME.TXT and creates a new tex t file with the same name, or creates a 
new version of OUTCOME.TXT on systems that support m ultiple versions of files.  
The access mo de specified with the OUTPUT, INF O, or MESS AGE command must not con flict with any 
operating system access codes, or the comm and fails.  
FAME ignores the ACCESS option if you specify a file as TERMINAL. FAME never uses  the KIND option 
with the OUTPUT, INFO, and MESSAGE commands since they o pen only t ext files.  
 
Using Channe ls 
In the discussion of the OUTPUT, INFO, and MESSAGE com mands, we referred to the existence of 
classes  of FAME output. These classes of output exist  to give you finer control over where yo ur output 
goes. For example, if y ou want, y ou can send your reports  and your analytical results to different text 
files. 
To get this fine control, you must follow a two -step process.  
 First, you must choose the channe l where you want a class of output to ap pear. The channel may 
be one of t he FAME -defined channels for textu al output, or it may be the channel name of a text

www.fisglobal.com  279  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
file that you open. Use the CHANNEL option to connect the output class to the channel that you 
choose. 
 Second, you need to use the appropr iate command to open a text file and connec t it to the 
channel. Use  the OUTPUT, INFO, or MESSAGE command for a FAME -defined channel. Use the 
CREATE or OPEN command for a user -defined channel.  
The sequence of the step s is not important. In fact, for some cl asses of output (for example, AUD IT and 
ECH O), reversing the order can avert error messages.  
Before we proceed, you need to know the classes of textual output and the FAME commands that 
produce them. These definition s are fixed by FAME; you cannot alter th em. 
The Classes of Output  
The out put from e ach FAME command belongs  to a specific output class. You cannot change the 
relati onship between a command and its output class. There are nine classes of textual output from  
FAME: 
 FAME produces directed output mes sages  with the TYPE and WRITE com mands. TYP E 
messages are always di rected to the OUTPUT channel. WRITE messages appear on th e 
OUTPUT channel or on the text channel specified in the WRITE command. TYPE and WRITE 
outpu t does not belong to a named class of ou tput and cannot be redirected wit h the CHAN NEL 
option.  
 FAME produce s reports  with the REPORT command. Reports belong to the REPORTS  class of 
output.  
 FAME produces results  with all FAME commands except the GRAPH, REPO RT, SIGNAL, TYPE, 
and WRITE commands. Th e output from these commands belo ngs to the  RESULTS class of 
output . The class is called RESULTS  because it includes the out put from all of FAME’s analytical 
commands.  
 FAME produces trace messages  when TRACE ON  is in effect during the execution of a 
proced ure, or when TUNE TRACE ON  is in effect dur ing the solution of simu ltaneous equations. 
Trace messages belong to the TRACE  class of output.  
 FAME produces progress messages  with the SIGNAL and EDIT commands. The output  from 
these commands belongs to the PROG RESS  class of output.  
 FAME produc es a warni ng message  when it detec ts an error condition that it can handle, or when 
the SIG NAL command is used to create a warning. Warning messages belong to the WARNINGS  
class of ou tput. 
 FAME produces an error message  when it detects an error that causes  a command  or option to 
fail, or w hen the SIGNAL command is used to create an error. These messages belong to the 
ERRORS  class of output.  
 FAME produces an echo  when you use an input f ile. Commands, options, and responses ec hoed 
from an input file belong to  the ECHO  class of output. The ech o includes the prompt that would 
have been issued if the line had come from the FAME session.  
 FAME produces an audit trail  of every statement executed from the ke yboard and from input files. 
This is the AUDIT class of output.  
Each class of output is connected to a channel, as described  next.

www.fisglobal.com  280  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
The CHANNEL Option  
Each of the nine classes of textual output is attached to a specif ic channel. (The classes are not channel s 
themselves.) You can use the CH ANNEL opti on to change the channel s to which nine of the classes are 
attached (you can’t af fect output from TYPE or WRITE with CHANNEL). The channel may be either a 
FAME -defined chann el or a user -defined channel.  
The CHANNE L option has the form CHANNEL cla ss channel , where class is one of the nine classes of 
text named in the preceding section, and channel  is the name of a FAME -defined channel or the channel 
name of a text file opened with the CREATE or OPEN command.  
The fiv e FAME -defined text channels are:  OUTPUT, I NFO, MESSAGE, DIALOG, an d NONE. By default, 
the nine classes of textual output ar e linked to the five FAME -defined channels in the following manner:  
 The TYPE and WRITE comma nds are connected directly to the OUTPUT  channel. You cannot 
change the T YPE comman d’s connection to the OU TPUT channel. The WRITE command has an 
optional argument that lets you connect it to any channel you choose. The CHANNEL option does 
not affect the o utput from these commands.  
 The REPORTS, RESULTS, and TRACE classes are co nnected to  the OUTPUT channel.  
 The PROGRESS, WARNINGS, and ERRORS classes are connected to the INFO channel.  
 The ECHO and AUDIT cl asses are connected to the NONE channel.  The NONE channel 
represents a “d isconnecte d” channel; any output d irected to NONE is irretrievably lost.  
 None of the classe s is connected to the DIALOG channel. The DIALOG channel is connected to 
the window where yo u type interactive commands.  
Thus, the d efault setting of the CHANNEL opt ion for te xtual output is: CHANNEL  REPORTS OUTPUT , 
RESULTS OUTPUT , TRACE OUTPUT , PROGRESS I NFO, WARNINGS INFO , ERRORS INFO , ECHO 
NONE , AUDIT NONE . 
To connect the REPORTS class of outp ut to the user -defined channel MYREP, is sue the option 
CHANNEL REPORTS MY REP. To re store the default, type CHA NNEL REPORTS OUTPUT . 
Each channel is connected to a fi le or window, as described next.  
Connecting a Channel to a File or Window  
When you enter the  FAME environment, four of the FAME -defined text channels, OUTPUT, INFO, 
MESSAGE, a nd DIALOG, are connected  to windows with the same names. The fifth, NONE, is neve r 
connected to a window or a file, but is used to discard output. You can reconnect three of  the channels to 
text files using the OU TPUT, INFO, and MESSAGE commands discussed earlier in this chapter.  For 
example, the command  
OUTPUT MYREP  
connects the OUTPU T channel to the file MYREP.TXT. Each class of output that is directed to the 
OUTPUT channel  (by default, these are the classes REPO RTS, RESULTS, and TRACE) will be sent to 
the file MYREP.TXT. If the  CHANNEL option has been used to redirect one of these cl asses of output 
away from the OUTPUT channel, then that class of output will not appear in M YREP.TXT.  
How would you split off a sing le class of output and send it do  a new des tination? You could use the 
CHANNEL option to direct it to a different FAME -defin ed channel. For example, the command

www.fisglobal.com  281  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
CHANNEL RESULTS INFO  
will send analytical results to th e INFO channel, to be displayed in the w indow or file connected to that 
channel. Ho wever, it’s much more li kely that you want to send a single class of output to it s very own file. 
At the end of the discussion of the OUTPUT command, we provided an example showing how to use the 
OUTPUT command to  send reports to one file and ana lytical re sults to another. A bett er way to do this is 
to open a text file for each class o f output (this was covered in the  chapter TEXT FILES  (p. 242)), and use 
the CHANNEL option to  direct th e output classes to the correct files. Thus, the example session from the 
OUTPUT command becomes:  
OPEN <ACCESS APPEND; KIND TEXT> REPORT.OUT, ANALYSIS.OUT  
CHANNEL REPORTS RE PORT.OUT, RESULTS ANALYSIS.OUT  
FIT SALES _DIST1 BY SALES_FORCE1  
REPORT SAL ES_DIST1, SALES_FORCE1, SALES_DIST 1.FITT 
FIT SALES_DIST2 BY SALES_FORCE2  
REPORT SALES_DIST2 , SALES_FORCE2, SALES_DIST2.FITT  
All of the reports will go to REPORT.OUT, and all of the an alytical results will go to ANALYSIS.OUT , and 
you won’t need to keep usin g the OUTP UT command.  
To connect a n output class to a user -defined channel, you must open a  text file (remembering to specify 
KIND TEXT and an appropriate access method such as APPEND  or OVERWRITE), then use the 
CHANNEL opt ion to connect the output class t o the chan nel name of the text fil e. For example:  
OPEN <ACCESS OVER; KIND TEXT> WALLY  
CHANNEL REPORTS WALLY  
In the example, the text file named WALLY.TXT is opened and assigned the ch annel name WALLY. It will 
receive all of  your reports until you redirect the REPORT S class. If you type:  
OPEN <ACCESS APPEND; KIND TEXT> BOB  
CHANNEL REPORTS BOB  
subsequent reports will go to BOB.TXT. To restore output to your FAME session, type:  
CHANNEL RE PORTS OUTPUT  
OUTPUT TERMINAL  
The second line is unnecessary if you haven’ t redirect ed the OUTPUT channel wi th the OUTPUT 
command.  
You coul d put the following lines in your fame.inp start-up file:  
OPEN <ACCESS AP PEND> TEST .AUD 
CHANNEL AUDIT TEST. AUD 
This example connects the AUDIT output class to the u ser-opened channel named TEST.AUD. Every 
time you enter the FAME environment, an audit trail  of your FAME session will be appended t o the file 
TEST.AUD.  
If you want to see eac h line of an input file as it is executed, type:  
CHANNEL ECHO DIALOG  
This option connects the ECHO output class to the FAME -defined DIALOG channel, which is always 
connected  to the DIALOG window of your FAME sessi on.

www.fisglobal.com  282  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
To keep warnings and error me ssages fro m popping up during a FA ME session, type:  
CHANNEL WARNINGS NONE, ERRORS NONE  
This option connects the WARNINGS and ERRORS output classes to the FAME -defined NONE channel, 
where they are discarded.  
The following ex amples show an illegal CHANNEL op tion, and one possible correction:  
CHANNEL REPORTS TERMINAL    — Illegal 
OUTPUT TERMINAL  
CHANNEL REPORTS OUTPUT  
The first example shown above is illegal because TERMINAL is a file -specification, not a channel name. 
To conne ct reports to the FAME session, y ou should enter the OUTPUT command  and CHANNEL option 
shown above.  
CHANNEL INFO "C: \USERS\WTB\ERROR.INF"    — Illegal 
INFO <ACCESS APPEND> "C: \USERS\WTB\ERROR.INF"  
The first example s hown above is illegal because you cannot  use the CHANNEL option to connec t a 
FAME -defined channel to a file . Instead, you may use the INFO command shown above.  
Hint The ECHO and AUDIT classes of output both print command lines; therefore, the two classes 
should never be routed to the same channe l. Most users connect the ECHO cl ass of out put to 
the DIALOG channe l, and connect the AU¬DIT class of output to a user -defin ed channel.  
Summary of Terms Used in the Redirection of Input and Output  
The following comma nd and option forms, along with the list s of acceptable names and paramet ers, 
summa rize the terms used in t he redirection of input and output.  
Command Forms

CHANNEL output -class channel -name  
RESPO NSE response -specification

www.fisglobal.com  284 WORK WITH FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER STUDIO  
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  is a software graphical user interface for  FIS Market Data Analyzer 
(FAME ). 
Working with the Input/Output win dow in FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  
The Input/Output  window allows you run FAME 4GL code. You can also paste multiple lines of code and 
recall pre vious commands entered in the Input/Ou tput windo w. FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  stores 
the 4GL code that  you type into the Input/Outpu t window for your current session. When you enter code, 
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  automatically fills in the info rmation in the Input/Output  window as yo u 
enter an y of the p revious code used during yo ur current session. When you perform actions using the FIS 
Market Data Analyzer studio  menus and controls, the actions are translated to 4GL commands that 
appear in the Input/Output  window.  
The Input/Output  window displays th e followin g tabs:  
 Output : This tab di splays the out put of the code executed in the Input/Outp ut window.  By 
default, this tab also displays the errors and warnings generated due to incorrect code execu ted 
in the Input/Output  window.  
Note  If you want to disp lay errors in a separate tab, set  CHANNEL ERRORS IN FO. If you 
want to revert to displaying errors in the Output  tab, set CHANNEL ERRORS OUTPUT . 
If you want to display warnings in a separate tab, set CHANNEL WARNINGS INFO . If 
you wan t to rev ert to displayin g warnings in the Output  tab, set CHANNEL WARNINGS 
OUTPUT. 
 MESSAGE : This tab disp lays messa ges that are sent to the pr e-defined MESSAGE channel 
using the WRITE command or the  CHANNEL option.  
To execu te the code  
1. In the input field in the Input/Output  windo w, enter the code you want to execute.  
2. Click Code  > Run. Alternatively, click the  
  button or press the ENTER key on y our 
keyboard.  
To halt the execution of the code, do one of the following:  
• Click Code > Stop . Alternatively, click the 
  button. 
If you sto p the code and enter a command in the input field i n the Input/Output  window, the  
previous command is ignored and the new command is executed when you run the code again.

www.fisglobal.com  285  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
• Click Code  > Pause . Alternati vely, click the

Now, we will create a new data s erver connect ion to a remot e database  and add it to t he sample project . 
You can ope n remote databases in FIS Market Data  Analyzer studio  by creating and using data server 
connections. The data server connection allows you to open remote databases for r eading or writing  data. 
You can creat e, edit, and delete saved data server connections. Data server connections can be of th e 
following types:  
 Global data server connection : Connection that is available for use globally within a FIS Market 
Data Analyzer  studio  session. A global data server connecti on can be used  in multiple projects.  
 Project data server  connection : Connection t hat is used by a particular project. The project 
data ser ver connection can be added from the list of global data server connections or a new data 
server connection can be add ed separately for a specific project.  
 Ad hoc data server  connection : Connection t hat is not used by a particular project. The ad hoc 
data server connection can be added by using the CONNECT statement in the Input/Output  
window. A d hoc connections are displ ayed only in t he Session Explorer. However, channels for  
an ad hoc connection are  not displayed in the Session Explorer.

Working with the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  text editor  
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  has an in tegrated text editor to enable you to edit your .inp and . pro 
code files. You can right -click to open the context menu in a file opened in the text editor to execute the 
INPUT, COMPILE, or CLOAD c ommands on your code . 
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  text e ditor provides the followin g features : 
 View and edit multiple do cuments 
• Tabbed view that allows you to switch between fi les using file selection tab.  
• CTRL+TAB allows you to switch between files.  
• Tiled a nd cascaded vi ew for viewing and editing multiple file s opened in the text editor . 
 Syntax h ighlighting  
• If you open an .inp or .pro file in the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  text editor, the syntax of 
the code is displayed in appropriate color codes. See Color  coding legend in FIS Market Data  
Analyz er studio  (p. 296) for more information.  
 Undo / redo actions  
• Any file  can always be undone to its initial contents.  
• Unlimited undo and redo actions.  
 Find and Replace  
• Replace specified text one by one, or as a whole.  
 Line numbering  
• FIS Market Data Analyzer stud io text editor can automatically count the lines in a file and 
display the appropriate number beside each line of text. This is useful when you need to refer 
to specific lines in a file. If  there is any error in the code of a procedur e file tha t is compile d 
using FIS Market Data Analyzer studio , the line number is displayed in the Output (OUTPUT)  
tab of the Input/Output  window.  
• Navigate to a specified line numbe r within the code.  
Note  If you  want to use a different text editor, you can invok e a differ ent text editor through the  
Input/Output  window. For example, enter the following c ode in the Input/Output  window:  
!Notepad TEST.INP

 As you type in the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  text editor or in the Input/Output  window,

itself. Another use of comm ents is to "commen t out" code to prevent  FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  
from executing it. Two consecutiv e hyphens are added as prefix to the lines of code that are to be 
commented out.

used source patterns. Templates are ins erted by right -clicking in the file contents opened in t he active text 
editor window.

Working with STUDIO tags  
STUDIO  tags are hints embedded in code f iles to in voke FIS Market Data Analyzer studi o to take certain 
actions. All STUDIO  tags begin with ----STUDIO_  and are followed by further text.  
Types o f STUDIO tags  
STUDIO  tags are  of the following types:  
 Passive STUDIO  tags - These tags must be carried out by making cho ices from right -click conte xt 
menus in the text editor by typing the keyboard short cut for the menu choice.  
 Active STUDIO  tags - These t ags are automatically detecte d by FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  
when a code file is opened and are immediately exe cuted.  
List of STUDIO tags  
 ----STUDIO_SUGGESTION_COMMAND  
 ----STUDIO_SUGGE STION_FUNCTION  
 ----STUDIO_SUGGESTION_OPTION  
 ----STUDIO_SUGGESTION_O BJECT_NAME 
 ----STUDIO_BEGIN_RUN_DEF AULT and ----STUDIO_END_RUN_DEFAULT  
 ----STUDIO_BEGIN_TESTS and ----STUDIO_END_TES TS 
 ----STUDIO_RUN_TESTS_ON_OPEN  
 ----STUDIO_CLOAD_ON_OPEN

Running default code snippets in FIS Market Data Analyzer stu dio 
You can incl ude entire sections of F AME 4GL code in code files in th e form of commented out lines of 
FAME 4GL using FIS Market Data Analyzer studio . The ----STUDIO_BEGIN_RUN_DEFAULT  and ----
STUDIO_END_RUN_DEFAULT  tags allow you to insert  commented  out code. The commented ou t code is 
ignored by the FAME compiler but provides a me ans to define a default set o f code that can be invoked 
within the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  environment. The default set of code can be executed even 
when you do not know at run-time the specific pro cedure or us er-defined function name and arguments 
requi red to invoke their exe cution. In the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  environment, this enables the 
procedure file to operate more like a FAME input file with a defined default set of FAME code.  
FIS Market Data A nalyzer studio  searches in the code file for the followi ng paired STUDIO tags:  
----STUDIO_BEGIN_RUN_DEFAULT  
 
<FAME 4GL code>  
----STUDIO_EN D_RUN_DEFAULT  
If you want the default code to be run whenever the code file is  opened, then  include the tag ----
STUDIO_RUN_DEFAULT_ON_OPEN  anywhere within the code file.  
Note  that the F AME  4GL code should be commented out with two dashes. For the ----
STUDIO_BEGIN_RUN_DEFAULT  and ----STUDIO_END_RUN_DEFAULT  tags, the code between thes e 
tags need t o have any leading two dash es removed upon execution. However, because the leading two 
dashes are removed, any comments must have four dashes.  
Example  
----STUDIO_BEG IN_RUN_DEFAULT  
----First extraction uses Japan  
--$extract "Japan"  
----Now extr action uses C hina

www.fisglobal.com  302  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
--$extract "China"  
----STUDIO_END_RUN_DEFAULT  
While two dashes before a line o f code are not explicitly required between the BEGIN  and END tags, the 
absence of two dashes means the line of code is included and subject to the rules of prof ile file 
comp ilation.  
The two dashes als o allow the code to execute in older FAME versions or in  a FAME env ironment outside 
the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  environment.  
To run defa ult code in open files  
1. In the FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  text edito r, open the fil e in which  you want to ru n the 
defaul t code.  
2. Right -click and select Run default code . 
Runnin g tests in FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  
You can include some sections in .pro files th at can test features of the code that are being currently 
developed.  These secti ons are en closed by  STUDIO  tags that are useful in procedure files but are also 
allowe d in input files. When you write test code for developing user -defined functions and user -defined 
procedures, you can use STUDIO  tags to help debug c ode as you write it. After the code is s table you can 
use the test sections to verify that the code still w orks, if and when you make small changes to it.  
FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  searches in the  code file for the following paired STUDIO  tags:  
----STUDIO_BEGIN_TESTS  
<FAME 4GL  code> 
----STUDIO_END_TESTS  
and runs tests on FAME 4GL code enclosed by these STUDIO tags. Th ere may be multiple such sections 
enclosed by the BEGIN_TESTS  and END_TESTS  tags i n a given code file. This can be useful for having 
individual tests for each proc edure or f unction in a .pro file. You  need not make any selection to run the 
tests. However, if required, you may also run tests on selected lines of code in FIS Market Data Analyzer 
studio . 
If you want the code enclosed by the STUDIO_BEGIN_TESTS  and STUDIO_END_ TESTS  tags to be run 
whenever the cod e file is opened, then include the ta g ----STUDIO_RUN_TE STS_ON_OPEN  anywhere 
within the code file. Alternatively, the code within the STUDIO_BEGIN_TESTS  and STUDIO_END_TESTS  
tags can be executed when Run tests  is select ed from  the right-click context menu.  The 4GL code 
enclosed by the STUDIO  tags can be run onl y when 2 hyphens precede each line of the 4GL code. Lines 
of 4GL code preceded by 4 hyphens produce no output but are displayed in  the DIALOG window as 
comments.  
Example  
In the following example, the DISPLAY @BANNER  statement (enclosed b y the STUDIO  tags) is executed 
when the code file is opened:  
----STUDIO_BEGIN_TESTS  
--DISPLAY @BANNER  
----STUDIO_END_TESTS  
DISPLAY LEFT("Company name ",10)

FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
----STUDIO_RUN_TESTS_ON_OPE N

2. Right -click and select Run tests . You may also use  the Run tests with CLEAR option to clear 
the output after running the tests.  
To run tests on selected code in open fi les 
1. In the FIS Market Data Anal yzer studio  text editor, open t he file in which you want to run the tests.  
2. Select the code on which you want to r un the tests. Ensure that the select ion includes ----
STUDIO_BEGIN_TESTS  and ----STUDIO_END_ TESTS  tags in which the FAM E 4GL code to be 
tested i s enclosed.  
3. Right -click and sel ect Run selected tests . You may also use the Run selected tests with 
CLEAR  option to clear the output after running th e tests.

Encoding  
The Encoding tab contains setting to  control the encoding format of the text editor in FIS Market 
Data Analyzer studio . 
 
Field Descri ption 
Western European (Wi ndows -
1252)  When this option i s selected, Windows -1252 e ncoding format  is used. 
This is the default encoding format for FIS Market Data A nalyzer 
studio . 
Japanese (Shift_JIS)  When this option is selected, Shift -JIS encoding f ormat is u sed. It is a 
character enco ding format for the Japa nese language.  
Unicode (UTF -8) When thi s option is selected, UTF -8 encoding format is used. It 
represents any character in the Unicode standard. UTF -8 is 
backwards compatible with ASCII. UTF -8 is also the preferred 
encoding format for e -mail and web pages . 
 
MASTUDIO Comman d 
The MASTUDIO comman d is used on the command line and it opens input, procedure, and pr oject files 
in FIS Market Data Analyzer studio . 
You can enter the path to a proje ct file on  the command line as the fi rst argument. FIS Market Data 
Analyzer studio  will start up wi th that p roject opened in Project Explorer. Similarly, you can enter the pat h 
to a procedure or input file on the command line and FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  will s tart up wi th 
the procedure or input f ile opened in the t ext editor.  
Form  
"%FAME%\MAStudio.exe  <complete file name and path>" [ --clean] [ --defaultLayout]  
--clean (o ptional) 
Is a command line setting that removes any persistent settings such as user preferen ces, recen t file lists, 
and customize d window layouts an d starts FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  in a fresh state.

www.fisglobal.com  312  
FIS MARKET DATA ANALYZER  2022.Q4  USER  GUIDE  
For example,  
%FAME%\MAStudio.exe --clean 
--defau ltLayout (optional ) 
Is a command line setting that resets only the customized window layouts to the  default s tate. 
Examples  
 Open a proje ct in FIS Mar ket Data Analyzer studio : 
"%FAME%\MAStudio.exe D: \FAME\project.masp"  
 You can also open an .inp or .pro file  in FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  using the command line:  
%FAME%\MAStudio.exe D: \FAME\input.inp  
%FAME%\MAStudio.exe D: \FAME\procedure.pro  
In Windo ws Explorer, you can Shift + right -click on .masp, .inp,  and .pro files to associate them with 
MAStudio.exe . Double-clicking the project o r file will open that project or file in FIS Market Data Analyzer 
studio .

Loaded Functions in FIS Market Data Anal yzer studio  
The Loaded Func tions  node in the Session Explorer shows  a list of all the currently loaded functi ons. 
When you open a FIS Market Data Analyzer studio  project that has .pro files marked  as auto -compile and  
load, then for e ach user -defined functi on in such files, a row is added to the Loaded Functions  node in 
the Session Explorer. In the Studio text editor, w hen you manually compile and load a .pro file that 
contains user -defined function s, a row i s added to  the Loaded Funct ions node for each user -defined 
function included in tha t file. When a new row is added to  the Loaded Functions  node, the property and 
value of the user -defined function is displayed in the row. The Property  column disp lays the n ame of the  
user-defined fun ction and the Value  column contains information about ho w the user -defined function 
was ob tained. 
Depending on how a user -defined function  is loaded in FIS Market Data Analyzer studio , the Value  
column displays the correspond ing inform ation: 
 
If the source of th e loaded function  is… The Value column displays...  
A .pro file compiled and loaded with a COMPILE 
command followed by a LOAD command.  The full path and file name of the .pro file . 
A .pro file compiled and loaded with a CLOAD 
command. The file name of the  .pro file but wi thout the full path .

the sequence of events a fter the f unction is invoked .

1. In the Loaded Fun ctions  node, right -click a f unction and click Properties . 
The Loaded Functions  dialog box provides information about how many arguments a particular 
function can a ccept and what types of arguments are  supported. You c an also enter argument 
values convenien tly. 
2. In the Loaded Functions  dialog box that opens for the user -defined loaded fun ction, the 
following argument fields are displayed:  
 
Field  Description  
Value  Enter the val ue of the argument. This fi eld can be edited . 
Name  Name of the argument.  
Type  Data type of the specified argu ment. The argument type can be any of 
the following:  
 NUMERIC  
 PRECISION  
 STRING  
 DATE  
 BOOLEAN  
 NAMELIST  
Applies to SERIES and SCALARS.  
Class Data cl ass of the specified argume nt. The argument class can be any 
of the following:  
 SERI ES 
 SCALAR  
 FORMULA  
Index Typ e Index can be either DATE or CASE. For series indexed  by DATE, the 
associated frequency is displayed. Applies to SERIES only.  
Default  Indicates  whether an argument was de clared with a def ault value. For 
example, true or false.  
Usage  Indicates the most g eneral form the actual argument can have based 
on how it was used in the body of the source code of the user -defined 
loaded function. I t can have  one of the following value s: 
 expression  
 variable - Name or database name with an i ndex. For example, 
IBM.CLOSE [22aug12] or PRC'IBM.CLOSE[22aug12])  
 dname - Optional database label followed by data object name. 
For example, tr'ibm.close or ibm.clo se. 
 variab le without database label  
 name
